('22', 0, 1, 2, 44) 1. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS
('22', 0, 2, 3, 71) ALIGARH, November 23 [1920] 1
('22', 0, 3, 4, 101) MY DEAREST CHARLIE 2, I have your letters and your wire.
('22', 0, 3, 5, 158) Have I done you an injustice?
('22', 0, 3, 6, 188) I simply wired saying I was trying to send you—I did not say you had accepted the post.
('22', 0, 3, 7, 276) And I said what I did on the strength of our conversation.
('22', 0, 3, 8, 335) 3 In any case there will be no pressure whatsoever brought to bear on you.
('22', 0, 3, 9, 410) You wills simply do what you can for the Muslim University.
('22', 0, 3, 10, 470) Yes I realize the necessity of putting the English connection on a pure basis.
('22', 0, 3, 11, 549) In its present condition it is hateful.
('22', 0, 3, 12, 589) But I am not as yet sure that it must be ended at any cost.
('22', 0, 3, 13, 649) It may be that the English temperament is not responsive to a status of perfect equality with the black and the brown races.
('22', 0, 3, 14, 774) Then the English must be made to retire from India.
('22', 0, 3, 15, 826) But I am not prepared to reject the possibility of an honourable equality.
('22', 0, 3, 16, 901) The connection must end on the clearest possible proof that the English have hopelessly failed to realize the first principle of religion, namely, brotherhood of man.
('22', 0, 3, 17, 1068) Baro Dada’s 4 letter has not been received by me.
('22', 0, 3, 18, 1118) It may be in the Ashram or it may be received by me tomorrow on reaching Delhi.
('22', 0, 3, 19, 1198) I have duly telegraphed to you.
('22', 0, 3, 20, 1230) I cannot wire any message to Dr. Dutta but if there is yet time I shall endeavour to write out something for him.
('22', 0, 3, 21, 1344) I do hope you are keeping well.
('22', 0, 3, 22, 1376) I do not wonder at the Gujarati children having been withdrawn.
('22', 0, 3, 23, 1440) 5 I do not think you have lost anything.
('22', 0, 3, 24, 1481) You cannot whittle down principles to keep a single boy.
('22', 0, 3, 25, 1538) I have not told youwhat I

('22', 1, 4, 15, 3049) 2. SPEECH ON NON CO OPERATION, AGRA 2
('22', 1, 5, 16, 3087) November 23, 1920
('22', 1, 6, 17, 3105) Mr. Gandhi began by referring to the recent Hindu Muslim disturbances at Agra and congratulated the people for settling the dispute without the intervention of the authorities.
('22', 1, 6, 18, 3282) He said it grieved him to see a disorderly meeting as that would not enable them to attain swaraj.
('22', 1, 6, 19, 3381) He said the procession 3 wasted time and huge meetings did not serve the purposes for which they were held.
('22', 1, 6, 20, 3489) They both wasted time and he would perhaps have to take a vow that he would not go out in a procession and would not address huge meetings.
('22', 1, 6, 21, 3629) India was in mourning for the 1,500 killed at the Jallianwala Bagh and he could not tolerate the idea of music and procession while in mourning.
('22', 1, 6, 22, 3774) He regretted that foreign articles were used in the decorations and buntings and foreign candles and lamps were used for the illumination.
('22', 1, 6, 23, 3913) These methods would not help them to get the Khilafat wrongs righted and to attain swaraj.
('22', 1, 7, 24, 4004) He said he had come to address the students only and would soon leave the meeting to address them at his residence, where only students could attend.
('22', 1, 7, 25, 4154) He said he regarded the Government as Satanic and was confident that swaraj could be attained in one year if the people became truthful and behaved better.
('22', 1, 7, 26, 4310) The Government called him

('22', 2, 3, 8, 5142) 3. SPEECH AT STUDENTS’ MEETING, AGRA 4
('22', 2, 4, 9, 5181) November 23, 1920 At no other place have I been as unhappy as I felt after coming here.
('22', 2, 4, 10, 5269) With all this confusion, you will not help me in my mission here.
('22', 2, 4, 11, 5335) When there is so much disorder, how can I advise students to leave college?
('22', 2, 6, 12, 5411) We are dazzled by the shining lustre of our chains and look upon them as the symbols of our freedom.
('22', 2, 6, 13, 5512) This state [of mind] bespeaks slavery of the worst kind.
('22', 2, 7, 14, 5569) Speaking about the timidity induced by their education, Gandhiji said: We may feel in our heart any measure of devotion for Tilak Maharaj, but where is the student who will express it freely?
('22', 2, 8, 15, 5761) * * * For us, fear has become synonymous with life.
('22', 2, 8, 16, 5813) What is the use of that education which does not help us to overcome fear, but which, on the contrary, strengthens it?
('22', 2, 8, 17, 5932) What kind of an education is it which does not teach us to follow truth and to cultivate devotion for the country?
('22', 2, 8, 18, 6047) But my argument is not merely that we should give up this education because it is bad.
('22', 2, 8, 19, 6134) My argument is that we ought not to receive it because it is provided by those who hold us in slavery.
('22', 2, 8, 20, 6237) From his owner a slave will not learn the lesson of freedom.
('22', 2, 8, 21, 6298) This Empire has

('22', 3, 1, 2, 6828) become defiled; even if this Satanic Empire should propose to give me training for freedom, I may not receive it.
('22', 3, 1, 3, 6942) No matter what the quality of this education, what is its source?
('22', 3, 1, 4, 7008) Why are you taken in because they teach you big books?
('22', 3, 1, 5, 7063) They do not give you real education in freedom, only deceive you into believing that they do.
('22', 3, 1, 6, 7157) In point of fact, it is with money stolen from the country that they give you this education by which you are taken in, and that is like using money stolen from a man to teach him to drink.
('22', 3, 1, 7, 7347) * * * As a boy, I loved my parents as Shravana 1 loved his.
('22', 3, 1, 8, 7407) I believe in God, too.
('22', 3, 1, 9, 7430) Would I, then, ask anyone to do something in disregard of his parents’ wishes?
('22', 3, 1, 10, 7509) However, one’s parents, too, were created by God and I have been arguing that, when parents’ wishes conflict with God’s command, one should obey the latter.
('22', 3, 1, 11, 7666) Those of you who feel in the depth of their heart that they will not learn lessons of freedom in schools run by an Empire such as I have described, who hear a command from God that, in order to secure freedom, they need to shake off this slavery, should reason with their parents respectfully.
('22', 3, 1, 12, 7960) If you feel that this is a house on fire, that you have no choice but to run out of it, only then should you abandon it.
('22', 3, 1, 13, 8081) I feel all the twenty four hours that I cannot live a moment longer under this Empire and, if you feel the same way, you would not want to ask if alternative schools had been provided for you.
('22', 3, 1, 14, 8274) Leaving your school or college without making conditions is the first lesson in freedom.
('22', 3, 1, 15, 8363) If, however, you do not have patience enough to occupy yourselves after leaving your school with collecting funds for a free school till one is set up, if you do not have patience to live by begging meanwhile, most certainly do not leave your school.
('22', 3, 1, 16, 8614) You should get training for bodily labour.
('22', 3, 1, 17, 8657) When an English boy comes out of school or college, he certainly has the strength for such labour.
('22', 3, 1, 18, 8756) If, however, your only ambition, after completing your education, is to be lawyers or the Government’s hacks, the present schools and colleges are the only ones for you.
('22', 3, 1, 19, 8926) If you understand the dignity of the ancient practice of madhukari 2 which is followed in Maharashtra even today, you should even live by begging and study.
('22', 3, 1, 20, 9083) If you have not acquired the strength for this, I do not want to win the country’s freedom through you.
('22', 3, 2, 21, 9187) 1 A youth, in the Ramayana, who was devoted to his aged parents and carried them on his shoulders to various places of pilgrimage 2 Collecting alms from door to door; literally, the collection of honey by the bee moving from flower to flower.
('22', 3, 2, 22, 9430) Here the reference is to the practice of students without means of support having their meals with different families by turns.

('22', 4, 1, 3, 9645) One who, in spite of it, has faith in God, who has mastered the senses, has observed the vow of non stealing and practised non violence—such a one may claim to hear the voice of conscience.
('22', 4, 1, 4, 9835) I, therefore, address myself only to those students who have been trained in self control and I tell them that they may unhesitatingly leave college if they hear the command of God.

('22', 5, 1, 2, 12261) 5. MORE DIFFICULTIES
('22', 5, 2, 3, 12282) The resolution 1 of the senate of the Gujarat National University in regard to Mr. Andrews’ question about the admission of children of the ‘depressed’ classes to the schools affiliated to that University is reported to have raised a flutter in Ahmedabad.
('22', 5, 2, 4, 12538) Not only has the flutter given satisfaction to a Times of India correspondent, but the occasion has led to the discovery by him of another defect in the constitution of the senate in that it does not contain a single Muslim member.
('22', 5, 2, 5, 12770) The discovery, however, I may inform the reader, is no proof of the want of national character of the University.
('22', 5, 2, 6, 12884) The Hindu Muslim unity is no mere lip expression.
('22', 5, 2, 7, 12934) It requires no artificial proofs.
('22', 5, 2, 8, 12968) The simple reason why there is no Mussulman representative on the senate is that no higher educated Mussulman, able to give his time, has been found to take sufficient interest in the national education movement.
('22', 5, 2, 9, 13181) I merely refer to this matter to show that we must reckon with attempts to discredit the movement even by misinterpretation of motives.
('22', 5, 2, 10, 13317) That is a difficulty from without and easier to deal with.
('22', 5, 2, 11, 13376) The ‘depressed’ classes difficulty is internal and therefore far more serious, because it may give rise to a split and weaken the cause—no cause can survive internal difficulties if they are indefinitely multiplied.
('22', 5, 2, 12, 13592) Yet there can be no surrender in the matter of principles for the avoidance of splits.
('22', 5, 2, 13, 13679) You cannot promote a cause when you are undermining it by surrendering its vital parts.
('22', 5, 2, 14, 13767) The ‘depressed’ classes problem is a vital part of the cause.
('22', 5, 2, 15, 13829) Swaraj is as inconceivable without full reparation to the ‘depressed’ classes as it is impossible without real Hindu Muslim unity.
('22', 5, 2, 16, 13960) In my opinion we have become ‘pariahs of the Empire’ because we have created ‘pariahs’ in our midst.
('22', 5, 2, 17, 14061) The slave owner is always more hurt than the slaves.
('22', 5, 2, 18, 14114) We shall be unfit to gain swaraj so long as we would keep in bondage a fifth of the population of Hindustan.
('22', 5, 2, 19, 14223) Have we not made the ‘pariah’ crawl on his belly?
('22', 5, 2, 20, 14273) Have we not segregated him?
('22', 5, 2, 21, 14301) And if it is religion so to treat the ‘pariah’, it is the religion of the white race to segregate us.
('22', 5, 2, 22, 14403) And if it is no argument for the white races to say that we are satisfied with the badge of our inferiority, it is less for us to say that the ‘pariah’ is satisfied with his.
('22', 5, 2, 23, 14578) Our slavery is complete when we begin to hug it.
('22', 5, 2, 24, 14627) The Gujarat senate therefore counted the cost when it refused to bend before the storm.
('22', 5, 2, 25, 14715) This non co operation is a process of self purification.
('22', 5, 2, 26, 14772) We may not cling to putrid customs and claim the pure boon of swaraj.
('22', 5, 2, 27, 14842) Untouchability, I hold, is a custom, not an
('22', 5, 3, 28, 14886) 1Vide footnote 1, “Conditions for Swaraj and practice of untouchability”, 21 11 1920.
('22', 6, 0, 1, 14972) VOL. 22 : 15 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 7
('22', 6, 1, 2, 15016) integral part of Hinduism.
('22', 6, 1, 3, 15043) The world has advanced in thought, though it is still barbarous in action.
('22', 6, 1, 4, 15118) And no religion can stand that which is not based on fundamental truths.
('22', 6, 1, 5, 15191) Any glorification of error will destroy a religion as surely as disregard of a disease is bound to destroy a body.
('22', 6, 1, 6, 15306) This Government of ours is an unscrupulous corporation.
('22', 6, 1, 7, 15362) It has ruled by dividing Mussulmans from Hindus.
('22', 6, 1, 8, 15411) It is quite capable of taking advantage of the internal weaknesses of Hindusim.
('22', 6, 1, 9, 15491) It will set the ‘depressed’ classes against the rest of the Hindus, non Brahmins against Brahmins.
('22', 6, 1, 10, 15590) The Gujarat senate resolution does not end the trouble.
('22', 6, 1, 11, 15646) It merely points out the difficulty.
('22', 6, 1, 12, 15683) The trouble will end only when the masses and classes of Hindus have rid themselves of the sin of untouchability.
('22', 6, 1, 13, 15797) A Hindu lover of swaraj will as assiduously work for the amelioration of the lot of the ‘depressed’ classes as he works for Hindu Muslim unity.
('22', 6, 1, 14, 15941) We must treat them as our brothers and give them the same rights that we claim for ourselves.
('22', 6, 1, 15, 16035) Young India, 24 11 1920
('22', 6, 2, 16, 16059) 6. COUNCIL ELECTIONS 1
('22', 6, 3, 17, 16082) The elections in the Bombay Presidency and elsewhere have demonstrated the success of non co operation about Councils, in so far as the voters are concerned.
('22', 6, 3, 18, 16240) In some cases not a single voter seems to have registered his vote.
('22', 6, 3, 19, 16308) What will the so called representatives do?
('22', 6, 3, 20, 16352) They know that the voters have refrained from going to the polls not out of laziness but out of deliberation.
('22', 6, 3, 21, 16462) They know, too, that thousands of voters have declared in writing their intention not to be represented.
('22', 6, 3, 22, 16567) The members had ample opportunity of acting on the electors and convincing them of the desirability of voting.
('22', 6, 3, 23, 16678) They cannot complain [of] intimidation or even picketing.
('22', 6, 3, 24, 16736) For the instructions were not to picket, and, as far as I am aware, the instructions were implicitly followed.
('22', 6, 3, 25, 16847) In the face of these facts, is it not the clear duty of the members declared to have been elected not to have anything to do with the Council?
('22', 6, 3, 26, 16990) The electors have shown in no uncertain terms that they do not want to have anything to do with the reformed Councils.
('22', 6, 3, 27, 17109) The members will reduce representative institutions to an absurdity if they persist in going to the Council when they have the clearest possible mandate to the contrary.
('22', 6, 3, 28, 17279) If the so called representatives do not obey the mandate of their electors, the course of the latter is quite clear.
('22', 6, 3, 29, 17396) They must form voters’
('22', 6, 4, 30, 17419) 1 Elections for the various Legislatures took place in November 1920; those for the Bombay Legislative Council were held on November 16.
('22', 7, 0, 1, 17556) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 7, 1, 2, 17596) associations, and through these bodies pass votes of no confidence; they must address their respective members notifying their disapproval of their conduct in allowing themselves to be declared elected.
('22', 7, 1, 3, 17799) It follows, too, that the electors must not on any account whatsoever take any work from these members.
('22', 7, 1, 4, 17903) For them the Council does not exist.
('22', 7, 1, 5, 17940) They must not seek any relief through it.
('22', 7, 1, 6, 17982) The next trial of the voters will commence when the Council is opened, if at all, in the face of this verdict.
('22', 7, 1, 7, 18093) The temptation to air grievances by having questions put in the Council will be very great.
('22', 7, 1, 8, 18185) The electors will have to resist the temptation.
('22', 7, 1, 9, 18234) But let us hope for the good name of our country that the members themselves will bow to the verdict so emphatically declared by the electors.
('22', 7, 1, 10, 18377) Young India, 24 11 1920
('22', 7, 2, 11, 18401) 7. STATE OF PRIMARY EDUCATION
('22', 7, 3, 12, 18431) Pandit Gangaram Sharma’s 1 letter 2 reproduced elsewhere is a seasonable contribution to the question of national education.
('22', 7, 3, 13, 18556) He has even been making a useful experiment in primary education in the Punjab, and is able to throw a flood of light on this very important problem.
('22', 7, 3, 14, 18706) His refusal to take Government grant and affiliate his school makes his scheme specially attractive.
('22', 7, 3, 15, 18807) It has received the blessings of Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviyaji and Mr. Shastriar.
('22', 7, 3, 16, 18889) The programme is ambitious and well thought out.
('22', 7, 3, 17, 18938) The scheme is inexpensive.
('22', 7, 3, 18, 18965) My fear is that it is overweighed with too many items.
('22', 7, 3, 19, 19020) But one has hardly the right to criticize an experiment without careful study on the spot.
('22', 7, 3, 20, 19111) I question the advisability of introducing a knowledge of English in any scheme of primary education.
('22', 7, 3, 21, 19213) In my opinion millions of boys and girls of this country do not need to know English at all.
('22', 7, 3, 22, 19306) They need ideas rather than languages.
('22', 7, 3, 23, 19345) And I would give even little children ideas about swaraj and other essential matters without their having to wait for higher literary knowledge.
('22', 7, 3, 24, 19490) The present system and method of education fill a boy with many useless facts and leave him without proper mental development till he begins to receive a high school training.
('22', 7, 3, 25, 19666) Thus we have come to think quite unwarrantably that we cannot imbibe true ideas of liberty, religion, etc., without a knowledge of English, and have therefore made of it a fetish.
('22', 7, 4, 26, 19846) 1 A Congress worker in the Punjab 2 Not reproduced here
('22', 8, 0, 1, 19902) VOL. 22 : 15 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 9
('22', 8, 1, 2, 19946) The more interesting part of Pandit Gangaram Sharma’s letter lies in the information he imparts about the difficulties placed in his way by the local officials and the startling figures he produces regarding the ‘progress’ of primary education in the Punjab.
('22', 8, 1, 3, 20205) It would appear that in 1844, in a population of 127 lakhs, there were 30,000 indigenous schools, catering for 4 lakhs of children.
('22', 8, 1, 4, 20337) In 1918 19, with a population of 190 lakhs, there were only 933 indigenous schools and 4,171 Government schools, catering in all for 239,332 children.
('22', 8, 1, 5, 20488) If the figures are correct, the state of primary education in the Punjab is worse now than it was in 1849, i.e., before British occupation.
('22', 8, 1, 6, 20628) Yet we are told that if we nationalize education, we cannot finance it!
('22', 8, 1, 7, 20700) There are other equally damaging figures and facts Pandit Gangaram Sharma has shown me.
('22', 8, 1, 8, 20788) I must deal with them later.
('22', 8, 2, 9, 20817) Young India, 24 11 1920

('22', 9, 14, 16, 22340) I spoke to you a few months ago about self control.
('22', 9, 14, 17, 22392) 5 Today also, the purpose of my visit here is to speak, as I understand the matter, on the same subject.
('22', 9, 14, 18, 22497) It is being said these days that I am putting wild ideas into students’ heads.
('22', 9, 14, 19, 22576) With a full sense of responsibility, I declare that I am doing nothing of the kind.
('22', 9, 14, 20, 22660) I can never think of putting such ideas into their heads.
('22', 9, 14, 21, 22718) I was also a student once and I did everything in my student days with full respect for elders.
('22', 9, 14, 22, 22814) I am, moreover, the father of four sons and I have had hundreds of boys who came to me and to whom I still claim to be a father.
('22', 9, 14, 23, 22943) That being so it is impossible that I should utter any words intended to put wild ideas into people’s heads.

('22', 10, 1, 9, 24879) To be sure, perfect truth is in silence alone but, so long as it is necessary to employ language, it can reflect the perfect truth only when I describe a situation to you exactly as I see it.

('22', 24, 3, 6, 60472) 16. TO WOMEN
('22', 24, 4, 7, 60485) I started begging for money at Dakor and, fortunately, I made a beginning with women.
('22', 24, 4, 8, 60571) 1 Among them, the sister who first gave me a piece of jewellery made a living by grinding flour for others.
('22', 24, 4, 9, 60679) When she took off her earring and handed it over to me, that same moment I was convinced that India’s women had understood the holy nature of peaceful non co operation.

('22', 27, 6, 16, 67243) November 28, 1920
('22', 27, 7, 17, 67261) Mahatma Gandhi, who was given a great ovation, in the course of his speech in Hindustani, emphasized at the outset that it was a time for action and not for speeches and meetings.

('22', 27, 7, 19, 67625) It had been deceiving the Indians so long and it was not yet penitent and rather asked them to forget the wrongs it had done them.

('22', 28, 2, 16, 69853) In dealing with such a Government it was impossible for them to hope to defeat it by worldly force; neither should they meet violence by violence.
('22', 28, 2, 17, 70000) To punish the Satan they should not employ Satanic means.

('22', 51, 3, 9, 131515) Those who wanted to sell that yarn might do so, but those who did not want to sell that should give it away as charity to others because of all the charities the charity of cloth was the best.
('22', 51, 3, 10, 131708) India became poorer all the more from the time this charkha was given up.
('22', 51, 3, 11, 131782) Women, who formerly used to live upon the charkha, were now leading a very miserable life in the bondage of slavery, breaking bricks and stones and being abused by overseers.
('22', 51, 3, 12, 131957) He had come across many women in Champaran who had got only one sari to cover their body with and hence they could not go for a bath in the Ganges when they wanted to do so.
('22', 51, 3, 13, 132131) Their life of freedom, when they used to have clothes made of the yarn spun by their own hands, was no more.

('22', 53, 8, 16, 136678) 39. SPEECH AT ARRAH
('22', 53, 9, 17, 136698) December 4, 1920
('22', 53, 10, 18, 136715) Mahatma Gandhi addressed the audience seated on a chair.
('22', 53, 10, 19, 136772) He said that he rejoiced extremely to see such a huge gathering of the Arrah people before him but at the same time it pained him to find that they were unable to hold the meeting in an orderly fashion.
('22', 53, 10, 20, 136975) 5 He added that the noise was so great that he had to lose half an hour of his time in asking the people to keep quiet, and asked if they could not discipline and control themselves, how could they hope to obtain swaraj in a year?
('22', 53, 10, 21, 137206) That was, he said, the first essential for obtaining swaraj.
('22', 53, 10, 22, 137267) Proceeding, Mahatmaji said that he had not forgotten the Shahabad riots that took place a few years ago, nor the fact that

('22', 54, 1, 4, 137996) He would like to tell them that they should settle their differences among themselves.
('22', 54, 1, 5, 138083) What was wanted was Hindu Muslim unity—not a sham unity, but a unity of heart and soul.
('22', 54, 1, 6, 138171) If they wanted to protect Islam from danger, to secure justice for the Punjab wrongs and to obtain swaraj, it could be only by means of co operation among themselves.
('22', 54, 1, 7, 138338) He was asked, he said, by a sannyasi whether he believed that the Mohammedans would join with him after the Khilafat wrongs had been righted, and the Mohammedans had complained to him that he had destroyed the Aligarh College but saved the [Benares] Hindu University.
('22', 54, 1, 8, 138606) He disposed of the first with saying that if the Hindus helped the Mohammedans honestly, God, who sees a man’s heart, would banish ill feelings from the hearts of the latter.
('22', 54, 1, 9, 138781) He repudiated the second allegation that he had saved the [Benares] Hindu University.
('22', 54, 1, 10, 138867) If the Hindus were impotent, would the Mohammedans, he asked, like to be so?
('22', 54, 1, 11, 138944) He entertained a very high regard for Malaviyaji but all the same he wanted to see all the students out of his University so long as it had any connection with Government.
('22', 54, 1, 12, 139116) He would like all the existing institutions in the country to be converted into national ones.
('22', 54, 1, 13, 139211) He referred to a private talk 1 with Mr. Hassan Imam in which the latter asked him whether the non violent form of non co operation would remain non violent, and he had been holding out for a long time.
('22', 54, 1, 14, 139414) Further, Mr. Hassan Imam had complained to him that the students cried “Shame!” to him and behaved in a rude manner with him.
('22', 54, 1, 15, 139540) Mahatmaji exhorted the audience to have tolerance for the views of those who happened to differ from them and not to behave with them in that way as that would not advance their cause.
('22', 54, 1, 16, 139725) Mahatmaji then enumerated the various parts of the programme of non co operation and wanted them to give up the use of foreign goods which, he said, would alone bring swaraj.
('22', 54, 1, 17, 139900) He laid great emphasis on the introduction and use of charkhas and said they should have nothing to do with a Satanic Government which was bent upon trampling their rights and liberties.
('22', 54, 1, 18, 140087) He then appealed for funds and said that the obligation of the Mohammedans was double for they had to pay to the Swaraj Sabha (recently established at Bankipur) and for the relief of the sufferers in Smyrna.

('22', 54, 3, 20, 140322) 40. TO “VAISHNAVAS”
('22', 54, 4, 21, 140342) A true Vaishnava is he Who is moved by others’ sufferings; Who helps people in distress, And feels no pride for having done so.
('22', 54, 4, 22, 140470) Respectful to everyone in the world,
('22', 54, 5, 23, 140507) 1 At Patna
('22', 55, 0, 1, 140518) 56 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 55, 1, 2, 140559) He speaks ill of none; Is self controlled in action, speech and thought— Twice blessed the mother who bore such a one.
('22', 55, 1, 3, 140678) He has an equal seeing eye, and is free from all craving, Another’s wife is to him a mother; His tongue utters no untruth, And never his hand touches another’s wealth.
('22', 55, 1, 4, 140846) Moha 1 and maya 2 have no power over him, In his mind reigns abiding detachment; He dances with rapture to Rama’s name— No centre of pilgrimage but is present in his person.
('22', 55, 1, 5, 141020) A man he is without greed and cunning, And purged of anger and desire; Offering reverence to such a one, says Narasainyo 3, Will bring release to seventy one generations of one’s forbears.
('22', 55, 2, 6, 141209) From the marks of a Vaishnava described by Narasinh Mehta we see that he is a man who l.
('22', 55, 2, 7, 141298) is ever active in bringing relief to the distressed, 2. takes no pride in doing so, 3. is respectful to all, 4. speaks ill of none, 5. is self controlled in speech, 6. in action and 7. in thought, 8. holds all in equal regard, 9. has renounced desires, 10. is loyal to one woman, his wife, 11. is ever truthful, 12. keeps the rule of non stealing, 13. is beyond the reach of maya, 14. is, in consequence, free from all desire, 15. is ever absorbed in repeating Rama’s name, 16. and, as a result, has been sanctified,
('22', 55, 3, 8, 141815) 1 Primal ignorance and the attachment resulting from it 2 Cosmic illusion 3 Narasinh Mehta (1414 1479); saint poet of Gujarati admired by Gandhiji for disregarding the common prejudice against the so called untouchables 4 This poem, which formed part of the daily prayers at the Ashram, appealed to Gandhiji as a perfect expression of his own ideal of life and seems to have had a powerful impact on him.

('22', 62, 5, 7, 158957) Lord Ronaldshay 1 has been doing me the favour of reading my booklet on Indian Home Rule which is a translation of Hind Swaraj 2. His Lordship told his audience that if swaraj meant what I had described it to be in the booklet, the Bengalis would have none of it.
('22', 62, 5, 8, 159221) I am sorry that the swaraj of the Congress resolution does not mean the swaraj depicted in the booklet; swaraj according to the Congress means the swaraj that the people of India want, not what the British Government may condescend to give.
('22', 62, 5, 9, 159462) In so far as I can see, swaraj will be a parliament chosen by the people with the fullest power over the finance, the police, the military, the navy, the courts and the educational institutions.
('22', 62, 5, 10, 159657) I am free to confess that the swaraj I expect to gain within one year, if India responds, will be such swaraj as will make practically impossible the repetition of the Khilafat and the Punjab wrongs, and will enable the nation to do good or evil as it chooses, and not be ‘good’ at the dictation of an irresponsible, insolent, and godless bureaucracy.
('22', 62, 5, 11, 160009) Under that swaraj, the nation will have the power to impose a heavy protective tariff on such foreign goods as are capable of being manufactured in India, as also the power to refuse to send a single soldier outside India for the purpose of enslaving the surrounding or remote nationalities.
('22', 62, 5, 12, 160301) The swaraj that I dream of will be a possibility only when the nation is free to make its choice both of good and evil.

('22', 66, 1, 8, 169195) It was our greed and disregard of essential virtues which enslaved us.
('22', 66, 1, 9, 169266) I believe that caste has saved Hinduism from disintegration.

('22', 66, 1, 11, 169396) I consider the four divisions alone to be fundamental, natural, and essential.

('22', 74, 2, 18, 190082) 49. SPEECH AT MOTIHARI 3
('22', 74, 3, 19, 190107) December 9, 1920
('22', 74, 4, 20, 190124) Mahatmaji addressed the meeting sitting on a chair and exhorted the people to join the non co operation movement whole heartedly if they wanted to be freed from the present condition of slavery and inhuman indignities at the hands of the bureaucracy.
('22', 74, 4, 21, 190375) He explained to the people their clear duty to treat one another as brothers.
('22', 74, 4, 22, 190453) He also explained to the police their duty and reminded that they were meant to protect the people and not to molest them.
('22', 74, 4, 23, 190576) If they failed in it he dared say that they should take shelter elsewhere.
('22', 74, 4, 24, 190651) He referred to the recent looting in the village under the jurisdiction of Lawria thana 4 and expressed his regret at the action of the police there.
('22', 74, 4, 25, 190801) Maulana Shaukat Ali also exhorted the people to adopt non co operation with great force and spoke on the desirability of Hindu Muslim unity.
('22', 74, 4, 26, 190942) He thanked the Hindus for standing by the side of the Mussulmans in the Khilafat question and said that his first action would be to stop cattle slaughter altogether from this country.

('22', 75, 1, 2, 191321) 50. LETTER TO SARALADEVI CHOWDHARANI
('22', 75, 2, 3, 191358) ON WAY TO BHAGALPUR, December 11, 1920 I had two letters from you, one a scrap, the other a longish letter which shows that you do not understand my language or my thoughts.
('22', 75, 2, 4, 191532) I have certainly not betrayed any annoyance over your complex nature, but I have remarked upon it.
('22', 75, 2, 5, 191631) If a person is born with a deformation [sic] one may not quarrel with nature for it, but one may pardonably take note of it and try to remove it.
('22', 75, 2, 6, 191777) And that is what I have done.
('22', 75, 2, 7, 191807) I refuse to call an indefinable complexity a piece of art.
('22', 75, 2, 8, 191866) All art yields to patient analysis and shows a unity of design behind the diversity on the canvas.
('22', 75, 2, 9, 191965) You are hugging your defects even when they are pointed out by a friend in a friendly manner.
('22', 75, 2, 10, 192059) I do not feel vexed but it makes my task of helping difficult.
('22', 75, 2, 11, 192122) What art can there be in moods, in fits and starts?
('22', 75, 2, 12, 192174) The simplest natures are certainly complex in a sense.
('22', 75, 2, 13, 192229) But they are easily analysed.
('22', 75, 2, 14, 192259) But they are called simple because they are easily understandable and readily yield to treatment.
('22', 75, 2, 15, 192357) But I do not want to quarrel with you.
('22', 75, 2, 16, 192396) In you I have an enigma to solve.
('22', 75, 2, 17, 192430) I shall not be impatient.
('22', 75, 2, 18, 192456) Only bear with me whenever I try to point [out] what to me appear to be your obvious limitations.
('22', 75, 2, 19, 192554) We all have them.
('22', 75, 2, 20, 192572) It is the privilege of friendship to lay the gentle finger on the weak spots.
('22', 75, 2, 21, 192650) Friendship becomes a divine institution only when it educates friends.
('22', 75, 2, 22, 192721) Let us try to elevate each other.
('22', 75, 2, 23, 192755) I await with interest your letter on shuddhi 1.
('22', 75, 3, 24, 192803) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('22', 75, 3, 25, 192849) Courtesy: Narayan Desai

('22', 76, 1, 2, 193364) 52. SPEECH ON NON CO OPERATION, MONGHYR 1
('22', 76, 2, 3, 193406) December 11, 1920
('22', 76, 3, 4, 193424) MR. PRESIDENT AND GENTLEMEN, I am too weak to stand and deliver my address.
('22', 76, 3, 5, 193500) My friend, Mr. Sri Krishna Singh, has told you that last year when the coolies of Jamalpur were on strike he came over to see me at Ahmedabad and requested me to come to Jamalpur.
('22', 76, 3, 6, 193680) But I was engaged in some other important work and so failed to comply with his request.
('22', 76, 3, 7, 193769) I say frankly I like the occupation of a kisan more than I like the profession of a barrister.
('22', 76, 3, 8, 193864) To my heart a labourer has a higher place than a pleader.
('22', 76, 3, 9, 193922) Last year when I heard of the distress of the coolies of Jamalpur, I was sorely aggrieved, but on account of my preoccupation with some other work I pleaded my inability to come.
('22', 76, 3, 10, 194101) Today I am much pleased to meet you all, especially the coolies of Jamalpur.
('22', 76, 3, 11, 194178) Your gathering today is very large and I fear my voice will not reach each and every one of you.
('22', 76, 3, 12, 194275) So I shall be very brief in my say.
('22', 76, 3, 13, 194311) It is the duty of every Indian, whether he be Hindu or Mohammedan, Arab or Afghan, male or female, to think deeply over the present condition of India—to analyse minutely the situation.
('22', 76, 3, 14, 194497) It is also the duty of every one of you to devise ways and methods for the weeding out of the present day evils.
('22', 76, 3, 15, 194610) The Government has disappointed seven crores of our Muslim brethren.
('22', 76, 3, 16, 194679) It has broken its pledge to Turkey and has practically dismembered it.
('22', 76, 3, 17, 194750) 2 This Government has forced our brothers in the Punjab to crawl on their bellies and has offered sundry other unthinkable humiliations to them.
('22', 76, 3, 18, 194895) It has caused our students, even infants of six or seven years of age to walk sixteen miles a day in the noon day scorching sun four times to salute the Union Jack—in consequence of which some of the tender boys gave up their ghosts.
('22', 76, 4, 19, 195129) This Government has massacred 1,500 innocent men in the Punjab and now tells us to forget it.
('22', 76, 4, 20, 195223) It says that it has no hand in the destiny of the Khilafat.
('22', 76, 4, 21, 195283) I ask you never to bow down, never to salute this Government.
('22', 76, 4, 22, 195345) I ask you not to participate in the actions of the Government.
('22', 76, 4, 23, 195408) We can remove Satan only by forsaking its company.
('22', 76, 5, 24, 195459) 1 This was delivered at a meeting held under the presidentship of Shah Umar.
('22', 76, 5, 25, 195536) 2 Vide “Khilafat”, 12 5 1920 to “Speech on Non co operation,Bombay”, 12 5 1920 and Appendix “Turkish Peace Terms”.
('22', 76, 5, 26, 195651) 3 Vide “Congress report on the Punjab Disorders”, 25 3 1920.
('22', 77, 0, 1, 195712) 78 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 77, 1, 2, 195753) we admit that this Government has inculcated Satanic elements in us, then I say it is our duty to forsake it.
('22', 77, 1, 3, 195863) If this Government does not confess its blunders, if this Government does not give out to the world that the way in which the Punjab and the Khilafat affairs have been disposed of is wrong, if the Government does not repent of its misdeeds and beg pardon for them, we shall know no rest.
('22', 77, 1, 4, 196151) We can remove the Satanic Government by two means: one, by means of the sword, and the other, by means of non co operation.
('22', 77, 1, 5, 196275) The greybeards of the Hindus and Mussulmans have come to the decision that we cannot succeed if we unsheathe our swords.
('22', 77, 1, 6, 196396) If we once do so, instead of bringing the Government to its knees we ourselves shall be no more and all wrongs and atrocities that have been perpetrated will go unrevenged.
('22', 77, 1, 7, 196569) But if we adopt non violent non co operation, we are bound to succeed.
('22', 77, 1, 8, 196640) If you admit that we should bid adieu to Satan, then we should seek the help and favour of God, as has been enjoined on us by the Koran, the Gita and Tulsidas.
('22', 77, 1, 9, 196800) We should see that we do not grow angry with anyone, see that we do not abuse any Englishmen, nor like to cut their throats.

('22', 77, 1, 12, 197155) The only thing that we want is that if they do not accede to our requests we should non co operate with them.
('22', 77, 1, 13, 197265) Neither should we help them in any way nor should we receive help from them.
('22', 77, 1, 14, 197342) It will not harm anybody.
('22', 77, 1, 15, 197368) God will come to our help and realize the extent of our misery.
('22', 77, 1, 16, 197432) I have asked you all to non co operate, but I ask you all to cooperate with yourselves.

('22', 77, 1, 22, 198089) There are six items in the non co operation movement.

('22', 79, 1, 2, 200518) my pain at the comments on my talk with Maharajshri.
('22', 79, 2, 3, 200571) I saw in them, not an attempt to determine the meaning of dharma, but only duragraha and attacks on me.
('22', 79, 2, 4, 200675) May it not be said that I, too, am guilty of duragraha and attack others?
('22', 79, 2, 5, 200749) Certainly, it may.
('22', 79, 2, 6, 200768) It will be for the reader to judge whether this is true or not.
('22', 79, 2, 7, 200832) At the very beginning of our talk, Maharajshri told me that, in the interpretation of shastra, reason had no scope.
('22', 79, 2, 8, 200948) That itself pained me.
('22', 79, 2, 9, 200971) In my view, that which reason cannot understand and which the heart does not accept can be no shastra, and I think that anyone who wants to follow dharma in its purity cannot but admit this principle.
('22', 79, 2, 10, 201172) If we do not do this, we shall run the risk of violating our dharma.
('22', 79, 2, 11, 201241) I have heard the Gita being interpreted to the effect that, if any of our relations are wicked, we may use force to reduce them to submission; indeed, that it is our dharma to do so.
('22', 79, 2, 12, 201424) Because Rama killed Ravana, is it dharma to kill a person whom we regard as Ravana?
('22', 79, 2, 13, 201508) The Manusmriti 2
('22', 79, 3, 14, 201525) permits the eating of meat; is a Vaishnava free, therefore, to eat meat?
('22', 79, 3, 15, 201598) I have had it from the lips of shastris 3 and men claiming to be sannyasis that, when ill, one may take even beef.
('22', 79, 3, 16, 201713) Where would I have been if, accepting all these interpretations of the shastras, I had gone about destroying my relatives, had advised the killing of the British and eaten beef in my illness?
('22', 79, 3, 17, 201905) On such occasions, I was saved because I accepted only that as dharma which my reason and my heart accepted as such, and I advise everyone to do the same.
('22', 79, 3, 18, 202060) For this reason, holy men of tapashcharya have told us that those who study the Vedas but do not follow dharma in conduct are mere pedants; that they neither swim across themselves, nor help others to do so.
('22', 79, 3, 19, 202268) So it is that I am never impressed by those who have the Vedas on their lips or have got the commentaries by heart and, instead of marvelling at their learning, cherish my little knowledge as of greater value.
('22', 79, 3, 20, 202478) These being my views, I was pained when Maharajshri enunciated the principle for determining the meaning of shastra, but I was also pleased by his frankness.
('22', 79, 3, 21, 202636) Though he held, thus, that the shastras were against me, his decision finally was that it would not be justice to exclude Antyajas from schools which were open to Muslims, Parsis, Christians, Jews and others.
('22', 79, 3, 22, 202845) Vaisnnavas, who give money for

('22', 82, 3, 5, 208236) 55. SPEECH AT BHAGALPUR
('22', 82, 4, 6, 208260) December 12, 1920
('22', 82, 5, 7, 208278) Mahatma Gandhi, addressing the audience, said that Satan could not be defeated by Satanic arts.
('22', 82, 5, 8, 208374) It was God only that could overcome Satan and the Satanic Government must therefore be overcome by truth and right.
('22', 82, 5, 9, 208490) He then said that the people could not make progress by adopting the English mode of life.
('22', 82, 5, 10, 208581) The Hindu rishis did not have any chairs and taught under the trees.
('22', 82, 5, 11, 208650) The Mohammedan fakirs too, who were the real cause of Mohammedan progress, did not sit on chairs but lived in the jungles.
('22', 82, 6, 12, 208773) The Mahatma then said that it was not he that was the cause of the Indian awakening; it was the realization by the people that they were in bondage.
('22', 82, 6, 13, 208922) The Government was s ubduing the people, not by aeroplanes but through titles, the Councils, the courts and the schools.
('22', 82, 6, 14, 209043) If they wanted to be free they must adopt the methods adopted by the Boers, of which he had personal experience.
('22', 82, 6, 15, 209156) 2 The Boer women did not allow their boys to attend British schools and showed a courage which was wanting in the Indian people.
('22', 82, 6, 16, 209285) The people therefore should non co operate with the Government.
('22', 82, 7, 17, 209349) He said that in ancient India the women spun thread and cloths were woven from them.

('22', 95, 2, 7, 244277) (a) Is not the Non co operation Movement creating a sort of race hatred between Englishmen and Indians, and is it in accordance with the Divine plan of universal love and brotherhood?
('22', 95, 3, 8, 244461) (b) Does not the use of the words “devilish”, “Satanic”, etc., savour of unbrotherly sentiment and incite feelings of hatred?

('22', 95, 6, 27, 246113) But we may no more drop non violent non co operation because of its dangers than we may stop freedom because of the danger of its abuse.

('22', 96, 1, 2, 246319) 62. DYERISM IN CHAMPARAN?
('22', 96, 2, 3, 246345) India is a land full of tragedies.
('22', 96, 2, 4, 246380) Champaran probably contributes the largest number of them.
('22', 96, 2, 5, 246439) The Searchlight of Patna has just reported one such awful tragedy.
('22', 96, 2, 6, 246506) It is being investigated by a local Congress Committee of which Mr. Mazharul Haq is the chairman.
('22', 96, 2, 7, 246604) I do not propose to anticipate the verdict.
('22', 96, 2, 8, 246648) I understand that the matter is also engaging the Bihar Government’s attention.
('22', 96, 2, 9, 246728) But as I happened to be in Bettiah, together with Maulana Shaukat Ali in connection with our non co operation tour, I venture to give my own impressions gathered from a hurried visit to the spot.
('22', 96, 2, 10, 246924) The tragedy took place about fourteen miles from Bettiah, about the 30th November last.
('22', 96, 2, 11, 247012) I do not think that the Government, i.e., the high officials, had any part in its enactment.
('22', 96, 2, 12, 247105) Nor had the English planters.
('22', 96, 2, 13, 247135) This seems to have been peculiarly a police matter, in which the police have acted in an irresponsible manner and without the knowledge of the higher authorities.
('22', 96, 2, 14, 247298) Its origin lies in a petty dispute between villagers that resulted in a petty assault.
('22', 96, 2, 15, 247385) In connection with it a local man of influence was arrested by the police.
('22', 96, 2, 16, 247460) The villagers appear to have resented it and rescued the man, and even surrounded the constables who arrested him.
('22', 96, 2, 17, 247575) This proved too much for the wounded dignity of the police.
('22', 96, 2, 18, 247635) The local Daroga, i.e., Sub Inspector of Police, is said to have organized a loot in which, under the guidance and direction of the police, men from a neighbouring village also are said to have taken part.
('22', 96, 2, 19, 247841) Houses were denuded of their contents—grain and ornaments.
('22', 96, 2, 20, 247900) Women are reported to have been molested and robbed of their jewellery.
('22', 96, 2, 21, 247972) One woman told me that she was made naked and dust was thrown into her eyes.
('22', 96, 2, 22, 248049) Another was equally grossly maltreated while she was in the act of easing herself.
('22', 96, 2, 23, 248132) The villagers had fled in a cowardly manner.
('22', 96, 2, 24, 248177) Houses were shown to us in which the grain kothis 1 were found to be emptied and broken, grain scattered about, big boxes unlocked and opened—with the contents removed.
('22', 96, 2, 25, 248346) Needless to say that the rescued man was almost immediately rearrested and several other men, too, were arrested by the police.
('22', 96, 2, 26, 248474) Among them is a local brahmachari.
('22', 96, 2, 27, 248509) He is a man of considerable influence.
('22', 96, 2, 28, 248548) He has succeeded in organizing Panchayats settling localdisputes.
('22', 96, 2, 29, 248614) His activity bids fair to popularize the principle of arbitration among the villagers.
('22', 96, 2, 30, 248701) The police, naturally wanting to undermine his influence and suspecting him of having had a hand in inciting the people to defy their authority (so it appears from the

('22', 98, 1, 12, 252317) When a policeman comes not to arrest but to molest, he travels beyond his authority.
('22', 98, 1, 13, 252402) The citizen has then the inalienable right of treating him as a robber and dealing with him as such.
('22', 98, 1, 14, 252503) He will therefore use sufficient force to prevent him from robbing.
('22', 98, 1, 15, 252571) He will most decidedly use force in order to defend the honour of his womanhood.
('22', 98, 1, 16, 252652) The doctrine of non violence is not for the weak and the cowardly; it is meant for the brave and the strong.
('22', 98, 1, 17, 252761) The bravest man allows himself to be killed without killing.
('22', 98, 1, 18, 252822) And he desists from killing or injuring, because he knows that it is wrong to injure.
('22', 98, 1, 19, 252908) Not so the villagers of Champaran.
('22', 98, 1, 20, 252943) They flee from the police.

('22', 98, 1, 22, 253046) They gain no merit of non violence but on the contrary incur the reproach of cowardice and unmanliness, they stand condemned before Government and man.
('22', 98, 1, 23, 253198) But the workers among a people so fallen as in Champaran will have to be most careful about what they do.
('22', 98, 1, 24, 253304) They and the people will put themselves in the wrong if they resist the police in the lawful execution of their office, even though the execution may prove or appear to them to be unlawful.
('22', 98, 1, 25, 253494) The police must not be resisted if they arrest without a warrant.
('22', 98, 1, 26, 253560) They must not take the law into their own hands but scrupulously obey it.
('22', 98, 1, 27, 253634) The safeguard against any serious blunder lies in the fact that on no account are they to seek the protection of the law.
('22', 98, 1, 28, 253756) If, therefore, they are in the wrong, they will invariably suffer punishment.
('22', 98, 1, 29, 253834) And when they are in the right, they will most probably not suffer punishment, and they will always have the satisfaction of having saved, or attempted to save, the property, or, what is infinitely better, the honour of their women.

('22', 124, 1, 2, 317585) 73. THE SIN OF SECRECY
('22', 124, 2, 3, 317608) One of the curses of India is often the sin of secrecy.
('22', 124, 2, 4, 317664) For fear of an unknown consequence we talk in whispers.
('22', 124, 2, 5, 317720) Nowhere has this secrecy oppressed me more than in Bengal.
('22', 124, 2, 6, 317779) Everybody wishes to speak to you ‘in private’.
('22', 124, 2, 7, 317826) The spectacle of innocent young men looking around before opening their lips to see that no third party overhears their conversation has given me the greatest grief.
('22', 124, 2, 8, 317992) Every stranger is suspected of belonging to the Secret Service.
('22', 124, 2, 9, 318056) I have been warned to beware of strangers.
('22', 124, 2, 10, 318099) The cup of my misery was filled when I was told that the unknown student who presided at the students’ meeting belonged to the Secret Service department.
('22', 124, 2, 11, 318253) I could recall the names of at least two prominent leaders who are suspected in high Indian circles of being spies of the Government.
('22', 124, 2, 12, 318387) I feel thankful to God that for years past I have come to regard secrecy as a sin more especially in politics.
('22', 124, 2, 13, 318498) If we realized the presence of God as witness to all we say and do, we would not have anything to conceal from anybody on earth.
('22', 124, 2, 14, 318627) For, we would not think unclean thoughts before our Maker, much less speak them.
('22', 124, 2, 15, 318708) It is uncleanness that seeks secrecy and darkness.
('22', 124, 2, 16, 318759) The tendency of human nature is to hide dirt, we do not want to see or touch dirty things: we want to put them out of sight.
('22', 124, 2, 17, 318884) And so must it be with our speech.
('22', 124, 2, 18, 318919) I would suggest that we should avoid even thinking thoughts we would hide from the world.
('22', 124, 2, 19, 319009) This desire for secrecy has bred cowardice amongst us and has made us dissemble our speech.
('22', 124, 2, 20, 319101) The best and the quickest way of getting rid of this corroding and degrading Secret Service is for us to make a final effort to think everything aloud, have no privileged conversation with any soul on earth and to cease to fear the spy.
('22', 124, 2, 21, 319338) We must ignore his presence and treat everyone as a friend entitled to know all our thoughts and plans.
('22', 124, 2, 22, 319442) I know that I have achieved most satisfactory results from evolving the boldest of my plans in broad daylight.
('22', 124, 2, 23, 319553) I have never lost a minute’s peace for having detectives by my side.
('22', 124, 2, 24, 319622) The public may not know that I have been shadowed throughout my stay in India.
('22', 124, 2, 25, 319701) That has not only not worried me but I have even taken friendly services from these gentlemen: many have apologized for having to shadow me.
('22', 124, 2, 26, 319842) As a rule, what I have spoken in their presence has already been published to the world.
('22', 124, 2, 27, 319931) The result is that now I do not even notice the presence of these men and I do not know that the Government is much the wiser for having watched my movements through its secret agency.
('22', 124, 2, 28, 320116) My opinion is that these agents accompany me as a matter of form or routine.
('22', 124, 2, 29, 320193) They certainly never bother me.
('22', 124, 2, 30, 320225) I venture to make a present of my experience to every
('22', 125, 0, 1, 320279) 126 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 125, 1, 2, 320321) young man in Bengal and for that matter in India.

('22', 125, 1, 4, 320470) It is the simplest thing to see that the moment you cease to dread the presence of the spy and therefore refuse to treat him as such, that moment his presence ceases to offend you.
('22', 125, 1, 5, 320651) Soon the Government will feel ashamed to have its Secret Service department or, if it does not, the secret police will be sick of an occupation which serves no use.

('22', 126, 2, 6, 323370) 74. SPEECH AT WEAVERS’ CONFERENCE, NAGPUR
('22', 126, 3, 7, 323412) December 25, 1920 Though I am extremely busy with other work, I could not refuse the invitation to preside over this Conference.
('22', 126, 3, 8, 323541) True, I am not a weaver by profession, but I regard myself as a farmer weaver.
('22', 126, 3, 9, 323620) In the court also I have stated this as my profession.
('22', 126, 3, 10, 323675) I think that the regeneration of India will be difficult, if not impossible, without the uplift of its weavers.
('22', 126, 3, 11, 323787) And the subject, therefore, came up for discussion at the last Congress.
('22', 126, 3, 12, 323860) At the time that India passed into subjection, there was no other country in the world which produced cloth in the same quantity and of the same quality as it did.
('22', 126, 3, 13, 324024) All this cloth was being produced when there was not a single mill here.
('22', 126, 3, 14, 324097) From khadi to Dacca muslin, every variety of cloth was available then.
('22', 126, 3, 15, 324168) There was enough to meet the country’s requirements of cloth and leave a surplus which was exported.
('22', 126, 3, 16, 324269) Foreigners were drawn to this country as visitors.
('22', 126, 3, 17, 324320) The man who invented the sacred spinning wheel had shown a greater genius than Hargreaves (inventor of the spinning jenny), and greater than anyone else in the country ever did.
('22', 126, 3, 18, 324498) In the days of our prosperity, there was a spinning mill in every home.
('22', 126, 3, 19, 324570) Brahma saw that if India was to remain free her women should be persuaded to look upon it as their sacred duty to produce some yarn [every day] That is why it happened that he did not create a distinct community whose function would be to spin but made that obligatory on all women.
('22', 126, 3, 20, 324853) Our downfall began with the coming of the East India Company.
('22', 126, 3, 21, 324915) From that time, weavers and spinners started giving up their profession.
('22', 126, 3, 22, 324988) As in Champaran the people were obliged to part with their indigo crop, so [in those times] they were pressed to give yarn, so much so that in sheer desperation people cut off their fingers.
('22', 126, 3, 23, 325179) After this, started the imports from Lancashire.
('22', 126, 3, 24, 325228) If you wish to bring about regeneration of dharma, you should atone for the past and revive the old professions of spinning and weaving.
('22', 126, 3, 25, 325365) Because we have forsaken the path of dharma, we have been doing evil things in the name of swadeshi.
('22', 127, 0, 1, 325466) 128 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 127, 1, 2, 325508) therefore, ask people to produce more yarn and more cloth so that they may protect dharma.
('22', 127, 1, 3, 325599) If they do not do this, we shall certainly have to import cloth from outside.
('22', 127, 1, 4, 325677) Shri Fazalbhoy 1 and Shri Wadia 2

('22', 143, 4, 12, 366737) 81. SPEECH ON CREED RESOLUTION AT PLENARY SESSION OF CONGRESS
('22', 143, 5, 13, 366799) December 28, 1920
('22', 143, 6, 14, 366817) The Resolution means that the aim of the National Congress is to achieve swaraj, and that by just, pure and peaceful means.
('22', 143, 6, 15, 366941) The Congress believes that we should secure swaraj as early as possible, this very day if we can have it.
('22', 143, 6, 16, 367047) In this Resolution, the Congress also indicates what we should do to achieve swaraj.
('22', 143, 6, 17, 367132) It says that we do not want to secure it by the power of the sword.
('22', 143, 6, 18, 367200) We do not want it through falsehood or by sacrificing truth.
('22', 143, 6, 19, 367261) On the contrary, our means should be as pure as our aim.
('22', 143, 6, 20, 367318) The Resolution, therefore, means that we pledge ourselves to secure swaraj and to adopt just, truthful and peaceful methods for the purpose.
('22', 143, 6, 21, 367459) I consider it my good fortune that I have an opportunity of moving such an important resolution in this Congress.
('22', 143, 6, 22, 367573) Let me remind you that till now the aim of the Congress was to secure what they call “Responsible Colonial Government” within the Empire, such as what the other colonies enjoy, and to do this by means consonant with law.
('22', 143, 6, 23, 367794) Law here means the law of the British Empire.
('22', 143, 6, 24, 367840) We should respect the law of this Government, even though it refuses to offer a satisfactory solution of the Khilafat problem and, on the Punjab issue does not even admit its error, let alone doing justice.
('22', 143, 6, 25, 368047) We may not seek to end the Government, if we wish to remain in the Congress—this was what the [Congress] constitution meant till this day.
('22', 143, 6, 26, 368186) It is impossible for Hindus and Muslims to submit any longer to a Government which has perpetrated such naked injustice and refuses to repair it.
('22', 143, 6, 27, 368332) We, therefore, declare through this Resolution that we want swaraj.
('22', 143, 6, 28, 368400) It is only when we have swaraj that we shall have justice in the matter of the Punjab and
('22', 144, 0, 1, 368490) VOL. 22 : 23 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 145
('22', 144, 1, 2, 368536) the Khilafat wrongs.
('22', 144, 1, 3, 368557) But I do not want that we should adopt the methods of the West for securing swaraj.
('22', 144, 1, 4, 368641) I know that Hindus and Muslims have not renounced for all time the use of force for securing swaraj, but everyone realizes that today we cannot succeed in our aim by using force and hence it is that we have resorted to non co operation.
('22', 144, 1, 5, 368878) We cannot save anything, ourselves or our dharma or the Empire, by using force.
('22', 144, 1, 6, 368958) If you agree with me in this, let none of you oppose this Resolution.
('22', 144, 1, 7, 369028) I know that there are two parties among our thinking men, and to one of them belongs the Hon’ble Pandit Malaviyaji, who is like an elder brother to me.
('22', 144, 1, 8, 369180) He has got a cold today and is running a temperature and hence could not come here to express his views.
('22', 144, 1, 9, 369285) I shall, therefore, tell you what he thinks.
('22', 144, 1, 10, 369330) There are not many who serve their country as well as he does and you know this.
('22', 144, 1, 11, 369411) Even if we cannot agree with a man like him, we should listen to him patiently and respectfully.
('22', 144, 1, 12, 369508) He argues that we talk of bringing down the British Empire, but that it is beyond our power.
('22', 144, 1, 13, 369601) How can India, unarmed and weak, bring down such a mighty Empire?
('22', 144, 1, 14, 369667) He says that we should not mislead the people by talking to them about what is beyond their strength, that anyone who leads them to attempt such a thing is a fool.
('22', 144, 1, 15, 369831) If, as he says, it were really beyond the people’s strength to bring down this Empire, I would certainly accept his advice.
('22', 144, 1, 16, 369955) On this point, however, I differ from him.
('22', 144, 1, 17, 369998) I believe that every man or woman has in him or her the necessary strength for winning swaraj.
('22', 144, 1, 18, 370093) While we have the assurance in our heart that this body is inhabited by an atman, so long, I believe, we have it in us to win swaraj.
('22', 144, 1, 19, 370227) The 33 crores of Hindus and Muslims are staunch in their faith, have God ever on their lips and would welcome death in His name.
('22', 144, 1, 20, 370356) For one cow slaughtered, a thousand Hindus are ready to shed blood, others’ and their own.
('22', 144, 1, 21, 370447) For any Muslim humiliated, large numbers of others are ready to shed their blood, and to take others’.
('22', 144, 1, 22, 370550) While India has such Hindus and Muslims, I shall never say that it is impossible for the country to win swaraj and I shall never permit this goal of ours, winning swaraj, to be relegated to some distant future.
('22', 144, 1, 23, 370761) This Empire has been guilty of so many crimes that living under its flag is tantamount to being disloyal to God.
('22', 144, 1, 24, 370874) It is, therefore, my humble prayer to you all to give your approval to this Resolution.
('22', 144, 1, 25, 370962) Those among us who feel that we are much too weak, that with the strength we have we cannot win swaraj, even to them this goal should be acceptable since we wish to secure it peacefully and without sacrificing truth.

('22', 145, 1, 2, 371274) Those who feel that the Empire may yet come round, that an Empire of this character will sooner or later be persuaded to do justice, that we shall succeed, after entering the Councils, in bringing it to see reason, even such persons will have a place in the Congress in virtue of this Resolution.
('22', 145, 1, 3, 371571) We have no desire to punish the Empire.

('22', 145, 1, 20, 373342) There was a minor scuffle in the Bengali camp yesterday.
('22', 145, 1, 21, 373399) I was grieved to hear about it.
('22', 145, 1, 22, 373431) I went to the spot to explain to the people how we should behave if we wanted to win swaraj.

('22', 146, 1, 3, 373959) Both the parties saw the reason of this.
('22', 146, 1, 4, 374000) If we want swaraj, we should not appeal to the Government when a brother has injured us, has even broken our head.

('22', 146, 1, 6, 374160) If anyone assaults me with a stick, I would bow to him in return.

('22', 146, 1, 19, 375659) Death at the hands of one’s countrymen is to be welcomed.

('22', 147, 4, 14, 377640) 82. INTERVIEW TO “THE TIMES OF INDIA” 1
('22', 147, 5, 15, 377680) [Before December 29, 1920]
('22', 147, 6, 16, 377707) Asked by the representative as to his impressions formed as a result of his activities during the last three months, Mr. Gandhi said: My own impression of these three months’ extensive experience is that this movement of non co operation has come to stay, and it is most decidedly a purifying movement, in spite of isolated instances of rowdyism, as for instance at Mrs. Besant’s meeting in Bombay, at some places in Delhi, Bengal and even in Gujarat.
('22', 147, 6, 17, 378159) The people are assimilating day after day the spirit of non violence, not necessarily as a creed, but as an inevitable policy.
('22', 147, 6, 18, 378286) I expect most startling results, more startling than, say, from the discoveries of Sir J. C. Bose, from the acceptance by the people of non violence.
('22', 147, 6, 19, 378436) If the Government could be assured beyond any possibility of doubt that no violence would ever be offered by us, the Government would from that moment alter its character unconsciously and involuntarily, but none
('22', 147, 7, 20, 378649) 1 An account of this interview, given at Nagpur, was published in Young India, 29 12 1920, under the title “Swaraj in Nine Months”, and also in Amrita Bazar Patrika, 5 1 1921.
('22', 148, 0, 1, 378825) VOL. 22 : 23 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 149
('22', 148, 1, 2, 378871) the less surely, on that account.
('22', 148, 2, 3, 378905) [INTERVIEWER:] Alter its character—in what directions?
('22', 148, 2, 4, 378960) [GANDHIJI:] Certainly in the direction in which we ask it should move—that being in the direction of Government becoming responsive to every call of the nation.
('22', 148, 3, 5, 379121) Will you kindly explain further?
('22', 148, 3, 6, 379154) By that I mean, people will be able, by asserting themselves, through fixed determination and self sacrifice to gain the redress of the Khilafat wrong, the Punjab wrong, and attain the swaraj of their choice.
('22', 148, 4, 7, 379363) But what is your swaraj, and where does the Government come in there— the Government which you say will alter its character unconsciously?
('22', 148, 4, 8, 379502) My swaraj is the parliamentary government of India in the modern sense of the term for the time being, and that government would be secured to us either through the friendly offices of the British people or without them.
('22', 148, 5, 9, 379723) What do you mean by the phrase ‘without them’ ?
('22', 148, 5, 10, 379771) This movement is an endeavour to purge the present Government of the selfishness and greed which determine almost everyone of their activities.
('22', 148, 5, 11, 379915) Suppose that we have made it impossible by dissociation from them to feed their greed.
('22', 148, 5, 12, 380002) They might not wish to remain in India, as happened in the case of Somaliland, where, the moment its administration ceased to be a paying proposition they evacuated it.
('22', 148, 6, 13, 380171) How do you think, in practice, this will work out?
('22', 148, 6, 14, 380222) What I have sketched before you is the final possibility.
('22', 148, 6, 15, 380280) What I expect is that nothing of that kind will happen.
('22', 148, 6, 16, 380336) In so far as I understand the British people, I think that they will bow to the inevitable.
('22', 148, 6, 17, 380428) They will recognize the force of public opinion when it has become real and potent.
('22', 148, 6, 18, 380512) Then, and only then, will they realize the hideous injustice which in their name the Imperial Ministers and theirrepresentatives in India have perpetrated.
('22', 148, 6, 19, 380668) They will, therefore, remedy the two wrongs in accordance with the wishes of the people, and they will also offer a constitution exactly in accordance with the wishes of the people of India as represented by their chosen leaders.
('22', 148, 7, 20, 380898) Supposing that the British Government wishes to retire because India is not a paying concern, what do you think will then be the position of India?
('22', 148, 7, 21, 381046) At that stage, surely, it is easy to understand that India will then have evolved either an outstanding spiritual height or the ability to
('22', 149, 0, 1, 381185) 150 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 149, 1, 2, 381227) offer violence against violence.
('22', 149, 1, 3, 381260) She will have evolved an organizing ability of a high order, and will, therefore, be in every way able to cope with any emergency that might arise.
('22', 149, 2, 4, 381408) In other words you expect the moment of the British evacuation, if such a contingency arises, will coincide with the moment of India’s preparedness and ability and conditions favourable for India to take over the Indian administration as a going concern and work it for the benefit and advancement of the nation ?
('22', 149, 2, 5, 381722) My experience during the last months fills me with the hope that within the nine months that remain of the year in which I have expected swaraj for India we shall redress the two wrongs and we shall see swaraj established in accordance with the wishes of the people of India.
('22', 149, 3, 6, 381998) Where will the present Government be at the end of the nine months?
('22', 149, 3, 7, 382066) The lion will then lie with the lamb.

('22', 149, 6, 10, 382175) A GOSPEL OF HATE ?
('22', 149, 7, 11, 382194) The Indian Interpreter has much to say against non co operation.
('22', 149, 7, 12, 382259) I do wish editors will try to understand public questions before dealing with them.
('22', 149, 7, 13, 382343) The Indian Interpreter is a Christian journal and one has a right to expect a fair knowledge of subjects handled in a responsible journal devoted to religious matters.
('22', 149, 7, 14, 382511) “India will never,” says the Interpreter, “attain unity by means of a common hate.
('22', 149, 7, 15, 382594) That appears, as far as an onlooker can judge, tobe the means to which Mr. Gandhi, the idealist, has surrendered himself.” Mr. Stokes 1, who has endeavoured to study the movement as an onlooker, says that it is not based on hate.
('22', 149, 7, 16, 382824) I have said so myself.
('22', 149, 7, 17, 382847) But prejudices die hard.
('22', 149, 7, 18, 382872) And in these days of mad rush to which modern journalism is making the largest contribution, people feed their prejudices, unconsciously it may be, by coming to hasty conclusions on insufficient data.
('22', 149, 7, 19, 383073) A COMMON DANGER It is a common danger, a common affliction, that is binding Hindus and Mussulmans.
('22', 149, 7, 20, 383172) I know no purifier so great as affliction.
('22', 149, 7, 21, 383215) “Adversity makes strange bedfellows”: with us it has knit together
('22', 149, 8, 22, 383282) 1 Who had adopted India as his home and was interested in non co operation; vide the following item.

('22', 150, 2, 3, 383482) BRITISH RULE AN EVIL ?
('22', 150, 3, 4, 383505) The Interpreter is however more to the point in asking:
('22', 150, 4, 5, 383561) Does Mr. Gandhi hold without hesitation or reserve that British rule in India is altogether evil and that the people of India are to be taught so to regard it?
('22', 150, 4, 6, 383721) He must hold it to be so evil that the wrongs it does outweigh the benefits it confers, for only so is non co operation to be justified at the bar of conscience or of Christ.
('22', 150, 4, 7, 383896) My answer is emphatically in the affirmative.
('22', 150, 4, 8, 383942) So long as I believed that the sum total of the energy of the British Empire was good, I clung to it despite what I used to regard as temporary aberrations.
('22', 150, 4, 9, 384099) I am not sorry for having done so.
('22', 150, 4, 10, 384134) But having my eyes opened, it would be sin for me to associate myself with the Empire unless it purges itself of its evil character.
('22', 150, 4, 11, 384267) I write this with sorrow and I should be pleased if I discovered that I was in error and that my present attitude was a reaction.
('22', 150, 4, 12, 384397) The continuous financial drain, the emasculation of the Punjab and the betrayal of the Muslim sentiment constitute, in my humble opinion, a threefold robbery of India.
('22', 150, 4, 13, 384565) The blessings of pax Britannica I reckon, therefore, to be a curse.
('22', 150, 4, 14, 384633) We would have at least remained like the other nations, brave men and women, instead of feeling as we do so utterly helpless, if we had no British Rule imposing on us an armed peace.
('22', 150, 4, 15, 384816) ‘The blessing’ of roads and railways is a return no self respecting nation would accept for its degradation.
('22', 150, 4, 16, 384925) ‘The blessing’ of education is proving one of the greatest obstacles in our progress towards freedom.
('22', 150, 5, 17, 385027) A MOVEMENT OF PURIFICATION
('22', 150, 6, 18, 385054) The fact is that non co operation by reason of its non violence has become a religious and purifying movement.
('22', 150, 6, 19, 385165) It is daily bringing strength to the nation, showing it its weak spots and the remedy for removing them.
('22', 150, 6, 20, 385270) It is a movement of self reliance.
('22', 150, 6, 21, 385305) It is the mightiest force for revolutionizing opinion and stimulating thought.
('22', 150, 6, 22, 385384) It is a movement of self imposed suffering and therefore possesses autom atic checks against extravagance or impatience.
('22', 150, 6, 23, 385505) The capacity of the nation for suffering regulates its advance towards freedom.
('22', 150, 6, 24, 385585) It isolates the forces of evil by refraining from participation in it, in any shape or form.

('22', 152, 1, 2, 388388) has contributed three articles on non co operation to the columns of the Servant of Calcutta and other papers.
('22', 152, 1, 3, 388499) I had the pleasure of reading them during my Bengal tour.
('22', 152, 1, 4, 388557) Mr. Stokes approves of non co operation but dreads the consequences that may follow complete success, i.e., evacuation of India by the British.
('22', 152, 1, 5, 388701) He conjures up before his mind a picture of India invaded by the Afghans from the North West, plundered by the Gurkhas from the hills.
('22', 152, 1, 6, 388836) For me, I say with Cardinal Newman: “I do not ask to see the distant scene; one step enough for me.” The movement is essentially religious.
('22', 152, 1, 7, 388976) The business of every godfearing man is to dissociate himself from evil in total disregard of consequences.
('22', 152, 1, 8, 389084) He must have faith in a good deed producing only a good result: that in my opinion is the Gita doctrine of work without attachment.
('22', 152, 1, 9, 389216) God does not permit him to peep into the future.
('22', 152, 1, 10, 389265) He follows truth although the following of it may endanger his very life.
('22', 152, 1, 11, 389339) He knows that it is better to die in the way of God than to live in the way of Satan.
('22', 152, 1, 12, 389425) Therefore, whoever is satisfied that this Government represents the activity of Satan has no choice left to him but to dissociate himself from it.
('22', 152, 1, 13, 389572) However, let us consider the worst that can happen to India on a sudden evacuation of India by the British.
('22', 152, 1, 14, 389680) What does it matter that the Gurkhas and the Pathans attack us?
('22', 152, 1, 15, 389744) Surely we would be better able to deal with their violence than we are with the continued violence, moral and physical, perpetrated by the present Government.
('22', 152, 1, 16, 389903) Mr. Stokes does not seem to eschew the use of physical force.
('22', 152, 1, 17, 389965) Surely the combined labour of the Rajput, the Sikh and the Mussulman warriors in a united India may be trusted to deal with plunderers from any or all the sides.
('22', 152, 1, 18, 390127) Imagine however the worst: Japan overwhelming us from the Bay of Bengal, the Gurkhas from the hills, and the Pathans from the North West.
('22', 152, 1, 19, 390265) If we do not succeed in driving them out we make terms with them and drive them out at the first opportunity.
('22', 152, 1, 20, 390375) This will be a more manly course than a helpless submission to an admittedly wrongful State.
('22', 152, 1, 21, 390468) But I refuse to contemplate the dismal outlook.
('22', 152, 1, 22, 390516) If the movement succeeds through non violent non co operation, and that is the supposition Mr. Stockes has started with, the English, whether they remain or retire, will do so as friends and under a wellordered agreement as between partners.
('22', 152, 1, 23, 390758) I still believe in the goodness of human nature, whether it is English or any other.
('22', 152, 1, 24, 390843) I therefore do not believe that the English will leave in “a night”.

('22', 153, 1, 2, 391007) incorrigible thieves and robbers without the ability to respond to purifying influences ?

('22', 153, 1, 4, 391107) If India returns to her spirituality, it will react upon the neighbouring tribes; she will interest herself in the welfare of these hardy but poor people, and even support them if necessary, not out of fear but as a matter of neighbourly duty.
('22', 153, 1, 5, 391351) She will have dealt with Japan simultaneously with the British.
