('22', 153, 3, 14, 392375) 85. CASTE “VERSUS” CLASS
('22', 153, 4, 15, 392400) Man being a social being has to devise some method of social organization.
('22', 153, 4, 16, 392475) We in India have evolved caste: They in Europe have organized class.
('22', 153, 4, 17, 392544) Neither has the solidarity and naturalness of a family which perhaps is a God ordained institution.
('22', 153, 4, 18, 392644) If caste has produced certain evils, class has not been productive of anything less.
('22', 153, 4, 19, 392729) If class helps to conserve certain social virtues, caste does the same in equal, if not greater, degree.
('22', 153, 4, 20, 392834) The beauty of the caste system is that it does not base itself upon distinctions of wealth possessions.
('22', 153, 4, 21, 392938) Money, as history has proved, is the greatest disruptive force in the world.
('22', 153, 4, 22, 393015) Even the sacredness of family ties is not safe against the pollution of wealth, says Shankaracharya.
('22', 153, 4, 23, 393116) Caste is but an extension of the principle of the family.
('22', 153, 4, 24, 393174) Both are governed by blood and heredity.
('22', 153, 4, 25, 393215) Western scientists are busy trying to prove that heredity is an illusion and that milieu is everything.
('22', 153, 4, 26, 393319) The sole experience of many lands goes
('22', 154, 0, 1, 393358) VOL. 22 : 23 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 155
('22', 154, 1, 2, 393404) against the conclusion of these scientists; but even accepting their doctrine of milieu, it is easy to prove that milieu can be conserved and developed more through caste than through class.
('22', 154, 1, 3, 393595) The Anglo Saxon is temperamentally incapable of appreciating any outlook but his own.
('22', 154, 1, 4, 393681) One can understand his violent opposition to everything that goes against his grain.
('22', 154, 1, 5, 393766) But Indians, whether Hindus or Christians, ought to be able to see that the spirit behind caste is not one of arrogant superiority; it is the classification of different systems of self culture.
('22', 154, 1, 6, 393961) It is the best possible adjustment of social stability and progress.
('22', 154, 1, 7, 394030) Just as the spirit of the family is inclusive of those who love each other and are wedded to each other by ties of blood and relation, caste also tries to include families of a particular way of purity of life (not standard of life, meaning by this term, economic standard of life).
('22', 154, 1, 8, 394313) Only, it does not leave the decision, whether a particular family belongs to a particular type, to the idiosyncracies or interested judgment of a few individuals.
('22', 154, 1, 9, 394476) It trusts to the principle of heredity, and being only a system of culture does not hold that any injustice is done if an individual or a family has to remain in a particular group in spite of their decision to change their mode of life for the better.
('22', 154, 1, 10, 394729) As we all know, change comes very slowly in social life, and thus, as a matter of fact, caste has allowed new groupings to suit the changes in lives.
('22', 154, 1, 11, 394879) But these changes are quiet and easy as a change in the shape of the clouds.
('22', 154, 1, 12, 394956) It is difficult to imagine a better harmonious human adjustment.
('22', 154, 1, 13, 395021) Caste does not connote superiority or inferiority.
('22', 154, 1, 14, 395072) It simply recognizes different outlooks and corresponding modes of life.
('22', 154, 1, 15, 395145) But it is no use denying the fact that a sort of hierarchy has been evolved in the caste system, but it cannot be called the creation of the Brahmins.
('22', 154, 1, 16, 395296) When all castes accept a common goal of life a hierarchy is inevitable, because all castes cannot realize the ideal in equal degree.
('22', 154, 1, 17, 395429) If all the castes believe that vegetarian diet is superior to animal diet, the vegetarian caste will naturally be looked up to.
('22', 154, 1, 18, 395557) There are certain sub castes in India that have ever stood on a par with each other, and yet have not interdined or intermarried.
('22', 154, 1, 19, 395687) Just as a Hindu or a Mohammedan does not think himself an inferior of the other because of his differences of faith, or just as a Brahmin or a Lingayat in Southern India mutually refuse to interdrink, all castes can confine their food and drink to their own caste.
('22', 154, 1, 20, 395952) Only by accepting the standard of the Brahmin or the Vaishnavas as the best, have the other castes consented to dine at the hands of the ‘purer’ castes.
('22', 155, 0, 1, 396105) 156 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 155, 1, 2, 396147) Touch, drink, food and marriage are progressively private affairs.
('22', 155, 1, 3, 396214) But by refusing to touch a man, you practically refuse all intercourse with him.
('22', 155, 1, 4, 396295) He is thus denied all the fruits of social development.
('22', 155, 1, 5, 396351) The touchables, for instance, can all attend the kathas, the kirtans (religious sermons).
('22', 155, 1, 6, 396441) They can visit temples and thus get the free education of religion, rituals and arts.
('22', 155, 1, 7, 396527) In the temple, all the touchables exchange their love and service and the fruits of civilization.
('22', 155, 1, 8, 396625) The ‘untouchables’ are automatically barred from all that.
('22', 155, 1, 9, 396684) In many places, being required to live outside the village, they are deprived of even the protection of their life and property.
('22', 155, 1, 10, 396813) In the social division of labour they do one of the most important duties to society, and they are deprived of the fruits of the great social life which is evolved by the family of castes.
('22', 155, 1, 11, 397002) Untouchability has made the ‘depressed’ classes the Cinderella of Hindu society.
('22', 155, 1, 12, 397083) The question of food and drink has or ought to have no social value.
('22', 155, 1, 13, 397152) It is merely the satisfaction of physical wants.
('22', 155, 1, 14, 397201) It is, on the other hand, an opportunity for the control of the senses.
('22', 155, 1, 15, 397273) Interdining has never been known to promote brotherhood in any special sense.
('22', 155, 1, 16, 397351) But the restraints about interdining have to a great extent helped the cultivation of will power and the conservation of certain social virtues.

('22', 157, 1, 9, 401342) The supremacy of brute force, worshipping money as God, spending most of one’s time in seeking worldly happiness, breath taking risks in pursuit of worldly enjoyments of all kinds, the expenditure of limitless mental energy on efforts to multiply the power of machinery, the expenditure of crores on the invention of means of destruction, the moral righteousness which looks down upon people outside Europe,—this civilization, in my view, deserves to be altogether rejected.

('22', 158, 1, 12, 404255) At a time when everyone was afraid of telling the truth, Jesus risked his life, described hypocrisy, pride and Iying in plain terms for what they were and so put innocent and simple folk on their guard, and saved them.
('22', 158, 1, 13, 404474) When the Buddha, with the lamb on his shoulder, went up to the cruel Brahmins who were engaged in an animal sacrifice, it was in no soft language that he spoke to them; he was, however, all love at heart.

('22', 159, 3, 13, 406889) We attribute perfection to a guru.

('22', 159, 3, 15, 407000) That is why I have deliberately said that I welcome people being followers of my ideas but I want no one to be my follower.
('22', 159, 3, 16, 407124) Following ideas requires understanding; in following a person, faith is the chief thing.
('22', 159, 3, 17, 407213) I do not want to be an object of the devotion which such faith expresses, but I certainly want people to follow my ideas with devotion.
('22', 159, 3, 18, 407349) They can do this, of course, only if they understand them.
('22', 159, 3, 19, 407408) I know, however, that at present many persons follow my ideas simply out of blind regard for me.

('22', 159, 3, 21, 407594) Between a person’s being my follower and his being a follower of my ideas there is the same difference which there is, according to Gladstone, between calling a man a fool and describing his ideas as foolish.
('22', 159, 3, 22, 407803) This is not all.
('22', 159, 3, 23, 407820) Shri Narasinhrao sees in me another weakness which “gurus” are especially prone to.

('22', 161, 2, 3, 410755) December 29, 1920 The paper costs much more than it is worth.
('22', 161, 2, 4, 410817) Its influence on English opinion is practically nothing and it is an indifferent vehicle of English opinion for India’s enlightenment.
('22', 161, 2, 5, 410952) Now that we have embarked on non co operation and are determined to become self reliant it would be consistent for us to disestablish the British Committee and stop India.
('22', 161, 2, 6, 411124) I would far concentrate all our attention and all our best workers on India.
('22', 161, 2, 7, 411201) The harvest is rich and the labourers are few.
('22', 161, 2, 8, 411248) We can ill spare a single worker for foreign work.
('22', 161, 2, 9, 411299) We shall hurt our cause, rather than help our cause.
('22', 161, 2, 10, 411352) If we are doing anything here, no propaganda will be necessary.

('22', 161, 2, 12, 411459) They understand only business, they understand only work.

('22', 161, 2, 15, 411774) We are too few for the work and we must husband our resources.

('22', 162, 1, 7, 414940) In order to continue the education of the youth of the country in a free and untainted atmosphere this Congress advises the owners, trustees and educationists in charge of aided or affiliated institutions to give up grants and affiliation and render them independent of all Government control and influence and advises the monied men and educationists of the country to establish national universities, new schools and colleges so as to render it possible for every child to receive suitable education in accordance with the needs of the nation.

('22', 167, 2, 3, 425564) NAGPUR, December 31, 1920 I have been just saying, with the permission of the President, a few things in connection with that portion of the Non co operation Resolution which you have all accepted with acclamation.
('22', 167, 2, 4, 425779) I refer to the All India Tilak Memorial Swaraj Fund.
('22', 167, 2, 5, 425832) I hope that all the delegates will do their utmost in order to contribute to this Fund.

('22', 167, 2, 7, 425967) They will be treasuring and perpetuating the memory of one who has commanded the universal reverence of India and who has laid down his life in the service of his country.
('22', 167, 2, 8, 426139) I have not the slightest doubt that this great memorial which you have decided to erect in memory of the illustrious deceased will be a magnificent success; but if it is to be a magnificent success it cannot be so except by the joint and united effort of every one of us, brothers and sisters.
('22', 167, 2, 9, 426433) Those of you who want even to make payments here, that is, after withdrawing from the pandal, can do so, but I hope that when you have gone to your homes you will not forget this thing but will consider it a sacred duty to contribute as much as you can, and continue to do so, to this sacred memorial in the hope and full belief that we shall be able to get swaraj within one year.
('22', 167, 2, 10, 426815) If we cannot contribute whatever we can to this purpose, I hardly think that we can be considered worth getting swaraj.
('22', 167, 2, 11, 426935) But your mantra 2 was that you should get swaraj, and if you see the letters over the picture 3, “Swaraj is my birthright”, and if you want to make that hope of his good within one year, you will all make the utmost attempt in order to make this memorial a success.

('22', 168, 4, 8, 428796) [December 1920] 2
('22', 168, 5, 9, 428814) I hope every Gujarati will read and ponder over this translation.
('22', 168, 5, 10, 428880) I think the translation is excellent, but it is not for its simple Gujarati that I commend it.
('22', 168, 5, 11, 428975) If we realize well enough what happened in the Punjab, 3 we shall readily understand our duty in the present circumstances.
('22', 168, 6, 12, 429099) MOHANDAS KARAMCHAND GANDHI [From Gujarati]

('22', 169, 1, 2, 429850) 92. CONGRESS CONSTITUTION ADOPTED AT NAGPUR SESSION 1
('22', 169, 2, 3, 429904) [December 1920]
('22', 169, 3, 4, 429920) Article 1 The object of the Indian National Congress is the attainment of Swarajya by the people of India by all legitimate and peaceful means.
('22', 169, 3, 5, 430064) (Note: This was passed as Resolution No.
('22', 169, 4, 6, 430105) SESSIONS OF THE CONGRESS
('22', 169, 5, 7, 430130) Article II (a) The Indian National Congress shall ordinarily meet once every year during Christmas holidays at such place as may have been decided upon at its previous session or such other place as may have been determined by the All India Congress Committee hereinafter referred to.
('22', 169, 5, 8, 430415) (b) An extraordinary session of the Congress may be summoned by the All India Congress Committee either of its own motion or on the requisition of a majority of the Provincial Congress Committees, wherever it may deem it advisable to hold such a session; and the Articles of this Constitution shall apply with such modifications as the All India Congress Committee may consider necessary in respect of each such session.
('22', 169, 6, 9, 430836) COMPONENT PARTS OF THE CONGRESS
('22', 169, 7, 10, 430868) Article III The Indian National Congress organization shall consist of the following: (a) The Indian National Congress.
('22', 169, 7, 11, 430988) (b) Provincial Congress Committees.
('22', 169, 7, 12, 431024) (c) District Congress Committees.
('22', 169, 7, 13, 431058) (d) Sub Divisional, Taluqa or Tahsil, Firka or other Local Congress Committees.
('22', 169, 7, 14, 431138) (e) The All India Congress Committee.
('22', 169, 7, 15, 431176) (f) Such other Committees outside India as may from time to
('22', 169, 8, 16, 431236) 1 This new constitution was framed by Gandhiji in consultation through correspondence with other members of the Constitution Committee; vide “Letter to N.C. Kelkar”, 2 7 1920 , “Letter to Chairman, A.I.C.C.”, 25 9 1920 & “The Congress Constitution”, 3 11 1920.
('22', 170, 0, 1, 431497) VOL. 22 : 23 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 171
('22', 170, 1, 2, 431543) time be recognized by the Congress in this behalf.
('22', 170, 1, 3, 431594) (g) Bodies formed or organized periodically by the Provincial, District, Taluqa or Tahsil, or other Local Congress Committees such as the Reception Committee of the Congress and the Provincial, District, Taluqa or Tahsil, or other local Conferences.
('22', 170, 2, 4, 431844) Article IV No person shall be eligible to be a member of any of the organizations referred to in the foregoing Article, unless he or she has attained the age of 21 and expresses in writing his or her acceptance of the object and the methods as laid down in Article I of this Constitution and of the Rules of the Congress.
('22', 170, 3, 5, 432166) PROVINCIAL CONGRESS COMMITTEE
('22', 170, 4, 6, 432196) Article V The following shall be the Provinces with headquarters mentioned against them and where no headquarters are mentioned and in every case the respective Provincial Congress Committees shall have the power to fix or alter them from time to time.

Burma Burmese ” Rangoon Provided that the All India Congress Committee may from time to time assign particular Indian States to particular Provinces and a Provincial Congress Committee may in its turn allot particular Indian States assigned to it by the All India Congress Committee to particular Districts within its jurisdiction The existing Provincial Congress Committees shall forthwith proceed to reorganize themselves in terms of this Constitution and such reorganization shall be final unless and until it is revised by the All India Congress Committee.
('22', 171, 2, 3, 433738) Article VI (a) There shall be a Provincial Congress Committee in and for each of the Provinces named in the foregoing Article.
('22', 171, 2, 4, 433865) (b) Each Provincial Congress Committee shall organize District and other Committees referred to in Article III and shall have the power to frame rules laying down conditions of membership and for the conduct of business not inconsistent with this Constitution or any rules made by the All India Congress Committee.
('22', 171, 2, 5, 434180) (c) Each Provincial Congress Committee shall consist of representatives elected annually by the members of the District and other Committees in accordance with the rules made by the Provincial Congress Committees.
('22', 171, 3, 6, 434394) FRANCHISE
('22', 171, 4, 7, 434404) Article VII Every person not disqualified under Article IV and paying a subscription of 4 annas per year shall be entitled to become a member of any organization controlled by the Provincial Congress Com mittees.
('22', 171, 4, 8, 434617) ELECTORATES AND DELEGATES
('22', 171, 5, 9, 434643) Article VIII Each Provincial Congress Committee shall be responsible for the election of delegates to the Congress.
('22', 172, 0, 1, 434759) VOL. 22 : 23 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 173
('22', 172, 1, 2, 434805) No one shall be qualified for election who is not of the age of 21 years and who does not subscribe to the Congress creed.
('22', 172, 1, 3, 434928) The number of delegates shall be not more than one for every 50 thousand or its fraction of the inhabitants of the Province of its jurisdiction, including the Indian States therein, in accordance with the last census: provided however, that the inclusion of Indian States in the electorate shall not be taken to include any interference by the Congress with the internal affairs of such States.
('22', 172, 1, 4, 435323) Each Provincial Congress Committee shall frame rules for the election of delegates, due regard being had to the return of women delegates and representation of minorities, special interrests or classes needing special protection.
('22', 172, 1, 5, 435553) The rules shall provide for the organization of electorates and shall prescribe the procedure to be adopted for securing the proportional representation (by a single transferable vote) of every variety of political opinion.
('22', 172, 1, 6, 435777) The rules framed by each Provincial Congress Committee shall be sent to the General Secretaries of the Congress not later than the 30th April 1921, which rules shall be published for general information by the Secretaries as soon as possible after the receipt thereof.
('22', 172, 1, 7, 436046) Each Provincial Congress Committee shall send to the Reception Committee of the ensuing Session of the Congress an alphabetical list of the delegates so elected containing the full name, occupation, age, sex, religion and address of each of them to reach the Committee not later than the 15th day of December every year, and in the case of an Extraordinary Session not later than ten days before the date advertised for the holding of such Session.
('22', 172, 2, 8, 436495) Article IX (a) Each Provincial Congress Committee shall pay annually such subscription to the All India Congress Committee as may be fixed by the latter from time to time.
('22', 172, 2, 9, 436667) (b) No member of a Congress Committee shall vote at the election of representatives or delegates or be elected as such unless and until he has paid the subscription due by him.
('22', 172, 3, 10, 436844) DELEGATES
('22', 172, 4, 11, 436854) Article X Each Committee referred to in Article VIII shall issue certificates to the delegates duly elected in accordance with the form
('22', 173, 0, 1, 436990) 174 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 173, 1, 2, 437032) hereto attached marked Appendix A and signed by a Secretary of the Committee.
('22', 173, 2, 3, 437110) Article XI Every delegate on presenting such a certificate and paying a fee of Rs. 10 at the Congress office shall receive ticket entitling him to admission to the Congress.
('22', 173, 3, 4, 437284) Article XII Delegates shall alone have the power of voting at the Congress sittings or otherwise taking part in its deliberations.
('22', 173, 4, 5, 437415) RECEPTION COMMITTEE
('22', 173, 5, 6, 437435) Article XIII The Reception Committee shall be formed by the Provincial Congress Committee at least six months before the meeting of the annual session and may include persons who are not members of the Provincial Congress Committee.
('22', 173, 5, 7, 437668) The members of the Reception Committee shall pay not less than Rs. 25 each.
('22', 173, 6, 8, 437744) Article XIV The Reception Committee shall elect its Chairman and other office bearers from amongst its own members.
('22', 173, 7, 9, 437860) Article XV It shall be the duty of the Reception Committee to collect funds for the expenses of the Congress Session, to elect the President of the Congress in the manner set forth in the following article and to make all necessary arrangements for the reception and accommodation of delegates and guests and, as far as practicable, of visitors and for the printing and publication of the report of the proceedings and to submit statements of receipts and expenditure to the Provincial Congress Committee within 4 months of the Session of the Congress.
('22', 173, 8, 10, 438413) ELECTION OF THE PRESIDENT
('22', 173, 9, 11, 438439) Article XVI The several Provincial Congress Committees shall, as far as possible by the end of June, suggest to the Reception Committee the names of persons who are in their opinion eligible for the Presidentship of the Congress and the Reception Committee shall, as far as possible in the first week of July, submit to all the Provincial Committees the names as suggested for their final recommendations provided that such final recommendation will be of any one but not
('22', 174, 0, 1, 438911) VOL. 22 : 23 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 175
('22', 174, 1, 2, 438957) more of such names and the Reception Committee shall, as far as possible, meet in the month of August to consider such recomme ndations.
('22', 174, 1, 3, 439094) If the person recommended by a majority of the Provincial Congress Committees is adopted by a majority of the members of the Reception Committee present at a special meeting called for the purpose, that person shall be the President of the next Congress.
('22', 174, 1, 4, 439349) If, however, the Reception Committee is unable to accept the President recommended by the Provincial Congress Committees or in case of emergency by resignation, death or otherwise of the President elected in this manner, the matter shall forthwith be referred by it to the All India Congress Committee whose decision shall be arrived at, as far as possible, before the end of September.
('22', 174, 1, 5, 439736) In either case the election shall be final, provided that in no case shall the person so elected as President belong to the Province in which the Congress is to be held.
('22', 174, 1, 6, 439906) The President of a special or extraordinary session shall be elected by the All India Congress Committee subject to the same proviso.
('22', 174, 2, 7, 440040) CONGRESS FUNDS
('22', 174, 3, 8, 440055) Article XVII (a) The Reception Committee shall, through the Provincial Congress Committee of the Province, remit to the All India Congress Committee, not later than two weeks after the termination of the Congress Session, ordinary or extraordinary, half the delegation fees.
('22', 174, 3, 9, 440330) (b) If the Reception Committee has a balance after defraying all the expenses of the session it shall hand over the same to the Provincial Congress Committee in the Province in which the session was held towards the Provincial Congress fund of that Province.
('22', 174, 5, 10, 440589) Article XVIII The receipts and expenditure of the Reception Committee shall be audited by an auditor or auditors appointed by the Provincial Congress Committee concerned and the statement of accounts together with the auditor’s report shall be sent by the Provincial Congress Committee, not later than six months from the termination of the Congress, to the All India Congress Committee.
('22', 174, 6, 11, 440977) ALL INDIA CONGRESS COMMITTEE
('22', 174, 7, 12, 441006) Article XIX The All India Congress Committee shall consist of 350 members exclusive of ex officio members.
('22', 175, 0, 1, 441113) 176 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 175, 1, 2, 441155) The ex officio members shall be past Presidents of the Congress and General Secretaries and Treasurers of the Congress.
('22', 175, 1, 3, 441275) Each Provincial Congress Committee shall elect the allotted number of members of the All India Congress Committee from among the members of the Congress Committees within its jurisdiction.
('22', 175, 1, 4, 441464) The allotment shall be on the basis of population according to the linguistic redistribution of Provinces or in such other manner as may appear more equitable to the All India Congress Committee and shall be published by the All India Congress Committee before the 31st day, January 1921. The method of election shall be the same as already prescribed for the election of delegates.
('22', 175, 1, 5, 441847) Election to the All India Congress Committee shall ordinarily take place in the month of November.
('22', 175, 1, 6, 441946) The first All India Congress Committee under this Constitution shall be elected on or before the 30th of June, 1921. Till then, the members of the All India Congress Committee recently elected shall continue in office.
('22', 175, 1, 7, 442165) The All India Congress Committee shall meet as often as may be necessary for the discharge of its obligation and every time upon requisition by 15 members thereof who shall state in their requisition the definite purpose for which they desire a meeting of the All India Congress Committee.
('22', 175, 1, 8, 442455) The All India Congress Committee shall hold office till the election of the new All India Congress Committee.
('22', 175, 2, 9, 442565) Article XX The Secretaries of the respective Provincial Congress Committees shall issue certificates of membership of the All India Committee to the persons so elected.
('22', 175, 3, 10, 442734) Article XXI The All India Congress Committee shall be the Committee of the Congress to carry out the programme of work laid down by the Congress from year to year and deal with all new matters that may arise during the year and may not be provided for by the Congress itself.
('22', 175, 3, 11, 443010) For this purpose the All India Congress Committee shall have the power to frame its own rules within this Constitution.
('22', 175, 4, 12, 443130) Article XXII The President of the Congress shall be the Chairman of the
('22', 176, 0, 1, 443202) VOL. 22 : 23 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 177
('22', 176, 1, 2, 443248) All India Congress Committee for the year following.
('22', 176, 2, 3, 443301) GENERAL SECRETARIES
('22', 176, 3, 4, 443321) Article XXIII The Indian National Congress shall have three General Secretaries, who shall be annually elected by the Congress.
('22', 176, 3, 5, 443449) They shall prepare the report of the work of the All India Congress Committee during the year and submit it, with a full account of the funds which may come into their hands, to the All India Congress Committee at a meeting to be held at the place and about the time of the session of the Congress for the year, and copies of such account and report shall then be presented to the Congress and sent to the Congress Committees.
('22', 176, 4, 6, 443876) WORKING COMMITTEE
('22', 176, 5, 7, 443894) Article XXIV The All India Congress Committee shall at its first meeting appoint a Working Committee consisting of the President, the General Secretaries, the Treasurers and 9 other members, which shall perform such functions as may be delegated to it from time to time by the All India Congress Committee.
('22', 176, 6, 8, 444201) SUBJECTS COMMITTEE
('22', 176, 7, 9, 444220) Article XXV The members of the All India Congress Committee shall constitute the Subjects Committee for the ordinary or extraordinary session following.
('22', 176, 8, 10, 444373) Article XXVI The Subjects Committee shall meet at least two days before the meeting of the Congress in open session.
('22', 176, 8, 11, 444490) At this meeting, the President elect shall preside and the outgoing Secretaries shall submit the draft programme of the work for the ensuing sessions of the Congress, including resolutions recommended by the different Provincial Congress Committees for adoption.
('22', 176, 9, 12, 444753) Article XXVII The Subjects Committee shall proceed to discuss the said programme and shall frame resolutions to be submitted to the open session.
('22', 176, 10, 13, 444899) Article XXVIII The Subjects Committee shall also meet from time to time as the
('22', 177, 0, 1, 444978) 178 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 177, 1, 2, 445020) occasion may require during the pendency of the Congress Session.
('22', 177, 2, 3, 445086) CONTENTIOUS SUBJECTS AND INTERESTS OF MINORITIES
('22', 177, 3, 4, 445135) Article XXIX No subject shall be passed for discussion by the Subjects Committee or allowed to be discussed at any Congress by the President thereof, to the introduction of what the Hindu or Mohammedan Delegates, as a body, object by a majority of _ ths of their number, and if, after the discussion of any subject which has been admitted for discussion, it shall appear that the Hindu or Mohammedan Delegates, as a body, are, by a majority of _ ths of their number, opposed to the resolution which it is proposed to pass thereon such resolution shall be dropped.
('22', 177, 4, 5, 445699) Article XXX The All India Congress Committee shall have the power to frame rules in respect of all matters not covered by the Constitution and not inconsistent with its Articles.
('22', 177, 5, 6, 445878) Article XXXI The Articles and the Creed of the Constitution now in force are hereby repealed without prejudice to all acts done thereunder.

('22', 177, 7, 8, 446085) 93. LETTER TO ANASUYSBEHN SARABHAI
('22', 177, 8, 9, 446120) MOTIHARI, Sunday [December 1920] 1
('22', 177, 9, 10, 446155) REVERED ANSUYABEHN, I have your letter.
('22', 177, 9, 11, 446195) Why should you be surprised that I have so much affection for you?
('22', 177, 9, 12, 446262) I have great faith in you.
('22', 177, 9, 13, 446289) I feel sure that when others have given up you will remain staunch.
('22', 177, 9, 14, 446357) I am a votary of purity, courage and truth.
('22', 177, 9, 15, 446401) I have ascribed all these qualities to you.
('22', 177, 9, 16, 446445) Look after your health.
('22', 177, 9, 17, 446469) I was very unhappy after taking you to Dakorji.
('22', 177, 9, 18, 446517) But such bitter experiences have always been my lot.
('22', 177, 10, 19, 446570) Vandemataram from MOHANDAS
('22', 177, 11, 20, 446597) 1 Gandhiji had visited Dakor in October 1920 and in the same year he was in Motihari on December 9, which date, however, does not concur with the “Sunday” mentioned in the date line.

('22', 179, 0, 1, 448316) 180 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 179, 1, 2, 448358) 96. THE CONGRESS
('22', 179, 2, 3, 448375) The largest 1 and the most important Congress ever held has come and gone.
('22', 179, 2, 4, 448450) It was the biggest demonstration ever held against the present system of Government.
('22', 179, 2, 5, 448535) The President 2 uttered the whole truth when he said that it was a Congress in which, instead of the President and the leaders driving the people, the people drove him and the latter.
('22', 179, 2, 6, 448719) It was clear to everyone on the platform that the people had taken the reins in their own hands.
('22', 179, 2, 7, 448816) The platform would gladly have moved at a slower pace.
('22', 179, 2, 8, 448871) The Congress gave one day to a full discussion of the creed 3 and voted solidly for it with but two dissentients after two nights’ sleep over the discussion.
('22', 179, 2, 9, 449029) It gave one day to a discussion of the Non co operation Resolution and voted for it with unparalleled enthusiasm.
('22', 179, 2, 10, 449143) It gave the last day to listening to the whole of the remaining thirty two Articles of the Constitution which were read and translated word for word by Maulana Mahomed Ali in a loud and clear voice.
('22', 179, 2, 11, 449342) It showed that it was intelligently following the reading of it, for there was dissent when Article Eight was reached.
('22', 179, 2, 12, 449461) It referred to non interference by the Congress in the internal affairs of the Native States.
('22', 179, 2, 13, 449555) The Congress would not have passed the proviso if it had meant that it could not even voice the feelings of the people residing in the territories ruled by the princes.
('22', 179, 2, 14, 449724) Happily, a resolution suggesting the advisability of establishing Responsible Government in their territories enabled me to illustrate to the audience that the proviso did not preclude the Congress from ventilating the grievances and aspirations of the subjects of these states, whilst it clearly prevented the Congress from taking any executive action in connection with them; as, for instance, holding a hostile demonstration in the Native States against any action of theirs.
('22', 179, 2, 15, 450203) The Congress claims to dictate to the Government but it cannot do so by the very nature of its constitution in respect of the Native States.
('22', 179, 2, 16, 450344) Thus the Congress has taken three important steps after the greatest deliberation.
('22', 179, 2, 17, 450427) It has expressed its determination in the clearest possible terms to attain complete self government, if possible still in
('22', 179, 3, 18, 450550) 1 The Congress session of December 1920 was attended by 14,582 delegates— the largest attendance till then at any Congress session.
('22', 179, 3, 19, 450682) 2 C. Vijayaraghavachariar 3 Article I of the new Constitution stating the object of the Congress; vide the preceding item.
('22', 180, 0, 1, 450805) VOL. 22 : 23 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 181
('22', 180, 1, 2, 450851) association with the British people, but even without, if necessary.
('22', 180, 1, 3, 450920) It proposes to do so only by means that are honourable and non violent.
('22', 180, 1, 4, 450992) It has introduced fundamental changes in the constitution regulating its activities and has performed an act of self denial in voluntarily restricting the number of delegates to one for every fifty thousand of the population of India and has insisted upon the delegates being the real representatives of those who want to take any part in the political life of the country.
('22', 180, 1, 5, 451366) And with a view to ensuring the representation of all political parties it has accepted the principle of the “single transferable vote”.
('22', 180, 1, 6, 451503) It has reaffirmed the Non co operation Resolutionof the Special Session 1 and amplified it in every respect.
('22', 180, 1, 7, 451612) 2 It has emphasized the necessity of non violence and laid down that the attainment of swaraj is conditional upon the complete harmony between the component parts of India, and has therefore inculcated Hindu Muslim unity.
('22', 180, 1, 8, 451834) The Hindu delegates have called upon their leaders to settle disputes between Brahmins and non Brahmins and have urged upon the religious heads the necessity of getting rid of the poison of untouchability.
('22', 180, 1, 9, 452040) The Congress has told the parents of school going children and the lawyers that they have not responded sufficiently to the call of the nation and that they must make greater effort in doing so.
('22', 180, 1, 10, 452235) It therefore follows that the lawyers who do not respond quickly to the call for suspension and the parents who persist in keeping their children in Government and aided institutions must find themselves dropping out from the public life of the country.
('22', 180, 1, 11, 452489) The country calls upon every man and woman in India to do their full share.
('22', 180, 1, 12, 452565) But of the details of the Non co operation Resolution I must write later.
('22', 180, 2, 13, 452639) Young India, 5 1 1921
('22', 180, 3, 14, 452661) 97. MORAL VALUES
('22', 180, 4, 15, 452678) There is an extract from the letter of an English friend.
('22', 180, 4, 16, 452736) It is a pleasure to me to receive letters from English friends.
('22', 180, 4, 17, 452800) I know that there are many honest Englishmen who are following the movement of non co operation with sympathetic attention, and would gladly help if they are clear about the moralities of non co operation.
('22', 180, 5, 18, 453006) 1 Held at Calcutta in September 1920 2 For the Non co operation Resolution as passed at Nagpur, vide Appendix “Congress resolution on Non co operation”.
('22', 181, 0, 1, 453159) 182 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 181, 1, 2, 453201) letter is a typical instance.
('22', 181, 2, 3, 453231) I understand that you are striving to establish swaraj in India by appealing to moral force to attain which you rely upon selflessness.
('22', 181, 2, 4, 453367) Permit me to observe that the idea is simply excellent.
('22', 181, 2, 5, 453423) But, is there no fear that the means—non co operation—which you are adopting will fail you in the end, if applied before every unit acts from a purely selfless motive?
('22', 181, 2, 6, 453591) When moral success is aimed at, surely the means must be of the same trend?I also earnestly look forward to the day when, not only India, but also the whole race of man will enjoy swaraj on the following lines:
('22', 181, 3, 7, 453802) The human species exists at the junction of the animal and the moral kingdoms of creation, blessed with free will by the Creator, wherewith to adjudicate between the demands of a material frame (the human animal body) and a moral form (character), and thereby to express the image of the first Great Cause in finite form (in the latter).
('22', 181, 3, 8, 454140) When every unit of the species learns to appreciate moral values in every thought, word and deed, by always giving preference to moral demands because they hail from a higher Kingdom of creation—and to do otherwise will be to defy Omnipotence—selflessness must obviously follow.
('22', 181, 3, 9, 454419) The results will be that every human being will love the other automatically and true swaraj knit the whole family together.
('22', 181, 4, 10, 454544) Does it not seem likely, on the other hand, that, to begin with non co operation will lead to the subordination of your moral goal to ulterior and inferior material desires; and, therefore, even if you do succeed, that you will have lost the very cream of your efforts unintentionally, by making fellow men greater animals than they already are?
('22', 181, 4, 11, 454890) The co operation of selfless representatives of a selfless nation will sooner make a selfless government than non co operation of a nation which strives to follow a selfless leader before waiting first to learn how to conquer self!
('22', 181, 5, 12, 455122) Kindly pause to consider these facts; whatever you do should be for the good of the whole brotherhood of man; and moral values must on no account take a second place, even in an ostensibly trivial instance; otherwise, the cure may be worse than the disease.
('22', 181, 5, 13, 455380) I have given the letter in full omitting an introductory sentence.
('22', 181, 5, 14, 455447) I have refrained from publishing the name because 1 am not sure of the writer’s intention regarding the publication of his name.

('22', 181, 5, 16, 455635) In my opinion there is confusion of thought in this statement of the case.
('22', 181, 5, 17, 455710) It ever has been my purpose to show that dishonourable means cannot bring about an honourable end.

('22', 182, 1, 5, 456220) He helplessly tries to inflict an injury on his supposed enemy.
('22', 182, 1, 6, 456284) In non co operation the result to be achieved is not infliction of punishment but the attainment of justice.

('22', 182, 1, 8, 456466) The hatred of the mob at Amritsar resulted in the cruel murder of innocent men.

('22', 188, 5, 12, 469320) What has the Congress done?

('22', 188, 5, 15, 469393) 2 These three questions should occur to every person.

('22', 188, 5, 17, 469568) Such a huge session of the Congress has never been held, and never before has it deliberated with such seriousness of purpose.
('22', 188, 5, 18, 469695) Important changes have been made in the constitution.
('22', 188, 5, 19, 469749) There was a long discussion on the objects of the Congress and, ultimately, after considering the matter for two nights and one day, votes were taken province wise and the proposed changes were almost unanimously approved.
('22', 188, 5, 20, 469972) The new aim is the achievements of swaraj in the form of our choice, that is, swaraj with the British connection kept up, if possible, or severed if it is not to our liking.
('22', 188, 5, 21, 470146) If this connection is to continue, it can do so only in such form as will permit the aim of the Congressto be fully realized.
('22', 188, 5, 22, 470272) That is to say, the British should give up behaving as our superiors.
('22', 188, 5, 23, 470342) The British connection ought to be intolerable to us so long as we feel that a handful of Englishmen are ruling over us.
('22', 188, 5, 24, 470463) The Congress has also suggested the means for achieving such swaraj.
('22', 188, 5, 25, 470532) It has decided that we are to win it by peaceful and pure means.
('22', 188, 5, 26, 470597) There is no room here for falsehood, trickery, hypocrisy, make believe, etc.

('22', 189, 1, 9, 471391) The other important change is that, while in the past any person and any number of persons could be delegates at a Congress session, this will not be possible now; there will be only two delegates for every hundred thousand of the population in the country.

('22', 189, 1, 11, 471740) According to me, even this number is too large.

('22', 189, 1, 13, 471989) Even then, the fact that some limit has been fixed is an improvement.
('22', 189, 1, 14, 472059) A change has also been made in the method of election.
('22', 189, 1, 15, 472114) Henceforth the delegates will be elected only through the choice of millions and it has also been made obligatory to take necessary measures to induce the participation of Muslims, women, the untouchables and others who have not so far been taking part.

('22', 189, 1, 17, 472512) In order that persons representing all points of view can enter the Congress, it has been decided to introduce a system of voting there under only one vote can be given and, if that vote is not needed by the candidate in question, it can be transferred to another.

('22', 198, 5, 22, 494418) 1. The old Provincial Congress Committee or the old District Congress Committee of a newly created Province 1 shall form the Provincial Congress Committee under the new constitution.
('22', 198, 6, 23, 494601) 2. The existing members who accept the new creed shall forthwith proceed to divide the Province into districts the existing political districts, being retained wherever possible.

('22', 199, 0, 1, 494948) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 199, 1, 2, 494990) 3. Each such district shall divide itself into talukas or tahsils, the existing divisions being retained so far as possible.
('22', 199, 1, 3, 495115) 4. Each taluka shall divide itself into firkas or circles.
('22', 199, 1, 4, 495174) 5. Each existing District Committee shall enrol, from among the villagers within its jurisdiction, as many members as are eligible under the constitution and these members shall form the electoral roll for the election of delegates to the Congress and representatives for the various district Congress Committees.
('22', 199, 1, 5, 495488) 6. An alphabetical list of members with the full name and address and occupation of each shall be forwarded to the Provincial Congress Committee every Monday.
('22', 199, 1, 6, 495647) 7. Each District Committee shall be responsible for the collection of subscription of the members and shall remit half of the proceeds to the Provincial Congress Committee at the same time as the list referred to in rule 6. 8. Each village containing more than five members of a Congress organization formed for it shall elect its secretary, treasurer, chairman, and two other members who shall form the Village Panchayat or Mahajan.

('22', 225, 4, 13, 558856) But surely, one fundamental doctrine of both the Christian and Hindu Scriptures points to quite a different course of conduct.

('22', 225, 4, 15, 559314) Jesus Christ, the Holy and Undefiled One, did not refuse to work along with sinful men, but, on the contrary, while loathing all evil and scathingly denouncing it even in the great ones of his time, He freely and closely associated with all men, from the Pharisee down to the hated tax gatherer of an alien government and the notorious sinner; and endeavoured, both by wise precept and loving example, to wean them from their wickedness and to win them to righteousness.

('22', 228, 5, 16, 565066) 121. SPEECH TO STUDENTS OF NATIONAL SCHOOL, NADIAD 2
('22', 228, 6, 17, 565119) January 19, 1921 Everybody who calls himself an Indian, including yourself and myself, has only one duty today, namely, to take effective steps and make necessary sacrifices to win swaraj within a year, as we wish to do.
('22', 228, 6, 18, 565340) I do not want you to regard swaraj as being a political matter.
('22', 228, 6, 19, 565404) Every child should know the meaning of swaraj, that to have swaraj is part of everyone’s dharma.
('22', 228, 6, 20, 565501) Every child should have the strength to keep his dharma inviolate, should be so strong that nobody can make him do anything against his will by force or threats.
('22', 228, 6, 21, 565663) Every child should have the courage to declare as wrong that which he considers to be wrong and as right that which it considers to be right.
('22', 228, 6, 22, 565805) Parents should have taught their children to discriminate between right and wrong.
('22', 228, 6, 23, 565888) This is the meaning of swaraj.
('22', 228, 6, 24, 565919) It is the right to say what is in one’s mind and act according to it, and the right to refuse to do anything which one considers sinful.

('22', 240, 1, 2, 592718) 126. DUTY OF SPINNING
('22', 240, 2, 3, 592740) I have already discussed the contents of the resolution 1 on non co operation passed by the Congress.
('22', 240, 2, 4, 592842) All the parts are im portant.
('22', 240, 2, 5, 592872) But, of all of them, one is so important that, if the nation acts on it, I am convinced that swaraj will follow immediately.
('22', 240, 2, 6, 592997) This part relates to the duty of spinning.
('22', 240, 2, 7, 593040) I am being asked everywhere whether, if we get swaraj, food will become cheaper and the prices of cloth will come down.
('22', 240, 2, 8, 593160) This is a pertinent question.
('22', 240, 2, 9, 593190) Whether we get swaraj or something else in its place, so long as we depend on foreign countries for the cloth we need, its price, and that of food, will certainly not come down.
('22', 240, 2, 10, 593368) They will not come down because, as long as we send out sixty crores of rupees for our cloth, hunger will not disappear from among us; so long will crores of people remain more or less unemployed and will not get the food and the clothes they need.
('22', 240, 2, 11, 593617) We are thus faced with the problem of producing enough cloth to meet our needs.
('22', 240, 2, 12, 593697) If we produce only that and no more, we shall save sixty crores of rupees and, what is more, the money will be earned by the poor.
('22', 240, 2, 13, 593828) This can be brought about in one way only, by spreading the spinning wheel movement.
('22', 240, 2, 14, 593913) India imports five crore pounds of yarn.
('22', 240, 2, 15, 593954) All this is yarn of 80 counts and higher.
('22', 240, 2, 16, 593996) This means that, had the yarn been coarser, the imports would have amounted to forty crore pounds.
('22', 240, 2, 17, 594095) As long as we are not producing this quantity of yarn, we should not talk about winning freedom for the country.
('22', 240, 2, 18, 594208) What should we do to produce this yarn?
('22', 240, 2, 19, 594248) Our mills cannot produce it.
('22', 240, 2, 20, 594277) Only the spinning wheel can do it, and the easiest method of increasing the output of yarn is to get school pupils to take up this work.
('22', 240, 2, 21, 594414) Accordingly, the senate of the Vidyapith 2 has recommended that the schools affiliated to it should introduce spinning and help produce the required yarn.
('22', 240, 2, 22, 594569) I have always thought of this, and said as much, as a deficiency in our educational programme.
('22', 240, 2, 23, 594664) I hope all teachers and students will welcome this suggestion.
('22', 240, 2, 24, 594727) We shall take it up for detailed consideration some other time.

('22', 241, 1, 2, 594953) 127. SPEECH AT STUDENTS’ MEETING, BOMBAY 1
('22', 241, 2, 3, 594996) January 20, 1921
('22', 241, 3, 4, 595013) Mr Gandhi, who spoke in Hindi, said that if they wanted swaraj, the students must leave their colleges and schools.
('22', 241, 3, 5, 595129) What was their duty, as students, and what were they to do for their country?
('22', 241, 3, 6, 595207) The Congress had given them a definite lead, and laid down the practical step they were to take, and that was non violent non co operation.
('22', 241, 3, 7, 595347) It was their duty to leave all schools and colleges aided or conducted by the Government and do practical work for their motherland.
('22', 241, 3, 8, 595480) By leaving their colleges they would be shaking the moral prestige of the Government and, if they succeeded in doing so, Indians would be successful in attaining swaraj.
('22', 241, 3, 9, 595650) That was the only way of gaining their object, which they all had in view and for which they had to sacrifice.
('22', 241, 3, 10, 595761) Even if they remained for a year or so without attending any educational institution, they would not lose anything.
('22', 241, 3, 11, 595877) What was required was courage and sacrifice to do the thing which could be acquired both in their homes and schools.
('22', 241, 4, 12, 595994) Two of the most important things required of them in order to attain their goal were: first the uplift of their country in an economic sense.
('22', 241, 4, 13, 596136) Everyone of them should learn the art of spinning and weaving; they should do this in order to free their country from the economic thraldom of foreign countries, and if they did it they would be able to render an immense amount of service to their country, by stopping all imports of foreign cloth.
('22', 241, 4, 14, 596436) The next point he wanted to emphasize was that they should have a uniform language; all Indians should have one common language so that wherever they went in India they could make themselves understood.
('22', 241, 4, 15, 596639) Mr. Gandhi suggested that for this purpose they should either adopt Hindi or Urdu.
('22', 241, 4, 16, 596722) He asked the audience to spread this gospel of hand loom weaving to every village in the country, so that they could uplift their country in the economic scale of nations.
('22', 241, 5, 17, 596894) Referring to the action of Calcutta students in leaving their colleges, Mr. Gandhi spoke in eloquent terms of it, and exhorted the students of Bombay to follow their inspiring example.
('22', 241, 5, 18, 597079) He was leaving for Calcutta 2 and he wanted to take their message to the students of Bengal that they in Bombay were with their brethren of Bengal.
('22', 241, 5, 19, 597227) Were they prepared to give him such a message ?
('22', 241, 5, 20, 597275) Were they prepared to make that sacrifice for their mother country?
('22', 241, 5, 21, 597343) He wished to have their reply that very day before he left Bombay.
('22', 241, 5, 22, 597410) Concluding, he prayed to God that the students might be granted wisdom enough to leave their colleges and schools.

('22', 243, 1, 2, 599939) the matter is that the people of India, however degraded their state, have survived to this day with their civilization, while Rome, Egypt, Greece, Persia, etc., have perished.
('22', 243, 1, 3, 600116) Ancient Egypt was not the same as modern Egypt.
('22', 243, 1, 4, 600164) Ancient India was the same, for the most part, as what India is even today.
('22', 243, 1, 5, 600240) Still, assuming for the sake of argument that India was powerless to protect itself at the time British rule came, then today it is even more powerless than it was in those days.
('22', 243, 1, 6, 600419) And the main cause of its being so is the Government itself.
('22', 243, 1, 7, 600480) The Government has not discharged its primary duty.
('22', 243, 1, 8, 600532) It was its duty to train us gradually for self defence.
('22', 243, 1, 9, 600588) Instead, our present condition is that we seem to be incapable of fighting such dangers, whether of external attack or internal disorders.

('22', 257, 4, 10, 636298) EDUCATION OR EXCISE ?
('22', 257, 5, 11, 636320) In his instructive articles 3 on Primary Education in the Punjab, which we have published from time to time, Mr. D. R. Gupta has shown by facts and figures what a set back education has received in that province since it passed into British hands.
('22', 257, 5, 12, 636568) There can be no doubt whatsoever that the civilizing influence there of British satraps and British officials tended to scotch most educational institutions.
('22', 257, 5, 13, 636726) The schools, the teachers, and the scholars have been shown ruthlessly to have suffered at the hands of the British administrator.
('22', 257, 5, 14, 636857) But if the progress of education in the Punjab was gall and wormwood to the official, the advancement of liquor traffic wassweet as honey.
('22', 257, 5, 15, 636996) The achievement of two aims was set before the young officer: to stifle education and to send up the excise revenue.
('22', 257, 5, 16, 637113) The Punjab Excise Report for 1919 20 shows an enormous rise in excise revenue.
('22', 257, 5, 17, 637192) An increase of 25 lakhs in the year brought the total revenue to nearly Rs. 130 lakhs!
('22', 257, 5, 18, 637279) The excise policy of the Government has brought in its wake many baneful results to the people.
('22', 257, 5, 19, 637375) We intend in future issues to reveal this policy as well as substantiate from official figures that the excise policy of the Government is directed systematically to increase the drink evil.

('22', 270, 3, 4, 666251) DEAR MR. BOMANJI 2, You have asked me to state briefly what can lead to a settlement of the present deadlock.
('22', 270, 3, 5, 666361) I shall endeavour to do so.
('22', 270, 3, 6, 666389) A settlement of the Khilafat and the Punjab questions is absolutely necessary to pave the way to an understanding.
('22', 270, 3, 7, 666504) To settle the Khilafat the minimum terms have been already stated.
('22', 270, 3, 8, 666571) They are restoration of the pre war status with such guarantees as may be necessary to prevent the misrule.
('22', 270, 3, 9, 666679) For the Punjab the Minimum is given in the Congress Commiittee’s Report.
('22', 270, 4, 10, 666752) Governments act upon recommendations of their own Committees.
('22', 270, 4, 11, 666814) They can have these from two committees to be appointed with summary powers.
('22', 270, 4, 12, 666891) The committee on the Khilafat may consist, say, of Mahomed Ali and the representative Mussalmans with Sir Valentine as chairman.
('22', 270, 4, 13, 667020) The Punjab committee may consist of Pundit M. M. Malaviya or Nehru 4 and Shastriar 5 and Sir George Lloyd as chairman.
('22', 270, 4, 14, 667139) When these two questions are settled by the adoption by these Committees of the above demands as their own recommendations, a conference of real representatives may he held to frame a scheme of swaraj.
('22', 270, 4, 15, 667341) And that scheme should be passed by the Parliament without alteration.
('22', 270, 4, 16, 667412) Non co operation must continue till swaraj is established.
('22', 270, 4, 17, 667471) But if the negotiations fructify, naturally steps would be taken not to extend its scope.
('22', 270, 5, 18, 667561) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('22', 271, 3, 4, 668071) MY DEAREST CHARLIE, You have inundated me with love letters and I have neglected you.
('22', 271, 3, 5, 668157) But you have been ever in my thoughts and prayer.
('22', 271, 3, 6, 668207) You had no business to get ill.
('22', 271, 3, 7, 668239) 2 You had therefore be better up and ‘doing’.
('22', 271, 3, 8, 668285) And yet on your sick bed you have been doing so much.
('22', 271, 3, 9, 668339) 3 For I see more and more that praying is doing and that silence is the best speech and often the best argument.
('22', 271, 3, 10, 668452) And that is my answer to your anxiety about the untouchables.
('22', 271, 3, 11, 668514) I look at the problem as an Indian and a Hindu, you as an Englishman and a Christian.
('22', 271, 3, 12, 668600) You look at it with the eye of an observer, I as an affected and afflicted party.
('22', 271, 3, 13, 668682) You can be patient, and I cannot.
('22', 271, 3, 14, 668716) Or you as a disinterested reformer can afford to be impatient whereas I as a sinner must be patient if I would get rid of the sin.
('22', 271, 3, 15, 668847) I may talk glibly of the Englishman’s sin in Jallianwala.
('22', 271, 3, 16, 668905) But as a Hindu, I may not talk about the sin of Hinduism against the untouchables.
('22', 271, 3, 17, 668988) I have to deal with the Hindu Dyers.

('22', 274, 1, 2, 674790) 142. LETTER TO LALCHAND
('22', 274, 2, 3, 674814) January 29, 1921
('22', 274, 3, 4, 674831) MY DEAR LALCHAND, I have read the letter from East Africa.
('22', 274, 3, 5, 674890) I believe that you will not shine as an editor.
('22', 274, 3, 6, 674938) You may shine in the absence of any light whatever.
('22', 274, 3, 7, 674990) But you have not reached the minimum standard.
('22', 274, 3, 8, 675037) You have neither the style nor the accuracy of knowledge.
('22', 274, 3, 9, 675095) 1 The style really comes from knowledge.
('22', 274, 3, 10, 675136) You will therefore be unable to give our people the lead they need in East Africa.
('22', 274, 3, 11, 675219) But you must be guided not by me but by your inner voice.
('22', 274, 3, 12, 675277) Anyway, I am seriously thinking of putting someone else in editorial charge.
('22', 274, 3, 13, 675354) I value you as manager, not as editor.
('22', 274, 3, 14, 675393) I am in constant dread.
('22', 274, 3, 15, 675417) I do not know what you have said on caste.
('22', 274, 3, 16, 675460) Joseph has frightened me.
('22', 274, 3, 17, 675486) You ought not to have written at all on that thorny topic.
('22', 274, 3, 18, 675545) You should have waited for me.
('22', 274, 3, 19, 675576) You see that I am in no hurry to air my views on the questions though thereby I am exposing myself [to] being misunderstood.
('22', 274, 3, 20, 675701) I must have leisure for the task.
('22', 274, 3, 21, 675735) I have seen a report of the Nagpur Congress speech.
('22', 274, 3, 22, 675787) It contains glaring errors.
('22', 274, 3, 23, 675815) Your weak English disables you even for the work of touching up things.
('22', 274, 3, 24, 675887) If you reproduce my speeches they should be touched up.
('22', 274, 3, 25, 675943) What therefore, I require, is a better scholar and more informed man than you are in order to make me feel easy about Young India.
('22', 274, 3, 26, 676074) You must therefore be prepared to vacate the chair at any moment.
('22', 274, 3, 27, 676140) If you will remain as manager, I would like to keep you.
('22', 274, 3, 28, 676197) But in that event I would expect you to be absorbed in that work and organize it in the most thorough manner possible.
('22', 274, 3, 29, 676316) I would like you not to take this letter amiss, but believe that it is best for the cause.
('22', 274, 3, 30, 676407) Young India ought to rise higher than where it stands today in its editorial get up and for that purpose an abler assistant is a necessity of the case.
('22', 274, 4, 31, 676559) Yours sincerely,
('22', 274, 5, 32, 676576) M. K. G.

('22', 275, 1, 2, 676749) 143. LETTER TO FRIEND IN BURMA 1
('22', 275, 2, 3, 676782) January 29, 1921
('22', 275, 3, 4, 676799) MY DEAR FRIEND, I know I owe you many apologies, for I have not personally attended to so many of your letters.
('22', 275, 3, 5, 676911) But you know my difficulties.
('22', 275, 3, 6, 676941) I have, however, been sending you replies through Mahadeo Desai or another Desai who has also been kindly helping me.
('22', 275, 3, 7, 677059) You do not now want me to deal with the difficulties you raised in your previous letters.
('22', 275, 3, 8, 677149) If you have any doubt still left, I promise to give you fullest satisfaction about the utmost correctness of my ruling to Mr. Jinnah about Swaraj Sabha 2. Did you ever see my reply 3 to his letter?
('22', 275, 3, 9, 677347) Do you also know that all the Commissioners 4 have at least fulfilled their obligations.
('22', 275, 3, 10, 677436) For Mr. Jayakar also has suspended his practice.
('22', 275, 3, 11, 677485) And now for the education question there.
('22', 275, 3, 12, 677527) We have such an awakening here all round that really it is not possible to spare anyone of those you name.
('22', 275, 3, 13, 677634) My advice to the Burmese is that they must revert to the old system with a new Spirit.
('22', 275, 3, 14, 677721) They need not at the present moment think of Western education.
('22', 275, 3, 15, 677785) If there is any tradition there about hand spinning it should be revived or you should find out the Burmese supplementary industry to agriculture and revive that lostindustry pending full swaraj.
('22', 275, 3, 16, 677981) Let the students understand that swaraj is not to be obtained by learning but by an exhibition in their own lives of the qualities necessary for swaraj, viz., openness, truthfulness, courage, cohesion, fellowship and self sacrifice.
('22', 275, 3, 17, 678214) If they have these qualities, they must take them to their villages and spread them.
('22', 275, 3, 18, 678299) They must teach the villagers that the English are not here for the benefit of the Burman but for their material end.
('22', 275, 3, 19, 678417) They must therefore suspend their literary training till they have freed themselves from foreign domination.
('22', 275, 3, 20, 678526) If I came there, that is how I should talk to them.
('22', 275, 3, 21, 678578) They must unlearn the infatuation of the English language.
('22', 275, 3, 22, 678637) Today it is positively a hindrance to national growth.
('22', 275, 4, 23, 678692) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('22', 275, 4, 24, 678738) Courtesy: Narayan Desai

('22', 276, 1, 2, 679097) 144. SPEECH TO POST GRADUATE AND LAW STUDENTS, CALCUTTA
('22', 276, 2, 3, 679153) January 29, 1921 I shall tell you that the only excuse I could offer for being so horribly late is this pile containing money and jewellery which your Marwari sisters have given for your sake.
('22', 276, 2, 4, 679346) I had the pleasure and privilege of addressing them just now and the response that they made—the so called uncultured ladies of Marwar—was a magnificent response.
('22', 276, 2, 5, 679509) I do not believe there is anything under Rs. 10,000 worth of jewellery and cash in that pile.
('22', 276, 2, 6, 679603) I know you will be pleased to hear from me that more is to be expected from our sisters this very afternoon.
('22', 276, 2, 7, 679712) Do you, therefore, wonder if you find me saying in season and out of season that I do expect swaraj within one year?
('22', 276, 2, 8, 679829) If the response in money, in men and in every respect continues as it has begun, the most confirmed sceptic will be converted to the view that I venture to hold, and I ask all the post graduate students who have gathered here to listen to your leaders, to respond to the resolution 1 of the Congress, nay more, to respond to the voice of your own conscience.
('22', 276, 2, 9, 680188) If you are satisfied that we cannot live under this Government with any degree of self respect, if you are satisfied that this Government has trodden underfoot the most sacred sentiments, that it has disregarded some of the inestimable privileges which we hold dear, you will come to the same conclusion that the Congress has come to: that association with that Government is a crime, is a sin, and if you endorse that view, it is impossible for us to receive any instruction at the hands of or under the influence of a Government such as ours.
('22', 276, 2, 10, 680733) The Duke of Connaught came to Calcutta yesterday and you saw what the great citizens of Calcutta had to say about his visit.
('22', 276, 2, 11, 680858) They carried out a complete hartal.
('22', 276, 2, 12, 680894) Do you suppose that for a man like me, who has always tendered the heartiest and voluntary co operation to this Government for a period of nearly 30 years—do you suppose that it was a matter of pleasure to me that I should associate myself heartily and entirely with a complete boycott of his visit ?
('22', 276, 2, 13, 681195) It was not a pleasure to me.
('22', 276, 2, 14, 681224) At the same time I felt it to be my duty not only to associate myself with it but to propagate the idea that
('22', 276, 3, 15, 681333) 1 On non co operation, passed at the Congress Session at Nagpur in December 1920
('22', 277, 0, 1, 681414) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 278
('22', 277, 1, 2, 681456) to extend any welcome to any representative of the Sovereign would be a mistake, would be a crime, would be inconsistent with our self respect, and that is the view I hold even up to the present moment.
('22', 277, 1, 3, 681659) The Duke of Connaught has come not to wipe your and my tears.
('22', 277, 1, 4, 681721) He has come not to wipe away the insult that has been hurled against Islam and the seven crores of Mohammedans of India.
('22', 277, 1, 5, 681842) He has come not to heal the wounds of the Punjab, but he has come to sustain the power which has been so horribly abused.
('22', 277, 1, 6, 681964) He has come to add prestige to an institution which we consider to be corrupt at its very source and, therefore, it became our duty to boycott that visit, and our duty not to receive any instruction under the influence of that Government.
('22', 277, 1, 7, 682203) And I therefore suggest to you, post graduate students of Calcutta, that you would far rather postpone your further literary progress and throw in your lot with the millions of your countrymen and gain swaraj inside of one year.
('22', 277, 1, 8, 682432) If you feel that by continuing your post graduate studies under the influence of this Government you can advance by one single minute the establishment of swaraj on this great soil, I have no word to say.
('22', 277, 1, 9, 682637) But if you are convinced, as I am convinced, that continuation of our studies under the aegis of this Government can only retard our progress towards the goal, you will not take one single minute before retiring from these studies.
('22', 277, 1, 10, 682869) I want you to face this question boldly and fairly.
('22', 277, 1, 11, 682921) You are not called upon to withdraw because the system of education is rotten, rotten though it undoubtedly is.
('22', 277, 1, 12, 683033) You are called upon to suspend your studies, to withdraw from these institutions because they are under the aegis of this Government which you and I want to destroy, if we cannot mend it.
('22', 277, 1, 13, 683221) And if you approach the question with that view, you will not ask any further question as to your future.
('22', 277, 1, 14, 683327) Your future is safe and insured immediately you come out of these institutions in order to advance the cause of swaraj.
('22', 277, 1, 15, 683447) Your future rests not on these institutions but on yourselves.
('22', 277, 1, 16, 683510) That is the lesson which the Congress resolution teaches you and teaches me.
('22', 277, 1, 17, 683587) Hitherto for a period of 35 years all our resolutions have been addressed to the Government.
('22', 277, 1, 18, 683680) The Congress has altered its course.
('22', 277, 1, 19, 683717) The Congress has asked the nation to become introspective.
('22', 277, 1, 20, 683776) The Congress has turned this searchlight inward.
('22', 277, 1, 21, 683825) The Congress addresses its resolution now not to the Government but to the nation.
('22', 277, 1, 22, 683908) Its prayer is addressed to you, the student world of Calcutta, and to me, an old man passed the stage of youth.
('22', 277, 1, 23, 684020) The Congress addresses its resolution and its prayers to the uncultured men of India, the people living on the fields of India, to
('22', 278, 0, 1, 684151) VOL. 22 : 23 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 279
('22', 278, 1, 2, 684197) the artisans, and to all those whom we consider to be the illiterate masses of India; And the question that rises before you this afternoon is: what are you, the post graduate students, going to do?
('22', 278, 1, 3, 684396) What part are you going to play in this great upheaval?
('22', 278, 1, 4, 684452) Are you going to be mere witnesses or are you going to be actors?
('22', 278, 1, 5, 684518) Are you going to throw yourselves in the thick of the fight and claim the laurels of victory?
('22', 278, 1, 6, 684612) I hope that your decision will be sound, swift and certain, and after having come upon that decision I hope that there will be no shrinking back.
('22', 278, 1, 7, 684758) And I ask the students who are gathered in this theatre 1 to burn their books and not to seek at the present moment a literary career.
('22', 278, 1, 8, 684893) I ask you to work as hewers of wood and drawers of water for the sake of swaraj.
('22', 278, 1, 9, 684974) I, therefore, ask every one of you students to take to the spinning wheel, and you will find the message of the spinning wheel to be true.
('22', 278, 1, 10, 685113) The message of the spinning wheel is that “he who takes me, he who turns me, brings swaraj within a measurable distance.” The message of the spinning wheel is that “every man, woman or child of India will turn me for one year or eight months, and I shall present, in turn, swaraj.” And I ask you to take that message from that wheel which costs no more than Rs. 6 or Rs. 8. Mr. Das was telling me only the other day that there is a Bengali song about the spinning wheel and the song runs somewhat thus: that the spinning wheel gives you all, that the spinning wheel is the cow of plenty; and I assure you that if you ask those who have taken to the spinning wheel they will tell you, “Yes, the spinning wheel is the Kamadhenu for ourselves.” The women who surrounded me this afternoon asked me to give them a message.
('22', 278, 1, 11, 685931) As I went round them asking for donations for your sake, they asked me for a message and my unhesitating message was: “Take up the spinning wheel.
('22', 278, 1, 12, 686078) Purify yourselves, sacrifice yourselves for the sake of the country,” and that is my humble message to you also.
('22', 278, 1, 13, 686191) Purify yourselves by withdrawing yourselves from slave owning institutions and take up the spinning wheel and, if you will do that, I promise you swaraj within one year.
('22', 278, 2, 14, 686361) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 30 1 1921
('22', 278, 3, 15, 686393) 1 The Star Theatre where this meeting was held
