('22', 382, 3, 21, 932892) 203. MESSAGE TO LAHORE SIKHS ON NANKANA TRAGEDY
('22', 382, 4, 22, 932940) March 4, 1921
('22', 382, 5, 23, 932954) DEAR FRIENDS, Having made my pilgrimage to Nankana Saheb yesterday I would like to say a word to my Sikh friends.
('22', 382, 5, 24, 933068) The traces that I saw of the massacre at one of the greatest of your temples and the stories related to me have left an indelible impression on my mind.
('22', 382, 5, 25, 933221) There seems little doubt that nearly one hundred and fifty men of the Akalis party were foully murdered and their bodies mutilated on that fateful Sunday, the 20th Feb[ruary], whilst not a single one of the murderers was apparently hurt by the Akali party.
('22', 382, 5, 26, 933478) There is no doubt that at least one Akali was tied to a tree in the temple ground
('22', 383, 0, 1, 933560) 384 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GADNDHI
('22', 383, 1, 2, 933603) and probably burnt alive.
('22', 383, 1, 3, 933629) There is still less doubt that many of the corpses were soaked in paraffin, and, in order probably to hide the fact that only men of one party were killed, they were burnt.
('22', 383, 1, 4, 933802) No one of the Akalis that gained entrance to the temple seems to have escaped to tell the tale of the butchery.
('22', 383, 1, 5, 933914) The temple presents the appearance of a fort.
('22', 383, 1, 6, 933960) The walls of the rooms that surround the shrine are pierced to admit of shooting through them.
('22', 383, 1, 7, 934055) The partition walls have connecting holes.
('22', 383, 1, 8, 934098) The main door has massive steel plates evidently of recent make.
('22', 383, 1, 9, 934163) The Granth Saheb 1 bears bullet marks.
('22', 383, 1, 10, 934202) The walls of the sanctuary and the pillars tell the same tale.
('22', 383, 1, 11, 934265) The Akali party seem to have been treacherously admitted and the gates closed on them.
('22', 383, 1, 12, 934352) Everything I saw and heard points to a second edition of Dyerism more barbarous, more calculated and more fiendish than the Dyerism at Jallianwala.
('22', 383, 1, 13, 934500) Man in Nankana, where once a snake is reported to have innocently spread its hood to shade the lamb like Guru 2, turned Satan on that black Sunday.
('22', 383, 1, 14, 934648) India weeps today over the awful tragedy.
('22', 383, 1, 15, 934690) I am ashamed to find that there are men today who are capable of the crime committed by sons of India in that holy temple.
('22', 383, 1, 16, 934813) Information is lacking to show why the Akali party went to the temple and whether they offered resistance to the murderers.
('22', 383, 1, 17, 934937) They had all their kirpans and mostly their hatchets.
('22', 383, 1, 18, 934991) There are three possibilities that could have happened: 1. The party went by a show of force to take possession of the temple but were overwhelmed by superior force and died fighting bravely.
('22', 383, 1, 19, 935183) 2. The party went merely as worshippers, had no intention of taking possession and were treacherously murdered without being able to defend themselves.
('22', 383, 1, 20, 935335) 3. The party went as worshippers, as in the second case, and were mercilessly attacked; but though able to defend themselves would not retaliate and willingly died being under a vow not to use violence in connection with the gurudwara movement.

('22', 387, 6, 13, 942933) 205. SPEECH AT MULTAN
('22', 387, 7, 14, 942955) March 5, 1921
('22', 387, 8, 15, 942969) Mahatmaji started by apologizing for having twice failed to keep his promise to go to Multan; once it was because of the news that the Government wanted to arrest him and Maulana Shaukat Ali, so they had to hurry back to Ahmedabad; and the second time the sudden and tragic news of Nankana Saheb compelled him to give up his programme of coming to Multan from Lyallpur; and even for the present visit he was greatly dissuaded from coming to Multan on account of the prevalence of plague.
('22', 387, 8, 16, 943457) But in spite of that, he had gone there owing to the affection they cherished for him.
('22', 387, 8, 17, 943544) While congratulating the Seva Samiti for the relief given by them to their plague stricken brethren, he could not help accusing the people of Multan and the Municipality of being partly responsible for the prevalence of the scourge on account of the extremely insanitary condition of the city.
('22', 387, 8, 18, 943838) Cleanliness and purity of body, mind and soul was their primary duty without which attainment of swaraj was impossible.
('22', 387, 8, 19, 943958) From the discussion of the plague, Mahatmaji proceeded to refer to a ‘greater plague’, the subjection of the nation.
('22', 387, 9, 20, 944075) 1 During 1921 Gandhiji several times referred to students’ disturbances in his writings and correspondence.
('22', 387, 9, 21, 944183) He was in Multan on March 5, 1921. 2 Here Gandhiji presumably refers to a recent incident in which disrespect was shown by students at Banaras to Malaviya.

('22', 388, 1, 2, 944385) From the persistent invitation of the Multanis he had thought that they were anxious to show him the progress they had made towards swaraj, but he regretted that he could not congratulate them on their achievements.
('22', 388, 1, 3, 944601) At first he had thought that his brother Maulana Shaukat Ali had missed a great deal by not coming to Multan and witnessing what the Multanis had done towards the national movement; but after coming to Multan he was no more sorry on that account.
('22', 388, 1, 4, 944848) He found that the Multanis had held a great meeting.
('22', 388, 1, 5, 944901) It was possible to have a bigger meeting, but he regretted they had done practically nothing to combat the greater plague.

('22', 391, 1, 2, 952138) 209. SPEECH AT HOSHIARPUR
('22', 391, 2, 3, 952164) March 8, 1921
('22', 391, 3, 4, 952178) Mahatmaji in his speech regretted the absence of Maulana Shaukat Ali who was his brother and had common cause with him.
('22', 391, 3, 5, 952298) He said he was a staunch Sanatanist and Maulana Shaukat Ali was a staunch Mohammedan, but still they were like brothers, which showed that Hindu Muslim unity was possible.
('22', 391, 3, 6, 952470) He congratulated Hoshiarpur on having hand made cloth factories, but regretted that still people had foreign cloth on them.
('22', 391, 3, 7, 952594) There was no shame for men and women in weaving and spinning for themselves.
('22', 391, 3, 8, 952671) To be able to kill was no courage.

('22', 394, 2, 7, 961432) 212. NOTES
('22', 394, 3, 8, 961443) TELEGRAPHIC EMBARGO
('22', 394, 4, 9, 961463) A message was required by my assistant at Ahmedabad regarding the Duke’s visit to Bombay.
('22', 394, 4, 10, 961553) 1 I sent the following wire: “Bombay should certainly boycott Duke’s visit like other cities.” The message was sent on the 18th ultimo.
('22', 394, 4, 11, 961689) I received the following reply dated the 24th ultimo at the Lahore Telegraph Office:
('22', 394, 5, 12, 961774) Your telegram addressed to Anandanand, Navajivan, Ahmedabad, on the 18th has been held up at Ahmedabad as objectionable under rulings of the Department.
('22', 394, 5, 13, 961927) A refund will be granted on your applying for same.
('22', 394, 6, 14, 961979) Nobody can seriously object to the prevention of the telegraph line being used for destroying a system in whose interest, chiefly, it is run.
('22', 394, 6, 15, 962121) Only, the embargo further discredits the system.
('22', 394, 6, 16, 962170) If one man alone thought it evil, the embargo would enable the thinker to hang his theme on the ‘atrocious limitation of the liberty of the public’.
('22', 394, 6, 17, 962319) In a case like the present, it was very like the attempt to stop with a straw an onrushing torrent.
('22', 394, 6, 18, 962419) In either case the prohibition of bona fide propaganda, even though it may be objectionable from the Govern ment’s standpoint, must be a useless procedure.
('22', 394, 6, 19, 962575) The present embargo, however, is symptomatic of a Government tottering to its own des truction.
('22', 394, 7, 20, 962671) ITS LESSON
('22', 394, 8, 21, 962682) Though I consider this embargo to be an exhibition of mere local overzeal, it has a lesson for us.
('22', 394, 8, 22, 962781) Any day the Government may prohibit the use of the telegraph, the post, the rail, and the press by non co operationists.
('22', 394, 8, 23, 962902) Will it stop the struggle for a single minute?
('22', 394, 9, 24, 962949) 1 The Duke of Connaught was to visit Bombay in the last week of February 1921.
('22', 395, 0, 1, 963028) 396 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 395, 1, 2, 963070) hope not.
('22', 395, 1, 3, 963080) It has been conceived so as to be independent of Government sufferance.
('22', 395, 1, 4, 963152) For it depends for success upon its universality.
('22', 395, 1, 5, 963202) Non co operation by stray individuals is, no doubt, possible and conceivable.
('22', 395, 1, 6, 963280) It has then to take a somewhat different shape.
('22', 395, 1, 7, 963328) But when the spirit of it pervades the whole of India, we need not feel dependent upon the telegraph, the post, the rail, or the press.
('22', 395, 1, 8, 963464) Our work can be done quite effectively without the aid of these agencies.
('22', 395, 1, 9, 963538) We can send messages from mouth to mouth with electric speed.
('22', 395, 1, 10, 963600) The railway train quickly transfers leaders from place to place, but it quickly transfers thousands of curiosity mongers who serve no purpose and cause national waste.
('22', 395, 1, 11, 963768) I can contemplate with perfect calmness the prohibition of the use of the rail by all except those who sign the creed of co operation with the Government—we should have an automatic census of co operators.
('22', 395, 1, 12, 963974) So long as we have pen and paper, or even slate and pencil, we need not despair of transmitting our thoughts in writing, if we have enough volunteers.

('22', 396, 2, 5, 966065) GOVERNMENT PROPAGANDA
('22', 396, 3, 6, 966087) The Bihar Government is illustrating the meaning of counter propaganda by Government, referred to in his speech by Lord Chelmsford.
('22', 396, 3, 7, 966219) 1 This Government has gagged non co operationists of unimpeachable character and invited its officials and other supporters to conduct an unopposed campaign against non co operation.
('22', 396, 3, 8, 966402) I understand that overzealous chowkidars announce these Government meetings in my name.
('22', 396, 3, 9, 966490) The people gather, see unfamiliar faces, and most of them retire.
('22', 396, 3, 10, 966556) Those who remain to listen to the eloquence of co operators are told that, if the law courts are abandoned and the drink shops are closed, the Government revenue will suffer.
('22', 396, 3, 11, 966731) Thus, these co operation speakers put a premium on drink and litigation.
('22', 396, 3, 12, 966804) I have given the substance of a graphic description given to me by a most reliable worker.
('22', 396, 3, 13, 966895) It is a highly probable picture.
('22', 396, 3, 14, 966928) A moment’s thought will show that the Government speakers must say what my informant has attributed to them.
('22', 396, 3, 15, 967037) A non co operationist usually begins by describing the Khilafat and the Punjab wrongs and demonstrating the Satanic nature of the system under which we are governed.
('22', 396, 3, 16, 967203) He ends by asking people to be peaceful, to renounce intoxicants, law courts, schools and foreign goods, and to take up the spinningwheel.
('22', 396, 3, 17, 967342) A thoughtless non co operation speaker also abusesco operators and ignorantly advises their social boycott.

('22', 396, 3, 19, 967780) The spinning wheel, he must contend, is an antediluvian fad impossible to reintroduce in our homes, and foreign goods we cannot do without till India has become educated and industrial to the extent of being able

('22', 397, 1, 2, 968090) to compete with foreign markets.
('22', 397, 1, 3, 968123) Thus Government propaganda must at least indirectly encourage drinking, litigation and use of foreign goods.
('22', 397, 1, 4, 968232) An honest Government responsive to the wishes of the people will seize this golden opportunity of allying itself with the people, thus getting rid of the drink curse, will encourage even indifferent experiments in national education as a lesson in self help, will stimulate the desire for settlement of disputes by arbitration, and will welcome the revival of hand spinning, if only as an aid to machine manufacture and industry in the place of idleness.

('22', 397, 2, 7, 969123) THE NAGPUR INCIDENT
('22', 397, 3, 8, 969143) Not only is it too early yet to expect any such change of heart, but the Nagpur prosecutions make it clear that the C. P. Government intend to take severe notice of temperance workers.
('22', 397, 3, 9, 969328) Dr. Cholkar and Mr. Paranjapye are well known workers.
('22', 397, 3, 10, 969383) They are both undergoing prosecution virtually for temperance propaganda, The magistrate’s notice, which I have seen in the papers, clearly shows that Government cannot look with unconcern upon a diminution in the drink revenue.
('22', 397, 3, 11, 969612) They insisted upon holding their sale of liquor licences by a show of force, when it was their plain duty not to hold such a sale at all in view of public feeling but take advantage of it to abolish the drink traffic altogether.
('22', 397, 4, 12, 969841) AND MADRAS?
('22', 397, 5, 13, 969853) Madras has not lagged behind, either, in the campaign against non co operation.
('22', 397, 5, 14, 969933) It may be noted, in passing, that Madras has not shown even the rowdyism that has been noticed elsewhere.

('22', 397, 5, 16, 970171) A telegram has just arrived saying that four more Malabar leaders have preferred imprisonment to giving security.
('22', 397, 5, 17, 970285) It is evident that this wave of repression that is passing through India is not due to accident but to

('22', 398, 1, 2, 970434) design.
('22', 398, 1, 3, 970442) I am inclined to believe the bazaar talk that the word has gone from the central authority that the local administrations are free to take up energetic measures to kill non co operation.
('22', 398, 2, 4, 970629) DUTY OF NON CO OPERATIONISTS
('22', 398, 3, 5, 970658) Our duty in the face of this repression is clear.
('22', 398, 3, 6, 970708) We have undertaken to suffer for the sake of Islam, the Punjab, and swaraj.
('22', 398, 3, 7, 970784) We must therefore welcome these prosecutions and the resulting imprisonments.
('22', 398, 3, 8, 970862) Every good movement passes through five stages: indifference, ridicule, abuse, repression and respect.
('22', 398, 3, 9, 970965) We had indifference for a few months.
('22', 398, 3, 10, 971003) Then the Viceroy graciously laughed at it.
('22', 398, 3, 11, 971046) Abuse, including misrepresentation, has been the order of the day.
('22', 398, 3, 12, 971113) The provincial Governors and the anti non co operation Press have heaped as much abuse upon the movement as they have been able to.
('22', 398, 3, 13, 971245) Now comes repression, at present yet in its fairly mild form.
('22', 398, 3, 14, 971307) Every movement that survives repression, mild or severe, invariably commands respect which is another name for success.
('22', 398, 3, 15, 971427) This repression, if we are true, may be treated as a sure sign of the approaching victory.
('22', 398, 3, 16, 971518) But, if we are true, we shall neither be cowed down nor angrily retaliate and be violent.
('22', 398, 3, 17, 971608) Violence is suicide.
('22', 398, 3, 18, 971629) Let us recognize that power dies hard, and that it is but natural for the Government to make a final effort for life even though it be through repression.
('22', 398, 3, 19, 971784) Complete self restraint at the present critical moment is the speediest way to success, and the easiest way of blunting the edge of repressive measures is a more extensive boycott of titles, schools, law courts, and foreign cloth, and a more intelligent activity for the revival of hand spinning and hand weaving.
('22', 398, 4, 20, 972098) JOURNALISTIC IGNORANCE
('22', 398, 5, 21, 972121) It has been my lot to be misrepresented and misunderstood throughout a busy life of thirty years, often by the respective governments with whom I had to deal and sometimes by the people whom I had to serve.
('22', 398, 5, 22, 972328) Having been intimately connected with the Press, both as a journalist and as a public man, I have had to suffer also for its ignorance.
('22', 398, 5, 23, 972464) But at no time have I so much realized the measure of ignorance betrayed by the Press as at the present moment.
('22', 398, 5, 24, 972576) The cuttings that friends at times send me from England and America add even unscrupulousness to ignorance.
('22', 398, 5, 25, 972684) The latest instance of careless reading and gross ignorance that has come under my notice is that of The Leader.
('22', 398, 5, 26, 972797) It has an article on spinning which misinterprets the very
('22', 399, 0, 1, 972856) 400 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 399, 1, 2, 972898) article it quotes.
('22', 399, 1, 3, 972917) One of the young men travelling with me showed it to me.
('22', 399, 1, 4, 972974) I was pained at the ignorance and carelessness betrayed by the writer.
('22', 399, 1, 5, 973045) I asked the young man in question to write out his own reply if he had understood The Leader’s fallacies.
('22', 399, 1, 6, 973151) His reply 1 is so effective that I give it elsewhere instead of attempting it myself.
('22', 399, 2, 7, 973237) CENSUS ENUMERATORS
('22', 399, 3, 8, 973256) I have been asked as to whether census enumerators should co operate with the Government by responding to the Government’s call.
('22', 399, 3, 9, 973385) Not being clear myself I have hitherto shirked a public answer.
('22', 399, 3, 10, 973449) The spirit of civil disobedience in me has pulled me one way, my loyalty to the existing programme has pulled me in the opposite direction.
('22', 399, 3, 11, 973589) My loyalty has triumphed and I am clear that we must co operate with the Government in the matter of the census.
('22', 399, 3, 12, 973702) I am convinced that it strengthens our cause.
('22', 399, 3, 13, 973748) It disciplines us in the habit of even reluctant obedience to statutory rules when they do not hurt our conscience or honour, and demonstrates the high and non violent character of our struggle.
('22', 399, 3, 14, 973943) We must resist the temptation to offer civil disobedience even when it is so great as in the matter of the census.
('22', 399, 3, 15, 974058) Thousands of us have a singular opportunity presented to us of showing our dislike of the existing system of Government.
('22', 399, 3, 16, 974179) But the exercise of restraint at the present moment enables us to prepare for civil disobedience in future.
('22', 399, 3, 17, 974287) Let us, therefore, help the Government to complete the census operations, not because we fear the punishment of disobedience, but because we are by nature and training law abiding, and we need not as yet disobey unmoral laws, whether by way of protest or with the view of destroying the authority of a Government which no longer enjoys our confidence.
('22', 399, 3, 18, 974639) That extreme step in non violent non co operation is open to us but we recognize that the atmosphere for its working has not yet been sufficiently created, and that we may not take extreme steps whilst milder measures are open to us.
('22', 399, 3, 19, 974873) I hope, therefore, that all those who may be called upon in terms of the existing law to help census operations will render the required assistance to the authorities.

('22', 401, 1, 2, 977726) 213. THE VICEROY’S TWO SPEECHES
('22', 401, 2, 3, 977758) His Excellency the Viceroy has made two important declara ions, one on the Khilafat 1 and the other on non co operation 2 and the policy of the Government arising from it.
('22', 401, 2, 4, 977930) On the Khilafat His Excellency has given an exact indication of the Government mentality.
('22', 401, 2, 5, 978020) He thinks that he has discharged his responsibility fully towards the Muslims of India by pressing their claim.
('22', 401, 2, 6, 978132) Whereas the Indian contention is that, on a matter so vital to the Muslims, he should have resigned when he found that the Imperial Government had disallowed the Indian claim.
('22', 401, 2, 7, 978308) Nobody accepts the plea of Britain’s helplessness at the Council table of the League of Nations.
('22', 401, 2, 8, 978405) The public may also recall the fact that, when the terms of the treaty of Sevres were published, 3 the Viceroy entered upon an elaborate defence of the part played by the Premier.
('22', 401, 2, 9, 978585) How comes it, then, that he finds himself again pleading the Muslim cause!
('22', 401, 2, 10, 978660) Would he have done so if there had been no non co operation?
('22', 401, 2, 11, 978721) And what has he to say even now?
('22', 401, 2, 12, 978754) If the claim is disallowed and non co operation is still pursued, he assumes that anarchy will be the result.
('22', 401, 2, 13, 978864) Therefore the Government, he threatens, will step in to restore order.
('22', 401, 2, 14, 978935) We know what “restoring” order means.
('22', 401, 2, 15, 978973) His Excellency forgets that, if there is anarchy in India, it would be due to the criminal breach of their duty both by the Imperial and the Indian Governments towards the three hundred millions of the people of India.
('22', 401, 2, 16, 979192) A Viceroy may be satisfied with merely pleading the case of India.
('22', 401, 2, 17, 979259) Can India be satisfied?
('22', 401, 2, 18, 979283) Can a man who is dying of hunger be satisfied with mere sympathy, especially when he knows that the sympathiser can give more than mere sympathy?
('22', 401, 2, 19, 979429) When the Indian Government pleads the duty of subordination to an immoral superior power, it must share the adverse judgment that may be pronounced against the latter.
('22', 401, 2, 20, 979597) No duty devolves upon any servant of submitting to orders in breach of trust or honour.
('22', 401, 2, 21, 979685) The treaty of Sevres is a breach of solemn pledges and the ordinary canons of honour.
('22', 401, 2, 22, 979771) One who sincerely sympathizes with a starving man is presumed to share such sufferings, and is not expected to shoot him when the latter shows symptoms of becoming mad through the pangs of hunger.
('22', 401, 2, 23, 979968) The responsibility for anarchy, if it does overtake India, will therefore rest

('22', 405, 3, 8, 987396) 216. SIKH AWAKENING
('22', 405, 4, 9, 987416) Such has been the awakening among the Sikhs and so spirited is that community that either this awakening will deliver India from bondage within eight months or it will obstruct that deliverance.
('22', 405, 4, 10, 987611) They have strength of both body and mind.
('22', 405, 4, 11, 987653) They are brave with the sword.
('22', 405, 4, 12, 987684) It may be said that they are strong of will, too.
('22', 405, 4, 13, 987734) The Sikhs are believed to number some thirty lakhs.
('22', 405, 4, 14, 987786) Till today I had thought of them as a sect of Hinduism.
('22', 405, 4, 15, 987842) But their leaders think that theirs is a distinct religion.
('22', 405, 4, 16, 987902) Guru Nanak was its founder and Guru Govind Singh its defender.
('22', 405, 4, 17, 987965) The Sikhs believe in ten gurus in all.
('22', 405, 4, 18, 988004) Guru Nanak, of course, was a Hindu but, according to Sikh leaders, he founded a new religion.
('22', 405, 4, 19, 988098) Outwardly their religion is symbolized by five K’s.
('22', 405, 4, 20, 988150) Those five things are: kesha 1, kangi 2, kada 3, kachha 4, kirpan.
('22', 405, 4, 21, 988217) As they do not shave their beards—or trim their hair, they need the comb.
('22', 405, 4, 22, 988291) The steel bangle they wear on the wrist is a symbol of self control.
('22', 405, 4, 23, 988360) The purpose of the kachha is easy to understand.

('22', 406, 1, 2, 988501) kirpan is what is called a jambiya and they look upon it as a sign oftheir strength in defending their faith and as an object of terror to the enemy.
('22', 406, 1, 3, 988651) Till some years ago, not much emphasis was laid on these five things, but the younger Sikhs now attach importance to them and those who, though professing to be Sikhs, do not wear them, are not accepted as such by the reformers.
('22', 406, 1, 4, 988880) The latter have been persuading even women to wear the kirpan.
('22', 406, 1, 5, 988943) One of their elders once told me that the Sikhs do not believe in varnashrama; there is no high or low among them; there is no untouchability; they look upon idol worship as a sin.
('22', 406, 1, 6, 989124) Though they show reverence for Rama, Krishna and others, these do not have among them the same place as in Hinduism.
('22', 406, 1, 7, 989241) They do not believe in cow protection, though they do not eat beef.
('22', 406, 1, 8, 989309) They believe in rebirth and mukti 1. They do not hold the Vedas or other Hindu scriptures in special regard.
('22', 406, 1, 9, 989418) Their sacred book 2 is the word of their gurus and, apart from that book, they accept no other scriptures as holy books.
('22', 406, 1, 10, 989539) Tobacco and liquor are forbidden among them.
('22', 406, 1, 11, 989584) Sikh temples are known as gurudwaras.
('22', 406, 1, 12, 989622) The reformers believe that the standards in these gurudwaras have become lax and the mahants too often impious scoundrels.
('22', 406, 1, 13, 989745) Some of the gurudwaras have historic importance.
('22', 406, 1, 14, 989794) The reformers think that it would be best to take over control of all of them.
('22', 406, 1, 15, 989873) This movement, which has been going on for a number of years now, seeks to introduce changes in them and to put their management under a committee.
('22', 406, 1, 16, 990021) Leading Sikhs like Sardar Sunder Singh Majithia are also associated with this movement, which has become more rigorous after the starting of non co operation.
('22', 406, 1, 17, 990180) Organizations of Sikhs known as Akali Jathas or Akali Dals are springing up everywhere and are taking over possession of the gurudwaras.
('22', 406, 1, 18, 990317) They have their headquarters at Amritsar.

('22', 406, 1, 20, 990540) Some of them have staffs without axes.
('22', 406, 1, 21, 990579) Fifty or a hundred men of such groups go and take possession of a gurudwara.

('22', 411, 11, 21, 1000776) HUMANITY V. PATRIOTISM A dear friend has drawn my attention to what he considers is an unfortunate appeal to patriotism rather than humanity in my letter 4 to the Sikhs.
('22', 411, 11, 22, 1000946) The portion objected to is this:
('22', 411, 12, 23, 1000979) The purest way of seeking justice against the murderers is not to seek it.
('22', 411, 12, 24, 1001054) The perpetrators, whether they are Sikhs, Pathans or Hindus, are our countrymen.

('22', 412, 1, 4, 1001691) Only the strong can forgive.
('22', 412, 1, 5, 1001720) I have read the foregoing again and again.
('22', 412, 1, 6, 1001763) I feel that if I had to rewrite the letter, I should not alter a single word in it.
('22', 412, 1, 7, 1001847) My appeal in that letter is to the Sikhs as Indians.
('22', 412, 1, 8, 1001900) And it was enough for me to confine my appeal to the point that could be easily appreciated and reached by those whom I was addressing.
('22', 412, 1, 9, 1002036) The main reasoning would be the same for all, and at all times.
('22', 412, 1, 10, 1002100) My letter as addressed to the Sikhs would have lost its force somewhat if I had broadened the appeal as from patriotism to humanity.
('22', 412, 1, 11, 1002233) A Sikh who will want to punish a non Sikh criminal but would forgive a Sikh may be told that to him Sikh and Indian must mean the same thing in matters such as the incident covers.

('22', 419, 3, 21, 1020306) 223. FAMINE INSURANCE
('22', 419, 4, 22, 1020328) When I wrote about the spinning wheel being a household instrument of famine insurance, I little realized its implications.
('22', 419, 4, 23, 1020452) What I then saw through the glass of reason darkly, I now see more clearly with the undimmed eye of experience.
('22', 419, 4, 24, 1020564) With famine staring us in the face in Bijapur, Ahmednagar and in some parts of Gujarat, 1 it behoves us to consider carefully what this spinning wheel as an insurance
('22', 419, 5, 25, 1020731) 1 During the early months of 1921, famine was declared by the Government in Bijapur district and scarcity in five other districts of Bombay Presidency.
('22', 420, 0, 1, 1020883) VOL. 22 : 23 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 421
('22', 420, 1, 2, 1020929) agency means.
('22', 420, 1, 3, 1020943) Let me give some figures.
('22', 420, 1, 4, 1020969) A spinning wheel costs, say, six rupees.
('22', 420, 1, 5, 1021010) If we supply a family of three with two wheels and all the members work at it together for eight hours each, they will, between them, earn at least six annas per day.
('22', 420, 1, 6, 1021177) I claim that six annas per day for a family will keep it going during a season of distress.
('22', 420, 1, 7, 1021269) I can conceive it to be possible for them to work at the rate of twelve hours each, when the work has to be done in their homes at their own leisure.
('22', 420, 1, 8, 1021419) They add fifty per cent to the daily earning making it nine annas per day.
('22', 420, 1, 9, 1021494) Thus at an outlay of Rs. 12,000, we can support for four months one thousand families, or three thousand souls, and get from them a
('22', 420, 2, 10, 1021626) 1,000 families x 6 Annas x 120 days = Rs. 45,000
('22', 420, 3, 11, 1021675) 16 return of worth of labour.
('22', 420, 3, 12, 1021705) No doubt, forty five thousand rupees will have to be found in the first instance for organizing famine relief, in addition to carded cotton and the spinning wheels.
('22', 420, 3, 13, 1021870) The whole of the yarn that may be produced by the famine stricken people would be used by the nation.
('22', 420, 3, 14, 1021972) There will be some little waste during the first month of learning I use the adjectives ‘some little’ advisedly because cotton will not be absolutely wasted.
('22', 420, 3, 15, 1022130) Suppose further that we make a present to these families of the spinning wheels, they will never need to starve or be in need of funds.
('22', 420, 3, 16, 1022266) All that will be necessary for these families in future will be to be able to have a supply of cotton and a ready sale for the yarn they may manufacture.
('22', 420, 3, 17, 1022420) The experiment can be indefinitely multiplied, and I make bold to say that, if we introduce the spinning wheel in every family home, we insure the nation practically against famine.
('22', 420, 3, 18, 1022602) I have assumed here that the famine is one of money and that the distressed area is able to buy corn if it has funds.
('22', 420, 3, 19, 1022720) Such was the case in Kheda three years ago, such was the case in Orissa 1 last year, and such is the case in Bijapur and Gujarat this year.
('22', 420, 3, 20, 1022860) I invite the public to try the experiment.
('22', 420, 3, 21, 1022903) I would ask the benevolent not to waste their benevolence by contributing funds to Government organizations which make people more and more helpless.
('22', 420, 3, 22, 1023053) I advise them to form their own committees of trustworthy workers and try the experiment themselves.
('22', 420, 3, 23, 1023154) Surely they will see that in it there is no possibility of failure or loss and every probability of the families helped becoming self reliant and
('22', 420, 4, 24, 1023300) 1 Vide “Famine in Orissa”, 9 5 1920 & “Distress in Orissa”, 12 5 1920.

('22', 421, 4, 14, 1024366) The famous jurist, Dr. Rash Behari Ghose 1 Bengal, died last Monday at the age of 76. His learning was unfathomable.
('22', 421, 4, 15, 1024483) His charity was of equal grandeur.
('22', 421, 4, 16, 1024518) His patriotism was not of the ordinary kind.
('22', 421, 4, 17, 1024563) His indefatigable diligence put to shame many a youth.
('22', 421, 4, 18, 1024618) His command of English was highly eulogized.
('22', 421, 4, 19, 1024663) Nevertheless he would be considered a man of bygone age.
('22', 421, 4, 20, 1024720) Dr. Rash Behari Ghose was the most striking example of how the most eminent of India’s men of learning become useless owing to a foreign domination and unnational education.
('22', 421, 4, 21, 1024894) He passed his youth in cultivating an English style which surpassed European writers, instead and then of devoting all his parts to his mother tongue.
('22', 421, 4, 22, 1025045) He expended his unfathomable erudition in elucidating law points based on Western view points of life and occidental speculation, and in interpreting the same.
('22', 421, 4, 23, 1025205) All that he did after having entered the Congress was to circumscribe the objective of the national assembly.
('22', 421, 4, 24, 1025315) The creed that he formulated at Surat had to be modified this year by the National Congress at Nagpur.
('22', 421, 4, 25, 1025418) He gave a sum of ten lakhs to the Calcutta University although he coupled it with the condition that the professor who was to be maintained on the interest of this foundation must be an Indian.
('22', 421, 4, 26, 1025612) He made large
('22', 421, 5, 27, 1025626) 1 1840 1921; president of the Indian National Congress at Surat, 1907, and at Madras, 1908

('22', 422, 1, 2, 1025763) contributions also to the Indian universities.
('22', 422, 1, 3, 1025810) Thus he dedicated his abilities to cultivate a foreign tongue, his intellect to assisting Government law courts, his wealth to aid that system of education of a Government in whose policy he had no confidence, and the weight of his personality in limiting the national ideal.
('22', 422, 1, 4, 1026086) Nevertheless had such a person been born in the epoch of swaraj, his life would have appeared golden and his services perceived by the entire world.
('22', 422, 1, 5, 1026235) By the two resolutions that he got passed in the Legislative Council, he demonstrated that he was perfectly conscious of the inordinate regard and affection which the people of India have for their own country.
('22', 422, 1, 6, 1026446) Had he received a national education, the same sentiment and love would have manifested themselves in him and he would have been in a position to render the loftiest services to the country.
('22', 422, 1, 7, 1026637) The people have not appreciated him to the extent that the Government did, because having received the culture confined to the Western globe, he had become almost a stranger to his people.

('22', 423, 6, 31, 1029911) Mr. Gandhi spoke in Gujarati.
('22', 423, 6, 32, 1029941) He said he wanted to tell them a few words about the present situation in the country.
('22', 423, 6, 33, 1030028) He had toured all over the country and had earned a good deal of experience during the tour, but he had no time to tell them at length all that he had known and seen in different parts of the country.
('22', 423, 6, 34, 1030229) He could only tell them that if they went on with their non co operation propaganda work as peacefully as they, in all parts of the country, had done during the last five months, they were sure to get swaraj in a year and so also the revision of the unjust Turkish Treaty and justice for the Punjab wrongs.
('22', 424, 0, 1, 1030536) VOL. 22 : 23 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 425
('22', 424, 1, 2, 1030582) The great achievement that they had made during the last five months was that the ryot had realized that Government given titles had no worth; that the education imparted by the bureaucracy was no education and that foreign goods had no value.
('22', 424, 1, 3, 1030826) The ryots had also realized that bureaucratic law courts were of no practical use to them.
('22', 424, 2, 4, 1030917) Continuing, he said it was not only the ryots that realized this truth, the other classes also had felt it.
('22', 424, 2, 5, 1031025) Those students present there could nothonestly say that they felt it honourable to remain in the Government schools and such was the case with the lawyers practising in bureaucratic courts.
('22', 424, 2, 6, 1031215) During his tours in Bengal, the Punjab and the United Provinces, he met hundreds of lawyers and students who seemed to feel ashamed, of course not ashamed of him but of themselves, because they could not shake off their bondage to those institutions which they knew to be mere shams.
('22', 424, 2, 7, 1031499) He also noticed that by and by they (lawyers and students) also were getting indifferent towards the present system of education and the British law courts.
('22', 424, 2, 8, 1031656) There were hopeful signs that full vairagya 1 would come over the classes, within the next seven months.

('22', 424, 2, 11, 1032072) But he could tell them that it would impede the attainment of swaraj if they did not discard a thing which they knew to be bad.

('22', 426, 6, 10, 1037367) [INTERVIEWER] Why are you against foreign propaganda?
('22', 426, 6, 11, 1037421) [GANDHIJI:] Our movement mainly depends for its success not upon propaganda, but upon internal reform and internal strength.
('22', 426, 6, 12, 1037546) Firstly, if not a soul outside India knew what we are doing, but, if we actually evolved strength, this Government must of necessity fall to pieces.

('22', 426, 6, 15, 1038075) I have, therefore, come to the conclusion that we must rely upon the truth of our movement to propagate itself.

('22', 436, 1, 2, 1059215) 233. THE SATYAGRAHA WEEK
('22', 436, 2, 3, 1059240) April is nearing.
('22', 436, 2, 4, 1059258) Can any Indian forget the inspiring Sunday of 6th April 1 and the terrible one of the 13th?
('22', 436, 2, 5, 1059350) 2 There is no exaggeration in saying that the new life of India commenced on the 6th of April.
('22', 436, 2, 6, 1059445) It is our duty to celebrate the two days.
('22', 436, 2, 7, 1059487) On the 6th, India awoke, shook off her sloth, and the first thing she saw on being fully awake was the fearful atonement forced on her on the evening of the 13th for the misuse of a newly acquired strength.
('22', 436, 2, 8, 1059694) That night India heard Ratan Devi lamenting the death of her husband, his lustreless head resting in her lap.
('22', 436, 2, 9, 1059804) How should we celebrate this week?

('22', 436, 2, 12, 1060147) This week should be spent in pure tapashcharya, pure devotion to God and the purest spirit of renunciation.
('22', 436, 2, 13, 1060255) During this week let us beg forgiveness of God for our offences and of those against whom we may have committed them.
('22', 436, 2, 14, 1060373) In humility lies our strength.
('22', 436, 2, 15, 1060404) Let us not wish ill to the British or others who act in opposition to us; we shall not talk offendingly to them.

('22', 442, 4, 31, 1074730) REMEDIES FOR PLAGUE
('22', 442, 5, 32, 1074750) I told the persons in charge of this hospital that I had experience of three epidemics of the plague, 1 the story of one of them being that I had a hand in eradicating the plague completely and of the other two that, though the epidemic could not be arrested immediately, it could be controlled fairly well.

('22', 442, 6, 35, 1075156) 1 In Rajkot (1896), Johannesburg (1905) and Ahmedabad (1917 18)
('22', 443, 0, 1, 1075220) 444 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 443, 1, 2, 1075262) 1. The victim of the plague should be, if possible, totally segregated and those who nurse him should not come in contact with others.
('22', 443, 1, 3, 1075397) 2. A house in which a case of plague has occurred should be sprinkled with lime and should not be used for at least ten days.
('22', 443, 1, 4, 1075523) 3. If it is full of moisture, ill lighted and ill ventilated, all the three defects should be removed.
('22', 443, 1, 5, 1075626) 4. If it is infested by rats, necessary repairs should be carried out so that they cannot stay on.
('22', 443, 1, 6, 1075725) If these remedies are kept in mind, there is no doubt that the plague will stop spreading.
('22', 443, 1, 7, 1075816) I know it is easy to enumerate these remedies but difficult to adopt them.
('22', 443, 1, 8, 1075891) That is precisely why the plague has made a home in India.
('22', 443, 1, 9, 1075950) But we must adopt as many remedies as possible despite our poverty.
('22', 443, 1, 10, 1076018) The steps to prevent the plague are simple and I wish to set down those I once suggested: 1. We should cultivate the habit of living in properly ventilated and well lighted houses.
('22', 443, 1, 11, 1076199) 2. We should see that our houses are so built as to make it impossible for rats to make their home in them.
('22', 443, 1, 12, 1076307) 3. Faeces should not be allowed to drop on the ground but only into a pot and, whenever the pot is used, a lot of dry earth should be thrown over it, so that all the excreta would be covered up and only the dry earth would be visible.
('22', 443, 1, 13, 1076542) 4. Even urine should drop into a pot.

('22', 448, 8, 23, 1087205) 240. NOTES
('22', 448, 9, 24, 1087216) ‘FOR GOD, KING, AND COUNTRY’
('22', 448, 10, 25, 1087245) During my peregrinations I once came across boys in uniform and asked them what their uniform meant.
('22', 448, 10, 26, 1087346) I observed that their uniform was made of foreign cloth or cloth woven out of foreign yarn.
('22', 448, 10, 27, 1087438) They said it was scouts’ uniform.
('22', 448, 10, 28, 1087472) They whetted my curiosity by
('22', 448, 11, 29, 1087501) 1 Who had shortly before been removed from the editorial staff of Young India; vide “Letter to Lalchand”, January 29, 1921.
('22', 449, 0, 1, 1087625) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 449, 1, 2, 1087667) the answer.
('22', 449, 1, 3, 1087679) I was eager to know what they did as scouts.
('22', 449, 1, 4, 1087724) The answer was that they lived for God, King, and Country.
('22', 449, 1, 5, 1087783) ‘Who is your King?’ I asked.
('22', 449, 1, 6, 1087812) ‘King George,’ was the reply.
('22', 449, 1, 7, 1087842) ‘How about Jallianwala?
('22', 449, 1, 8, 1087866) Supposing you had been in that place on the 13th April 1919 and were asked by General Dyer to shoot your terrified countrymen, what would you have done ?’
('22', 449, 2, 9, 1088021) Of course I would not have obeyed the command.
('22', 449, 2, 10, 1088068) But General Dyer wore the King’s Uniform ?
('22', 449, 3, 11, 1088111) Yes, but he belongs to the bureaucracy and I have nothing to do with it.
('22', 449, 3, 12, 1088184) I suggested that he could not separate the bureaucracy from the King, that the King was an impersonal ideal existence which meant the British Empire and that no Indian could remain loyal, in the accepted sense, to the Empire as it was at present represented and be loyal to God at the same time.
('22', 449, 3, 13, 1088480) An Empire which could be responsible for the terrorism of the Martial Law regime, that would not repent of the wrong, that could enter into secret treaties in breach of solemn obligations, could only be reckoned as a godless Empire.
('22', 449, 3, 14, 1088713) Loyalty to such an Empire was disloyalty to God.
('22', 449, 3, 15, 1088762) The boy was puzzled.
('22', 449, 3, 16, 1088783) I continued my argument: ‘Supposing our country becomes godless in order to enrich itself, exploits other people, trafficks in intoxicants, goes to war for the sake of extending its trade and resorts to fraud in order to sustain its power and prestige, how can we be consistently loyal to God and country?
('22', 449, 3, 17, 1089089) Must we not forsake the country for the sake of God?
('22', 449, 3, 18, 1089142) I suggest, therefore, that you should bind yourself to be faithful and loyal only to God and none else in the same sense and in the same breath.’ There were many of his companions who were deeply interested in the conversation.
('22', 449, 3, 19, 1089370) Their chief too came in.
('22', 449, 3, 20, 1089395) I repeated my argument to him and asked him to tax himself and stimulate the inquiring spirit of the grown up young men whom he was guiding.
('22', 449, 3, 21, 1089536) Hardly was the absorbing topic exhausted, when the train steamed out of the station.
('22', 449, 3, 22, 1089621) I felt sorry for the splendid lads and understood better the deep meaning of the movement of non co operation.
('22', 449, 3, 23, 1089732) There can be but one universal creed for man, that is loyalty to God.
('22', 449, 3, 24, 1089802) It includes, when it is not inconsistent, loyalty to King, country and humanity.
('22', 449, 3, 25, 1089883) But it equally often excludes all else.
('22', 449, 3, 26, 1089923) I hope that the youth of the country as well as their tutors will revise their creed and set themselves right where they
('22', 450, 0, 1, 1090044) VOL. 22 : 23 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 451
('22', 450, 1, 2, 1090090) are convinced of their error.
('22', 450, 1, 3, 1090120) It is no small matter for tender minds to have formulas presented to them which cannot bear scrutiny.
('22', 450, 2, 4, 1090222) SATYAGRAHA, CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE, PASSIVE RESISTANCE, NON CO OPERATION
('22', 450, 3, 5, 1090291) It is often my lot to answer knotty questions on all sorts of topics arising out of this great movement of national purification.
('22', 450, 3, 6, 1090421) A company of collegiate non co operators asked me to define for them the terms which I have used as heading for this note.
('22', 450, 3, 7, 1090544) And even at this late day, I was seriously asked whether satyagraha did not at times warrant resistance by violence, as for instance in the case of a sister whose virtue might be in danger from a desperado.
('22', 450, 3, 8, 1090751) I ventured to suggest that it was the completest defence without irritation, without being ruffled, to interpose oneself between the victim and the victimizer, and to face death.
('22', 450, 3, 9, 1090930) I added that this (for the assailant) novel method of defence would, in all probability, exhaust his passion and he would no longer want to ravish an innocent woman, but would want to flee from her presence for very shame, and that, if he did not, the act of personal bravery on the part of her brother would steel her heart for putting up an equally brave defence and resisting the lust of a man turned brute for the while.
('22', 450, 3, 10, 1091355) And I thought I clinched my argument by saying that if, in spite of all the defence, the unexpected happened, and the physical force of the tyrant overpowered his victim, the disgrace would not be that of the woman but of her assailant and that both she and her brother, who died in the attempt to defend her virtue, would stand well before the Throne of Judgment.
('22', 450, 3, 11, 1091720) I do not warrant that my argument convinced my listener or that it would convince the reader.
('22', 450, 3, 12, 1091814) The world I know will go on as before.
('22', 450, 3, 13, 1091853) But it is well at this moment of self examination to understand and appreciate the implications of the powerful movement of non violence.
('22', 450, 3, 14, 1091991) All religions have emphasized the highest ideal, but all have more or less permitted departures as so many concessions to human weaknesses.
('22', 450, 3, 15, 1092131) I now proceed to summarize the explanations I gave of the various terms.
('22', 450, 3, 16, 1092204) It is beyond my capacity to give accurate and terse definitions.
('22', 450, 3, 17, 1092269) Satyagraha, then, is literally holding on to Truth and it means, therefore, Truth force.
('22', 450, 3, 18, 1092358) Truth is soul or spirit.
('22', 450, 3, 19, 1092383) It is, therefore, known as soul force.
('22', 450, 3, 20, 1092422) It excludes the use of violence because man is not capable of knowing the absolute truth and, therefore, not competent to punish.
('22', 451, 0, 1, 1092552) 452 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 451, 1, 2, 1092594) The word was coined 1 in South Africa to distinguish the non violent resistance of the Indians of South Africa from the contemporary ‘passive resistance’ of the suffragettes and others.
('22', 451, 1, 3, 1092780) It is not conceived as a weapon of the weak.
('22', 451, 1, 4, 1092825) Passive resistance is used in the orthodox English sense and covers the suffragette movement as well as the resistance of the nonconformists.
('22', 451, 1, 5, 1092967) Passive resistance has been conceived and is regarded as a weapon of the weak.
('22', 451, 1, 6, 1093046) Whilst it avoids violence, being not open to the weak, it does not exclude its use if, in the opinion of a passive resister, the occasion demands it.
('22', 451, 1, 7, 1093196) However, it has always been distinguished from armed resistance and its application was at one time confined to Christian martyrs.
('22', 451, 1, 8, 1093327) Civil disobedience is civil breach of unmoral statutory enactments.
('22', 451, 1, 9, 1093395) The expression was, so far as I am aware, coined by Thoreau to signify his own resistance to the laws of a slave state.
('22', 451, 1, 10, 1093515) He has left a masterly treatise 2 on the duty of civil disobedience.
('22', 451, 1, 11, 1093584) But Thoreau was not perhaps an out and out champion of non violence.
('22', 451, 1, 12, 1093653) Probably, also, Thoreau limited his breach of statutory laws to the revenue law, i.e., payment of taxes, whereas the term “civil disobedience” as practised in 1919 covered a breach of any statutory and unmoral law.
('22', 451, 1, 13, 1093868) It signified the resister’s outlawry in a civil, i.e., non violent manner.
('22', 451, 1, 14, 1093943) He invoked the sanctions of the law and cheerfully suffered imprisonment.
('22', 451, 1, 15, 1094017) It is a branch of satyagraha.
('22', 451, 1, 16, 1094047) Non co operation predominantly implies withdrawing of co operation from the state that in the non co operator’s view has become corrupt and excludes civil disobedience of the fierce type described above.
('22', 451, 1, 17, 1094251) By its very nature, non co operation is even open to children of understanding and can be safely practised by the masses.
('22', 451, 1, 18, 1094373) Civil disobedience presupposes the habit of willing obedience to laws without fear of their sanctions.
('22', 451, 1, 19, 1094476) It can therefore be practised only as a last resort and by a select few in the first instance at any rate.
('22', 451, 1, 20, 1094583) Non co operation, too, like civil disobedience is a branch of satyagraha which includes all non violent resistance for the vindication of Truth.
('22', 451, 1, 21, 1094728) Young India, 23 3 1921
('22', 451, 2, 22, 1094751) 1 In 1908; vide “Gujarati equivalents for passive resistance, etc.”, 7 3 1908. 2 For a summary of it by Gandhiji, vide, “Duty of Disobeying Laws”,7 9 1907 & “Duty of Disobeying Laws”, 14 9 1907.

('22', 452, 1, 2, 1094992) 241. SATYAGRAHA WEEK
('22', 452, 2, 3, 1095013) April 6th and 13th will be soon upon us.
('22', 452, 2, 4, 1095054) The 6th 1 saw India one and awakened.
('22', 452, 2, 5, 1095092) The 13th was a black Sunday, when a diabolical attempt was made to crush the spirit of a nation that had just become awakened.
('22', 452, 2, 6, 1095219) India observed the anniversary of the two days last year in a fitting manner, and the whole week commencing from the 6th was treated as a week of consecration.
('22', 452, 2, 7, 1095379) Would that the coming April will find us ready for greater consecration.
('22', 452, 2, 8, 1095452) We have every reason and every occasion for it.
('22', 452, 2, 9, 1095500) Last year we concentrated merely on securing subscriptions for paying the purchase price of the ground hallowed by innocent blood.
('22', 452, 2, 10, 1095631) 2 It was a necessary and pious act.
('22', 452, 2, 11, 1095667) But greater things have happened since then.
('22', 452, 2, 12, 1095712) The nation has affirmed and reaffirmed its determination to redress the Khilafat and the Punjab wrongs and to establish swaraj.
('22', 452, 2, 13, 1095840) The December Congress went further and declared its intention to acquire swaraj within one year.
('22', 452, 2, 14, 1095937) We cannot, then, do better than consecrate ourselves for greater national effort in this direction.
('22', 452, 2, 15, 1096037) The school and the courts movements continue.
('22', 452, 2, 16, 1096083) No special endeavour is now necessary on that score except on the part of those who have left educational institutions or law courts.
('22', 452, 2, 17, 1096217) They must search within and see how they are utilizing their time.
('22', 452, 2, 18, 1096284) But there are six things in which we certainly need to make a very special effort.
('22', 452, 2, 19, 1096367) Firstly, we must acquire greater mastery over ourselves and secure an atmosphere of perfect calm, peace, and goodwill.
('22', 452, 2, 20, 1096486) We must ask forgiveness for every unkind word thoughtlessly uttered or unkind deed done to anyone.
('22', 452, 2, 21, 1096585) Secondly, we must still further cleanse our hearts and we Hindus and Muslims must cease to suspect one another’s motives; and we should believe ourselves to be incapable of wronging one another.
('22', 452, 2, 22, 1096780) Thirdly, we Hindus must call no one unclean or mean or inferior to ourselves, and must therefore cease to regard the ‘pariah’ class to be untouchable.

('22', 454, 2, 3, 1099787) DEAR FRIENDS, I know that you are following with considerable interest the present non co operation movement.

('22', 462, 4, 23, 1120441) THE CONGRESS CONSTITUTION
('22', 462, 5, 24, 1120467) My experiences in the course of my travels over the country have increasingly convinced me that even if, in accordance with the constitution of the Congress, we could but form a committee in every village and in this way establish Congress authority, we would not be far from swaraj.
('22', 462, 5, 25, 1120751) No one will think this a difficult task; if it is considered so, we should give up all talk of attaining swaraj this year.
('22', 462, 5, 26, 1120874) Wherever new life has come into the people and a few leaders have started working honestly, these things are being done.
('22', 462, 5, 27, 1120995) In the district of Jabalpur alone, 50,000 people are said to have enrolled themselves.
('22', 462, 5, 28, 1121082) In some villages, almost 90 per cent of the men and women have got themselves enrolled on the Congress register.
('22', 462, 5, 29, 1121195) Those who saw this done were not lawyers, but two young sons of wealthy zemindars.
('22', 462, 5, 30, 1121278) They have been sacrificing their time and money for the service of the people.
('22', 462, 5, 31, 1121357) In fact, the lawyers, by and large, have kept away from this activity.
('22', 462, 5, 32, 1121428) Where the people still cling to ideas of position and status, look to lawyers and other old workers and do not have the courage to break away from them and go ahead with the work, the movement makes no progress.
('22', 462, 5, 33, 1121640) In Gujarat, 25,000 members of the Congress had
('22', 463, 0, 1, 1121687) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 463, 1, 2, 1121729) been enrolled by February 28. This is in no way an impressive record.
('22', 463, 1, 3, 1121799) Just as by June end we should have collected from all over India a crore of rupees, we should within the same period have enrolled one crore Congress members.
('22', 463, 1, 4, 1121958) That is to say, we have still to collect one and a quarter crores and to make arrangements for enrolling a crore of members and for such other work.
('22', 463, 1, 5, 1122107) The total population of Gujarat is placed at 96 lakhs.
('22', 463, 1, 6, 1122162) At the rate of a crore for 30 crores, we should have enrolled three lakh members by the end of June and the Provincial Committee should have Rs. 75,000 as membership fee from these three lakhs in addition to the contributions to the Tilak Swaraj Fund.
('22', 463, 1, 7, 1122414) The enrolment of members will be of some advantage only if the work is properly organized.
('22', 463, 1, 8, 1122505) We should have on our record the full name, occupation, address and age of every member.
('22', 463, 1, 9, 1122594) He should have a general idea of the Congress constitution and should also be familiar with the main principles of non co operation.
('22', 463, 1, 10, 1122727) A worker should be specially appointed to supervise this work and he should watch all the time how it is progressing at each place.
('22', 463, 1, 11, 1122859) Detailed and authentic information should be published every week on behalf of every district.
('22', 463, 1, 12, 1122954) To attend to this, some persons will have to give all their 24 hours to swaraj work.
('22', 463, 1, 13, 1123039) Not only that, they should use intelligence and judgment, and be truthful, in all that they do.

('22', 463, 1, 17, 1123389) Nevertheless, it is necessary for us to learn to attend to the minutest detail.
('22', 463, 1, 18, 1123469) There is a saying in English, “Take care of the pence and the pound will take care of itself.” Drop by drop fills the lake.
('22', 463, 1, 19, 1123593) SPINNING WHEEL AND KHADI I saw in Jubbalpore those [two] young zemindars do this work; they have not been doing only this work but have also taken up energetically the work of swadeshi.
('22', 463, 1, 20, 1123779) They are introducing the spinning wheel in village after village.
('22', 463, 1, 21, 1123845) They have bought a stock of cotton, got it made into slivers and distributed these among the people.
('22', 463, 1, 22, 1123946) Where six months ago not a single spinning wheel was being plied, hundreds are now working and khadi is being produced.
('22', 463, 1, 23, 1124066) Both the cousins wear khadi and, for the required yarn, they themselves spin daily.
('22', 463, 1, 24, 1124150) PROHIBITION Prohibition work has been going on in full swing.
('22', 463, 1, 25, 1124212) In some places, there was no applicant for a liquor licence.
('22', 463, 1, 26, 1124273) If we can show courage and see that consumption of liquor is stopped, we can retain

('22', 464, 1, 2, 1124403) 17 crores of rupees in the homes of the poor in India.
('22', 464, 1, 3, 1124458) The Government has at present an annual income of Rs. 17 crores and this comes from our own homes.
('22', 464, 2, 4, 1124557) APPEAL TO WOMEN
('22', 464, 3, 5, 1124573) If the women of Gujarat undertake this sacred work, we shall succeed before June in rooting out this evil of drink from Gujarat at any rate.
('22', 464, 3, 6, 1124714) They should go to the liquor booths in every district and appeal first to their owners and, if they do not oblige, to thecustomers.

('22', 464, 3, 10, 1125221) Our sisters should bear a few abuses for the sake of Bharatvarsha 1. If women in any town give the lead, I am sure women elsewhere will take up the work.
('22', 464, 4, 11, 1125375) BUT WHAT ABOUT EDUCATION ?

('22', 465, 0, 1, 1126679) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 465, 1, 2, 1126721) RESOURCES FOR EDUCATION
('22', 465, 2, 3, 1126745) Under swaraj, the resources for education cannot come either from liquor [revenues] or from land revenues.
('22', 465, 2, 4, 1126852) The beautiful spinning wheel is the right source.
('22', 465, 2, 5, 1126902) If the spinning wheel and the loom are introduced in every school, our education will never be a burden to us.
('22', 465, 2, 6, 1127013) Today, of course, we should expect children to give all their time to the spinning wheel, but even after independence, they should give at least an hour daily to it.
('22', 465, 2, 7, 1127179) Swaraj will be swaraj only if its effect is felt in every department of life.
('22', 465, 2, 8, 1127257) Today education is intended only to train slaves—to produce servants.
('22', 465, 2, 9, 1127327) Education under swaraj should aim at making the pupils self reliant right from their early years.
('22', 465, 2, 10, 1127425) Hence we would necessarily teach them spinning and weaving.
('22', 465, 2, 11, 1127485) If desired, they may also be taught some other trade or profession besides this, but spinning and weaving should be made compulsory.
('22', 465, 2, 12, 1127618) The spinning wheel should become the “refuge of the hapless and support of the poor”.
('22', 465, 2, 13, 1127704) No other profession can serve our needs as well as this, for it is the only work which can be made universally available and an alternative or a supplementary employment to agriculture.
('22', 465, 2, 14, 1127890) All cannot be carpenters or blacksmiths, but all should know spinning and should spin a little for the sake of the nation or for supplementing their income.
('22', 465, 2, 15, 1128047) All need food and clothing and that is the reason why the spinning wheel can be adopted as a universal employment.
('22', 465, 2, 16, 1128162) Our national education should be planned on the lines above suggested, right from today.
('22', 465, 2, 17, 1128251) Otherwise this will be the cause of the very first conflict among us under swaraj.
('22', 465, 2, 18, 1128334) It may be argued by some that there should be no teaching of crafts as part of education.
('22', 465, 2, 19, 1128424) Let us make the learning of a craft a part of education right from now on in order that public opinion be sufficiently moulded to leave no room for argument at a later stage.
('22', 465, 3, 20, 1128599) BEGINNING OF THE ERA OF ACTION
('22', 465, 4, 21, 1128630) I have been observing everywhere that the era of talking is over.
('22', 465, 4, 22, 1128696) We still love to hear speeches and speakers love to speak but, all the same, the people have realized that what is required now is action, that swaraj cannot be won by talking.
('22', 465, 4, 23, 1128873) If those who are eager for action do not take advantage of this age of action, they will miss the opportunity which has offered itself.

('22', 465, 4, 28, 1129326) Is it necessary now to probe what kind of a Government this is?

('22', 467, 3, 6, 1132163) You must not get ill so often.

('22', 469, 1, 3, 1136212) 1 He asserted that the masses were untouched by this problem.

('22', 469, 1, 6, 1136515) He was aware of the difficulties that faced him in obtaining swaraj but considered that in the few months of probation we were now undergoing, we should have thrown away the want of faith in ourselves.

('22', 477, 2, 8, 1157945) 257. SPEECH ON FIRST RESOLUTION AT A.I.C.C. MEETING 1
('22', 477, 3, 9, 1157999) BEZWADA, March 31, 1921
('22', 477, 4, 10, 1158023) Mr. Gandhi in proposing the first resolution for adoption made a lucid and clear statement of the present situation.
('22', 477, 4, 11, 1158140) He pointed out that in respect of those aspects of propaganda upon which they had so far concentrated, namely, giving up of titles, Councils, educational institutions and courts, there was no need for further concentration as the success already achieved therein was in every way satisfactory.
('22', 477, 4, 12, 1158434) Whatever be the number of students who had given up college or of lawyers who had given up practice, the Congress had achieved the real object of propaganda, namely, the demolition of prestige of these institutions of the bureauctatic Government of this country.
('22', 477, 4, 13, 1158697) Most of those who yet continued in schools or in courts were fully convinced of the principle for which the Congress had fought although for a variety of reasons they were not able to give effect to the resolutions immediately.
('22', 477, 4, 14, 1158925) The Congress might therefore well trust to time for the movement to work its way fully.
('22', 477, 4, 15, 1159013) He therefore pointed out that in order to achieve the programme of swaraj within the time 2 mentioned in the Nagpur Congress resolution, they should now concentrate upon those parts of it which would directly lead the masses of this country to its realization.
('22', 477, 5, 16, 1159274) The awakening of the masses was phenomenal and while the masses were fully alive to the urgent need of realization of swaraj the leaders were lagging behind.
('22', 477, 5, 17, 1159432) It was therefore necessary to give form and shape to the aspirations of the masses.
('22', 477, 5, 18, 1159516) Their aspirations for swaraj were based upon the very definite perception that without swaraj their condition could not improve and the direct means of improving their condition was to enable them to clothe and feed themselves.
('22', 477, 5, 19, 1159744) It was for this purpose that he felt the charkha movement was full of the utmost potentialities in the winning
('22', 477, 6, 20, 1159855) 1At this meeting of the All India Congress Committee Gandhiji moved four resolutions which were adopted; for their text, vide “Resolutions at A.I.C.C. Meeting, Bezwada”, March 31, 1921. 2 The time limit of one year mentioned in the resolution on non co operation adopted by the Congress at Nagpur in December 1920
('22', 478, 0, 1, 1160169) VOL. 22 : 23 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 479
('22', 478, 1, 2, 1160215) of swaraj.
('22', 478, 1, 3, 1160226) If the masses were enabled to perceive that situation and to realize it by receiving their economic independence through the use of the spinning wheel in their houses so as to obtain the maximum of production and wherewithal to feed and clothe themselves, it would immediately have the effect of making them feel that they were no longer dependent on foreigners for their livelihood and progress.
('22', 478, 1, 4, 1160623) It would also effect a complete economic boycott of the most important of foreign imports of this country.
('22', 478, 1, 5, 1160730) If this was achieved swaraj could be considered to have been realized.
('22', 478, 1, 6, 1160801) That was why he desired that the charkha movement should be encouraged.
('22', 478, 2, 7, 1160873) In order that the propaganda might succeed, workers were needed.
('22', 478, 2, 8, 1160938) Congress organizations should be thoroughly put into operation.
('22', 478, 2, 9, 1161002) If, as the resolution insisted, one crore of rupees were collected before the 30th June, as he was quite hopeful it would be, and one crore of manhood and womanhood of the country were registered as Congressmen, there could be no more patent proof of the fitness of the people for swaraj than of their ability to achieve it through the Congress orgnaization itself.

('22', 478, 3, 11, 1161388) 258. SPEECH ON SECOND RESOLUTION AT A.I.C.C. MEETING 1
('22', 478, 4, 12, 1161443) BEZWADA, March 31, 1921
('22', 478, 5, 13, 1161467) Mr. Gandhi pointed out that in deference to the ruling of the chair that civil disobedience as such was not recommended in express terms by the Nagpur Congress and was not within the four corners of the resolution on non co operation, he proposed that the A.I.C.C. in this matter should only express its opinion on the matter in the form of advice, in order that the country might have a lead from the Committee.
('22', 478, 5, 14, 1161880) The question of civil disobedience had been raised in several quarters in consequence of the action of the Government against non co operators.
('22', 478, 5, 15, 1162024) He referred at length to the entirely unjustifiable character of several proceedings taken by the authorities in several province and he pointed out how wonderfully the people had conformed to non violence even under grave provocation.
('22', 478, 5, 16, 1162260) Nevertheless, he felt that the Committee should not recommend civil disobedience suggested in the form which was understood by those who advocated it.
('22', 478, 5, 17, 1162411) Though it was true that non payment of tax was one form of civil disobedience contemplated by the Congress resolutions, yet it was not initiated as part of a programme of civil disobedience against the Government in respect of particular laws or orders, lawful or otherwise.
('22', 478, 5, 18, 1162686) The scheme of civil disobedience which he had practised in South Africa and developed in his own mind was one which could not yet be put into operation.
('22', 478, 5, 19, 1162839) If the country was organized and restrained so thoroughly as he desired it would then be time to put it into operation.
('22', 478, 5, 20, 1162959) As it was he considered that notwithstanding the great progress of non violence among the people, there was still an element of what he would, for want of a better term, call mob law, not in the wrong sense but in the idea that the
('22', 478, 6, 21, 1163191) 1 For the text of the resolution vide the following item.
('22', 479, 0, 1, 1163249) 480 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 479, 1, 2, 1163291) people had not yet so thoroughly disciplined themselves to the restraint that was needed when their dearest wishes were violated or when their great leaders were snatched away to prison under most provocative circumstances.
('22', 479, 1, 3, 1163515) Until, therefore, they were able to exercise self control perfectly, they should not initiate civil disobedience.
('22', 479, 1, 4, 1163629) Of course, he was glad to note that the people were in a fair way to it.
('22', 479, 1, 5, 1163702) If any person took upon himself the responsibility of offering civil disobedience to particular orders or laws, which he conscientiously thought he could not obey, as for example in the case of Mr. Yakub Hassan, 1 he was at liberty to do so.
('22', 479, 1, 6, 1163944) But he might do so only on his own responsibility and not in the name of the Congress.

('22', 479, 2, 8, 1164051) 259. RESOLUTIONS AT A.I.C.C. MEETING, BEZWADA 2
('22', 479, 3, 9, 1164099) March 31, 1921
('22', 479, 4, 10, 1164114) RESOLUTION I
('22', 479, 5, 11, 1164127) In the opinion of the A.I.C.C. all Congress organizations and workers should concentrate their attention chiefly upon: (a) bringing the All India Tilak Memorial Swaraj Fund to one crore of rupees and before 30th June next each Congress province to collect in the ratio of its population.
('22', 479, 5, 12, 1164415) (b) putting in Congress registers one crore of members in pursuance of the Constitution and before 30th June next each province to contribute the number of members in the ratio of its population.
('22', 479, 5, 13, 1164611) (c) introducing into villages and houses 20 lakhs of charkhas (spinning wheels) in good working order before 30th June next, each province to introduce the number of charkhas in the ratio of its population.
('22', 479, 6, 14, 1164818) RESOLUTION II
('22', 479, 7, 15, 1164832) (a) The All India Congress Committee is of opinion that the orders of the officials in various provinces against non co operators in pursuit of the policy of repression are totally unwarranted by the situation in the country and are in most cases pronounced by the highest legal opinion to be illegal.
('22', 479, 7, 16, 1165134) (b) The Committee believes that the country has responded in a wonderful manner and in the face of grave provocation by
('22', 479, 8, 17, 1165254) 1Vide “Speech at Gujranwala”, February 19, 1921. 2 These four resolutions moved by Gandhiji were presumably drafted by him.
('22', 480, 0, 1, 1165378) VOL. 22 : 23 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 481
('22', 480, 1, 2, 1165424) Government to the principle of non violence enjoined by Congress in the country’s pursuit after swaraj and redress of Khilafat and Punjab wrongs.
('22', 480, 1, 3, 1165570) (c) This Committee is of opinion that apart from the fact that civil disobedience is not expressly comprised in the Congress resolution relating to non co operation, the country is not yet disciplined, organized and ripe for the immediate taking up of civil disobedience.
('22', 480, 1, 4, 1165842) (d) This Committee by way of preparation, therefore, advises all those upon whom orders may be served to conform to them and trusts that new workers will take the place of those who may be disabled by the Government and that the people at large instead of becoming disheartened or frightened by such orders, will continue their work of quest, organization and construction sketched by the Congress resolution.
('22', 480, 2, 5, 1166252) RESOLUTION III

('22', 481, 4, 7, 1167740) Mahatma Gandhi in urging the proposition observed that though the enforcing of such a resolution 2 might be difficult and unpleasant, it was a duty that had to be faced and overcome by those who had to bring into being the new constitution.

('22', 483, 5, 7, 1171526) You will also forgive me for I have not been able to bring my brother Maulana Shaukat Ali with me.

('22', 483, 5, 9, 1171819) It has not been possible recently to travel together.

('22', 483, 5, 15, 1172589) I claim to be a staunch sanatani Hindu.

('22', 499, 1, 6, 1210821) It was decided to proceed thence in a bullock cart.
('22', 499, 1, 7, 1210873) The journey commenced at 1 a.m.
('22', 499, 1, 8, 1210905) I was tired and felt sleepy too.
('22', 499, 1, 9, 1210938) Why should I bother to see what manner of bullocks they were and who the driver was?

('22', 499, 1, 11, 1211114) At times, they would move slowly, but mostly they kept running.Who does not like to see bullocks running?

('22', 499, 1, 22, 1212072) I put up with it for about two minutes.

('22', 501, 3, 23, 1217897) Untouchability is a subject which raises all manner of doubts in the minds of different people.

('22', 502, 1, 4, 1218381) A friend has suggested that I should answer the following three questions: 1. The very profession of Bhangis and Chamars is dirty.
('22', 502, 1, 5, 1218512) Whoever follows this profession gets so subtly affected by it that even if he should clean himself regularly by bathing, he becomes unclean to his very bones.
('22', 502, 1, 6, 1218671) Hence physical contact with him should be totally avoided.
('22', 502, 1, 7, 1218730) 2. Though doctors and others are engaged in unclean work, the Bhangi’s work is not unclean in the same sense.

('22', 502, 1, 9, 1218955) 3. So long as the Dheds and Bhangis have not given up their work altogether, they simply ought not to be touched.
