('22', 504, 2, 4, 1223983) 273. MY NOTES
('22', 504, 3, 5, 1223997) WHITE MARRED BY BLACK SPOT
('22', 504, 4, 6, 1224024) A friend, quoting instances of several people who, taking advantage of the swadeshi movement, are practising dishonesty, writes:
('22', 504, 5, 7, 1224153) I for one desire honesty in the country first and then propaganda for swadeshi.
('22', 504, 5, 8, 1224233) The idea springs from sincerity but is one sided.
('22', 504, 5, 9, 1224283) I have learnt from Jain philosophy a great many things which were worth learning, one of them being the idea of the many sidedness of truth.
('22', 504, 5, 10, 1224424) Stated in an extreme form, nothing is true.
('22', 504, 5, 11, 1224468) There are two sides to every question.
('22', 504, 5, 12, 1224507) In the assertion “I for one desire honesty first” is an extreme position.
('22', 504, 5, 13, 1224581) Honesty is, indeed, desirable, now and always.
('22', 504, 5, 14, 1224628) If we say, however, that the propaganda for swadeshi should be postponed until such time as we learn honesty, we may have to lose both honesty and swadeshi.
('22', 504, 5, 15, 1224785) Truth and such other virtues do not of themselves develop in one.
('22', 504, 5, 16, 1224851) They develop as one acts.
('22', 504, 5, 17, 1224877) Our rulers have withheld the grant of swaraj to this day by saying that India can have self rule when it becomes fit for it and we have allowed them to do so.
('22', 504, 5, 18, 1225036) India is already fit.
('22', 504, 5, 19, 1225058) If the country had been perfect, it would never have been enslaved.
('22', 504, 5, 20, 1225126) But the fitness for swaraj develops as we enjoy swaraj.
('22', 504, 5, 21, 1225182) In the same way, honesty will come through the practice of swadeshi.
('22', 504, 5, 22, 1225251) The idea that swadeshi cannot flourish without honesty is perfectly true and does not contradict the principle of the many sidedness of truth.
('22', 504, 5, 23, 1225394) By holding that view, we can progress in both things simultaneously.
('22', 504, 5, 24, 1225463) A firm faith that nothing can succeed without honesty helps to develop that quality and we shall then feel no misgivings in conducting any beneficial activity.
('22', 504, 5, 25, 1225623) It is my view that, if we had not abandoned swadeshi through infatuation [for foreign articles] we would have been saved from our present plight and the dishonesty which has crept in among us.
('22', 504, 5, 26, 1225816) I am convinced that the spread of swadeshi means the spread of truth, of the idea of devotion to one’s own dharma and of that of swaraj.
('22', 504, 5, 27, 1225953) It is, therefore, my advice to believers in swadeshi, not to be disheartened by the inertia prevailing in the country but to go on spreading swadeshi.
('22', 504, 5, 28, 1226104) We give an object lesson in truth by propagating swadeshi, introducing the spinning wheel, by wearing khadi ourselves and inducing others to do so.
('22', 505, 0, 1, 1226252) 506 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 505, 1, 2, 1226294) DISHONESTY
('22', 505, 2, 3, 1226305) The instances that this friend cites are about the sale of khadi and the fraud concerning spinning wheels.
('22', 505, 2, 4, 1226412) He says that khadi sellers either palm off khadi made from mill spun yarn as handspun khadi, or make big profits on genuine khadi.
('22', 505, 2, 5, 1226543) Those who sell spinning wheels charge high prices, regardless of quality.
('22', 505, 2, 6, 1226617) I, too, have been noticing both these malpractices.
('22', 505, 2, 7, 1226669) Every movement has its crooks.
('22', 505, 2, 8, 1226700) The test of the efficiency of the organizers of the new movement lies in their ability to defeat the tricks of swindlers, and the success of the movement depends upon their possessing it.
('22', 505, 2, 9, 1226888) Charging higher prices for khadi will not be possible for long, because, when its production goes up, the sellers will compete with one another and reduce the prices.
('22', 505, 2, 10, 1227055) It is difficult to counteract the sale of spurious khadi.
('22', 505, 2, 11, 1227113) I have been trying to arrange for the testing of pure khadi and to discover the means of doing so.
('22', 505, 2, 12, 1227212) It is difficult to find testers immediately because it is not very easy to detect hand spun yarn once it has been woven [into cloth].
('22', 505, 2, 13, 1227346) Meanwhile, all should decide to buy khadi from a place they can rely upon.
('22', 505, 2, 14, 1227421) If even then one is cheated, the sin will be upon the person who cheats, never on the person who gets cheated.
('22', 505, 2, 15, 1227532) Despite such deception, the love of khadi will grow, its dread will disappear [and] khadi will come to be regarded as civilized dress— the country will have this benefit at any rate.
('22', 505, 3, 16, 1227715) TESTING OF SPINNING WHEELS
('22', 505, 4, 17, 1227742) There is, indeed, danger in the sale of bad spinning wheels; the spinning wheels sold are such that one cannot spin well on them or their output is extremely low or they break down soon, and there is every likelihood of people coming to feel disgust for the spinning wheel as such.
('22', 505, 4, 18, 1228024) But it is my hope that a remedy for this will soon be found.
('22', 505, 4, 19, 1228085) Experiments on the spinning wheel are going on.
('22', 505, 4, 20, 1228133) As the number of those who can judge a spinning wheel grows, the sale of bad spinning wheels will cease.
('22', 505, 4, 21, 1228238) In Bombay they have a standard “balance of honesty” for testing gold.
('22', 505, 4, 22, 1228308) I have been thinking if it is not possible to devise a similar means for testing a spinning wheel.
('22', 505, 4, 23, 1228407) It is only in this way that the use of any good thing spreads.
('22', 505, 4, 24, 1228470) I hope we shall soon be able to judge a good spinning wheel, just as we can a typewriter, a sewing machine, etc.
('22', 505, 4, 25, 1228583) The people’s faith in the spinning wheel has been growing so much that I believe we shall soon see good, strong and cheap spinning wheels in the country’s markets.
('22', 505, 4, 26, 1228747) Meanwhile, it will be good if, at every place where the spinning wheel movement is going on, the organizers themselves learn to distinguish between good and bad spinning wheels.
('22', 505, 4, 27, 1228925) I shall set down here just this little test:
('22', 506, 0, 1, 1228970) VOL. 22 : 23 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 507
('22', 506, 1, 2, 1229016) 1. The wheel of the spinning wheel must turn noiselessly and without stopping.
('22', 506, 1, 3, 1229095) 2. Every part of the spinning wheel must be well set.
('22', 506, 1, 4, 1229149) 3. The handle of the wheel should be so fixed that it does not slide.
('22', 506, 1, 5, 1229219) 4. The spindle of the spinning wheel must rotate without noise.
('22', 506, 1, 6, 1229283) For this, the spindle holders should have been made of straw or leather.
('22', 506, 1, 7, 1229356) 5. good spinner should be able to turn out from the spinning wheel at least two and a half tolas of yarn in an hour.
('22', 506, 1, 8, 1229473) No spinning wheel should be approved which does not satisfy the last test, i.e., which could not be worked for one hour with this result.
('22', 506, 1, 9, 1229611) CARPENTER VOLUNTEERS It has become a fixed practice among us to enrol only students as volunteers.
('22', 506, 1, 10, 1229710) I have said before now that it is necessary, instead, to start the practice of enlisting all good young men in volunteer bodies.
('22', 506, 1, 11, 1229839) If we really want to conduct our national activities on a large scale, we should engage many artisans also in such work.
('22', 506, 1, 12, 1229960) When carpenters, blacksmiths and others begin to work for the national good, we shall also succeed in producing cheap and good spinning wheels.
('22', 506, 1, 13, 1230104) Our condition today is so pitiful that, if we are ready to spin, we do not get carpenters who will make good spinning wheels in a short time.
('22', 506, 1, 14, 1230246) If we find such carpenters, we do not get blacksmiths to make spindles.
('22', 506, 1, 15, 1230318) If we find blacksmiths and carpenters, we do not get honest and patriotic carders.
('22', 506, 1, 16, 1230401) If, however, we have with us organizations of carpenters, blacksmiths, carders, and others, all working for swaraj, we can help the people to rise to a great height.
('22', 506, 1, 17, 1230567) A letter from a carpenter friend shows how easy it is to do this.
('22', 506, 1, 18, 1230633) He writes: What you have written in your article 1 about the construction of the Swaminarayan temple by free labour is correct.
('22', 506, 1, 19, 1230761) The artisans needed for building the temple of swaraj should be supplied by us from among ourselves.
('22', 506, 1, 20, 1230862) We shall estimate the number required for this purpose or for building big schools and have a meeting of the community to distribute the work among ourselves.
('22', 506, 1, 21, 1231021) We shall fix monthly turns and help in the name of the country without asking for wages.
('22', 506, 1, 22, 1231110) There must be in the country many others like the carpenter who has written this and, if we but try, we can easily engage them in national work, and associations of artisans who will build the temple of swaraj will spring up everywhere.
('22', 506, 1, 23, 1231347) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 5 4 1921

('22', 507, 1, 2, 1231472) 274. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, MASULIPATAM
('22', 507, 2, 3, 1231515) April 5, 1921
('22', 507, 3, 4, 1231529) HINDU AND MOHAMMEDAN BRETHREN AND SISTERS, I thank the Municipality for the address given to me and the sentiments expressed therein.
('22', 507, 3, 5, 1231663) For me it is a matter of great pleasure and joy that I have been able to fulfil the promise I made to myself and to some friends that I would visit Andhra Jatheeya Kalasala 1, Masulipatam, at the earliest possible opportunity.
('22', 507, 3, 6, 1231890) Although I have previously passed through Bezwada twice, for some reason or other I was unable then to visit Masulipatam.
('22', 507, 3, 7, 1232012) And my joy is therefore all the greater that my hope of visiting it was deferred and realized at this late period.
('22', 507, 3, 8, 1232127) I call it late, because when I first had the idea of visiting the national institution in Masulipatam, non co operation was not born.
('22', 507, 3, 9, 1232261) I have now passed two quiet, and what shall always remain with me, sacred days on the sacred grounds of this great educational institution.
('22', 507, 3, 10, 1232401) And I am here to inform you that the expectations that I had formed of this institution have been more than realized after the observations that I was able to make of it during these two privileged days.
('22', 507, 3, 11, 1232605) I see method, organizing ability, and sacrifice written in every inch of that ground.
('22', 507, 3, 12, 1232691) As an Indian I feel proud of it.
('22', 507, 3, 13, 1232724) As the inhabitants of this great Andhra province, I hope that all the Andhra friends are equally proud of it, and I hope that you, the citizens of Masulipatam, consider it a privilege that you have an institution in your midst which is manned by men who are filled with the spirit of sacrifice.
('22', 507, 3, 14, 1233019) I do not hastily bestow praise upon any institution.
('22', 507, 3, 15, 1233072) But I would have been false to myself and I would have been false to you, if I did not convey to you the sentiments that have been fired within me during these two days.
('22', 507, 3, 16, 1233242) I ask you therefore to make that institution your own.
('22', 507, 3, 17, 1233297) Strengthen where you may find it to be weak.
('22', 507, 3, 18, 1233342) Strengthen it further where you find that there is a strength in it.
('22', 507, 3, 19, 1233411) Look up to it as an ideal, and try to perfect it in order to perfect your own ideals.
('22', 507, 3, 20, 1233497) I was surprised and pained to find that although you have two big educational institutions in your midst not one of them had supported this great institution.
('22', 507, 3, 21, 1233656) I had hoped that as the result of non co operation the students of Masulipatam High School and College were tired and disgusted as the students all over India have felt tired and disgusted with the institutions dominated by the spirit of this Government.
('22', 507, 3, 22, 1233911) I had hoped that such students at least would have gone to this institution.
('22', 507, 3, 23, 1233988) In other places I have been asked by the student world where they were to go, as there were no national institutions in existence.
('22', 507, 3, 24, 1234119) The student world of Masulipatam have absolutely no such
('22', 507, 4, 25, 1234176) 1Andhra National College
('22', 508, 0, 1, 1234201) VOL. 22 : 23 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 509
('22', 508, 1, 2, 1234247) excuse in view of the fact that this institution has been in their midst for the last nearly fifteen years.
('22', 508, 1, 3, 1234355) If you are brave boys you would take my advice.
('22', 508, 1, 4, 1234403) You should go to this school, and as scholars in this institution, if you find that there is anything that does not satisfy your head or your heart, you should insist upon the teaching staff to correct those defects.
('22', 508, 1, 5, 1234620) We are entering tomorrow upon the sacred National Week.
('22', 508, 1, 6, 1234676) The sixth of April, 1919, witnessed India awakened.
('22', 508, 1, 7, 1234728) The sixth of April, 1919, witnessed an awakened India when her Hindu and Mussulman peoples showed a real desire to be united.
('22', 508, 1, 8, 1234854) True swadeshi spirit was also born on that day.
('22', 508, 1, 9, 1234902) The 13th of April, seven days after that great awakening, witnessed a black Sunday.
('22', 508, 1, 10, 1234986) Nearly 1,500 innocent men were butchered at Jallianwala Bagh.
('22', 508, 1, 11, 1235048) The dying were neglected by the butchers and I want the students, I want the pleaders and I want all the sisters who are surrounding me to imagine in their minds the pictureof that one solitary figure of a brave and noble woman, Ratan Devi, weeping over the corpse of her dead husband and fearlessly and in defiance of the order of General Dyer taking in her lap the head, the cold head, of her dear husband.
('22', 508, 1, 12, 1235457) Ratan Devi was your sister and mine.
('22', 508, 1, 13, 1235494) I ask you to imagine what you would have felt if you had been in Ratan Devi’s place in that desolate field of Jallianwala Bagh.
('22', 508, 1, 14, 1235622) I do not want you to become irritated against Englishmen.
('22', 508, 1, 15, 1235680) But I want you to turn your searchlight inward.
('22', 508, 1, 16, 1235728) We observed the sacred week by commencing with fasting, prayer and hartal and we closed the week likewise.
('22', 508, 1, 17, 1235835) I hope that you, the citizens of Masulipatam, will tomorrow fast, pray and observe hartal.
('22', 508, 1, 18, 1235926) Fasting is an age old institution.
('22', 508, 1, 19, 1235961) We fast when we do not feel pure, we fast as a penance for our past sins, and pray to God for making us strong.
('22', 508, 1, 20, 1236073) We pray to God for forgiveness of our sins, and after prayer we turn over a new leaf.
('22', 508, 1, 21, 1236159) I hope therefore that every one of you who has come here will not forget these two necessary ceremonies.
('22', 508, 1, 22, 1236264) I treat the hartal also as a religious observance for tomorrow and tomorrow week.
('22', 508, 1, 23, 1236346) It is not to be deemed as expressing a political demonstration, but it should be interpreted as expression of India’s determination to find herself.
('22', 508, 1, 24, 1236495) I would ask you tomorrow and during the whole week to dispel every thought of ill will and malice against any member of this Government, whether he be English or Indian.
('22', 508, 1, 25, 1236665) The fear with which we are filled is the first sin.
('22', 508, 1, 26, 1236717) We fear Englishmen, we fear the Japanese, we fear every other man but God.
('22', 508, 1, 27, 1236792) And believe me, it is only a man who has no faith in God and who has
('22', 509, 0, 1, 1236861) 510 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 509, 1, 2, 1236903) no faith in himself, only such a man fears his fellow beings.
('22', 509, 1, 3, 1236965) The second great sin that we committed against India, against humanity and against God was the destruction of the spinning wheel.
('22', 509, 1, 4, 1237095) I wish I could convince the whole of India that it was due to this great sin of ours, national sin as I call it, that India became degraded and a slave nation.
('22', 509, 1, 5, 1237255) The least expiation we can do is to banish every inch of foreign cloth from our midst, and therefore I ask you men and women of Masulipatam from tomorrow to make up a fixed determination not to wear foreign cloth any more, but to wear only that cloth which is woven and spun by yourselves and not by others.
('22', 509, 1, 6, 1237563) Another sin that we have committed is selfishness.
('22', 509, 1, 7, 1237614) We have thought not of the nation but ourselves, and when we have gone beyond the family we have not been able to progress beyond the city or village.
('22', 509, 1, 8, 1237765) And the least expiation we can do is to cease to live for ourselves only, begin to live for India.
('22', 509, 1, 9, 1237864) The rupture between Hindus and Mohamemdans is another of our sins.
('22', 509, 1, 10, 1237931) We have extended our horizon from the Himalayas to Rameswar, from Bengal to Sind.
('22', 509, 1, 11, 1238013) Hindu Muslim unity is an established fact.
('22', 509, 1, 12, 1238056) Therefore there remains the spinning wheel for us to concentrate upon.
('22', 509, 1, 13, 1238127) I would ask you further to think of the things that the All India Congress Committee has commended to our attention, to find a crore of rupees for the Tilak Swaraj Fund.
('22', 509, 1, 14, 1238297) The Andhra Desh proportion comes to 7_ lakhs of rupees.
('22', 509, 1, 15, 1238353) I hope that men and women of Masulipatam will give their best to this Fund.
('22', 509, 1, 16, 1238429) Presently volunteers will go over to you.
('22', 509, 1, 17, 1238471) Several sisters of Masulipatam have been to me already and given their ornaments and money.
('22', 509, 1, 18, 1238563) I hope that the response from Masulipatam will be no less than elsewhere.
('22', 509, 2, 19, 1238637) The Hindu, 8 4 1921
('22', 510, 0, 1, 1238657) VOL. 22 : 23 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 511
('22', 510, 1, 2, 1238703) APPENDICES
('22', 510, 2, 3, 1238714) APPENDIX I
('22', 510, 3, 4, 1238725) CONGRESS RESOLUTION ON NON CO OPERATI0N 1
('22', 510, 4, 5, 1238767) Whereas in the opinion of the Congress the existing Government of India has forfeited the confidence of the country; and
('22', 510, 5, 6, 1238888) Whereas the people of India are now determined to establish swaraj; and
('22', 510, 6, 7, 1238960) Whereas all methods adopted by the people of India prior to the last Special Session of the Indian National Congress have failed to secure due recognition of their rights and liberties and the redress of their many and grievous wrongs, more specially with reference to the Khilafat and the Punjab;
('22', 510, 7, 8, 1239258) Now this Congress while reaffirming the resolution on non violent non co operation passed at the Special Session of the Congress at Calcutta declares that the entire or any part or parts of the scheme of non violent non co operation, with the renunciation of voluntary association with the present Government at one end and the refusal to pay taxes at the other, should be put in force at a time to be determined by either the Indian National Congress or the All India Congress Committee and that in the meanwhile, to prepare the country for it, effective steps should continue to be taken in that behalf:
('22', 510, 8, 9, 1239864) (a) by calling upon the parents and guardians of schoolchildren (and not the children themselves) under the age of 16 years to make greater efforts for the purpose of withdrawing them from such schools as are owned, aided or in any way controlled by Government and concurrently to provide for their training in national schools or by such other means as may be within their power in the absence of such schools;
('22', 510, 9, 10, 1240276) (b) by calling upon students of the age of 16 and over to withdraw without delay, irrespective of consequences, from institutions owned, aided or in any way controlled by Government, if they feel that it is against their conscience to continue in institutions which are dominated by a system of government which the nation has solemnly resolved to bring to an end, and advising such students either to devote themselves to some special service in connection with the non co operation movement or to continue their education in national institutions;
('22', 510, 10, 11, 1240826) (c) by calling upon trustees, managers and teachers of Government affiliated or aided schools and municipalities and local boards to help to nationalize them;
('22', 510, 11, 12, 1240985) 1 Passed at the Nagpur session on December 30, 1920
('22', 511, 0, 1, 1241037) 512 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 511, 1, 2, 1241079) (d) by calling upon lawyers to make greater efforts to suspend their practice and to devote their attention to national service including boycott of law courts by litigants and fellow lawyers and the settlement of disputes by private arbitration;
('22', 511, 2, 3, 1241326) (e) in order to make India economically independent and self contained by calling upon merchants and traders to carry out a gradual boycott of foreign trade relations, to encourage hand spinning and hand weaving and in that behalf by having a scheme of economic boycott planned and formulated by a committee of experts to be nominated by the All India Congress Committee;
('22', 511, 3, 4, 1241698) (f) and generally, inasmuch as self sacrifice is essential to the success of non co operation, by calling upon every section and every man and woman in the country to make the utmost possible contribution of self sacrifice to the national movement;
('22', 511, 4, 5, 1241947) (g) by organizing Committees in each village or group of villages with a provincial central organization in the principal cities of each Province for the purpose of accelerating the progress of non co operation;
('22', 511, 5, 6, 1242159) (h) by organizing a band of national workers for a service to be called the Indian National Service; and
('22', 511, 6, 7, 1242264) (i) by taking effective steps to raise a national fund to be called the ALL INDIA TILAK MEMORIAL SWARAJ FUND for the purpose of financing the foregoing National Service and the non co operation movement in general.
('22', 511, 7, 8, 1242479) This Congress congratulates the nation upon the progress made so far in working the programme of non co operation, specially with regard to the boycott of Councils by the voters, and claims in the circumstances in which they have been brought into existence, that the new Councils do not represent the country and trusts that those who have allowed themselves to be elected in spite of the deliberate abstention from the polls of an overwhelming majority of their constituents, will see their way to resign their seats in the Councils, and that if they retain their seats in spite of the declared wish of their respective constituencies in direct negation of the principle of democracy, the electors will studiously refrain from asking for any political service from such Councillors.
('22', 511, 8, 9, 1243264) This Congress recognizes the growing friendliness between the police and the soldiery and the people, and hopes that the former will refuse to subordinate their creed and country to the fulfilment of orders of their officers, and, by courteous and considerate behaviour towards the people, will remove the reproach hitherto levelled against them that they are devoid of any regard for the feelings and sentiments of their own people.
('22', 511, 9, 10, 1243698) And this Congress appeals to all people in Government employment pending
('22', 512, 0, 1, 1243771) VOL. 22 : 23 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 513
('22', 512, 1, 2, 1243817) the call of the nation for resignation of their service, to help the national cause by importing greater kindness and stricter honesty in their dealings with their people and fearlessly and openly to attend all popular gatherings whilst refraining from taking any active part therein and, more specially, by openly rendering financial assistance to the national movement.
('22', 512, 2, 3, 1244189) This Congress desires to lay special emphasis on NON VIOLENCE being the integral part of the non co operation resolution and invites the attention of the people to the fact that NON VIOLENCE in word and deed is as essential between people themselves as in respect of the Government, and this Congress is of opinion that the spirit of violence is not only contrary to the growth of a true spirit of democracy but actually retards the enforcement (if necessary) of the other stages of non co operation.
('22', 512, 3, 4, 1244690) Finally, in order that the Khilafat and the Punjab wrongs may be redressed and swaraj established within one year, this Congress urges upon all public bodies, whether affiliated to the Congress or otherwise, to devote their exclusive attention to the promotion of non violence and non co operation with the Government and, inasmuch as the movement of non co operation can only succeed by complete co operation amongst the people themselves, this Congress calls upon public associations to advance Hindu Muslim unity and the Hindu delegates of this Congress call upon the leading Hindus to settle all disputes between Brahmins and non Brahmins, wherever they may be existing, and to make a special effort to rid Hinduism of the reproach of untouchability, and respectfully urges the religious heads to help the growing desire to reform Hinduism in the matter of its treatment of the suppressed classes.
('22', 512, 4, 5, 1245592) Report of the Thirty fifth Session of the Indian National Congress
('22', 512, 5, 6, 1245659) APPENDIX II
('22', 512, 6, 7, 1245671) VICEROY’S SPEECH ON KHILAFAT 1
('22', 512, 7, 8, 1245702) GENTLEMEN,
('22', 512, 8, 9, 1245713) I am very glad to have had this opportunity of meeting you here this afternoon and at having had laid before me one more representation on behalf of the Muslim community with regard to the present situation.
('22', 512, 8, 10, 1245921) I need hardly remind you, though perhaps it is worth while doing so, that I and my Government have repeatedly brought your contentions to the notice of His Majesty’s Government and of the Peace Conferences which have been sitting in Europe on this question.
('22', 512, 8, 11, 1246179) May I remind you that early in the stages of the Peace Conference the Secretary of State, Lord Sinha and the Maharaja of Bikaner, who were then representing India at the Peace Conference, stoutly fought your case before the Peace Conference.
('22', 512, 8, 12, 1246421) But inasmuch as none of these
('22', 512, 9, 13, 1246451) 1 This was delivered in Calcutta on February 24, 1921, to a deputation representing elected Muslim members in the Bengal Legislative Council and Assembly, who had urged modification of the Turkish Peace Terms.
('22', 513, 0, 1, 1246661) 514 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 513, 1, 2, 1246703) gentlemen could be said to represent strictly your community, I asked certain other gentlemen to go actually before the Peace Conference itself and plead the Mohammedan cause, and they were His Highness the Aga Khan, Mr. Aftab Ahmad and Mr. Yusuf Ali, and these gentlemen were heard.
('22', 513, 1, 3, 1246987) Now not only have we done this, but every memorial which any sections of your community have forwarded to me has been forwarded to the Secretary of State and has been supported in the most strenuous terms, not only by official documents from my Government, but by personal telegrams from myself.
('22', 513, 1, 4, 1247283) So that I can assure you, from first to last and long before the non co operation movement began, that we, as a Government, and I, as the head of the Government, strongly supported your contentions, not only before His Majesty’s Government but also before the Peace Conference.
('22', 513, 1, 5, 1247561) And lately in order that we should leave no stone unturned for your case to be represented, not only adequately, but to your own satisfaction, we have again asked certain gentlemen unofficially to go to Europe and present your case there—His Highness the Aga Khan, Mr. Hasan Imam, and Mr. Chhotani, and Mr. Chhotani is accompanied by Dr. Ansari, who will be acting as his secretary.
('22', 513, 2, 6, 1247944) I should think that a recapitulation of what we have done and what we have attempted to do, such as I have laid before you this afternoon, ought to convince you and, I hope, does convince you, that we have left nothing undone which we could do in order to support your case.
('22', 513, 2, 7, 1248219) I am not acquainted with what is going on in London at the present moment; I have no knowledge, either official or private, of the Conferences which are taking place; but I can assure you that, from first to last, we have espoused your cause and we have fought it in a way which, if I was at liberty to place before you the communications which we have sent home, I think would satisfy every individual.
('22', 513, 3, 8, 1248623) In conclusion I must again express my great sympathy with you and my determination to the last moment to press every point which we can in favour of your representations.
('22', 513, 4, 9, 1248794) Speeches by Lord Chelmsford, Vol. II
('22', 513, 5, 10, 1248831) APPENDIX III
('22', 513, 6, 11, 1248844) VICEROY’S SPEECH ON NON CO OPERATION 1
('22', 513, 7, 12, 1248883) MR. CHAIRMAN AND GENTLEMEN,
('22', 513, 8, 13, 1248911) This is the fourth time on which I have had the privilege and pleasure of being the guest of the Calcutta Club.
('22', 513, 8, 14, 1249023) Naturally at the end of five years one looks back upon sins of omission and commission and it is a matter of regret to me that in 1917 when you were so good as to invite me to be your guest, the preoccupations of the work which I was doing with Mr. Montagu at the time prevented me from accepting your
('22', 513, 9, 15, 1249325) 1 Delivered on February 23, 1921, at a dinner given in his honour by the Calcutta Club.
('22', 514, 0, 1, 1249413) VOL. 22 : 23 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 515
('22', 514, 1, 2, 1249459) kind invitation.
('22', 514, 1, 3, 1249476) Otherwise I should have been your guest every year that I paid a visit to Calcutta.
('22', 514, 1, 4, 1249560) I hope that this practice which you have followed in my case will be followed in the case of my successors because I can conceive no more convenient method of bringing the Viceroy into contact with prominent men, and prominent men into touch with the Viceroy, than these annual dinners.
('22', 514, 1, 5, 1249847) In April 1916, on my assumption of office, I paid a short informal visit to Calcutta to leave, as I said at that time, my card at the former capital.
('22', 514, 1, 6, 1249997) Today I have been able to do no more than spare a few days in order to leave my P. P. C. card.
('22', 514, 1, 7, 1250092) I hope, however, that you, gentlemen, who belong to Calcutta, will have realized from my constant visits to Calcutta my fondness for your great city and my regret that fate has rendered it impossible for me to live amongst you as all my predecessors have done.
('22', 514, 2, 8, 1250353) Now, as I look back upon the past five years, I realize the great changes that have taken place.
('22', 514, 2, 9, 1250450) There is an old Latin tag coelum non animum qui trans mare currant.
('22', 514, 2, 10, 1250518) They change their sky and not their mind who cross the sea.
('22', 514, 2, 11, 1250578) I do not believe myself that this was true even of the days when the poet wrote, because environment has a great influence upon the mind of those who are subjected to change.
('22', 514, 2, 12, 1250753) The principle of it is undoubtedly not true of those who have crossed the floor of a House from the Opposition to the Ministerial Bench, because, naturally, for the first time they cease to be critics and become the criticized.
('22', 514, 2, 13, 1250981) This is inherent in the nature of Parliamentary institution everywhere, but it is inevitable that a man who, for the first time, is made acquainted with the reasons for Government action should see greater justification for what the Government does than in the old days when he was not so well acquainted with facts and was inclined to think that nothing that the Government could do was right.
('22', 514, 3, 14, 1251376) Now I am sure you will forgive me, on this last occasion of a visit to your Club, if I dwell for a few moments on the unrestful times through which we are passing.
('22', 514, 3, 15, 1251540) I think I may assume that the mere fact of your presence here tonight proves you to be co operators with Government.
('22', 514, 3, 16, 1251657) We are not the only country which is subject to unrest at the present moment; indeed, look where you like over the world, unrest is almost the order of the day.
('22', 514, 3, 17, 1251818) But you may naturally ask: Granted that this is so, what is your policy with regard to the present situation?
('22', 514, 3, 18, 1251928) Let me summarize the position as I see it.
('22', 514, 3, 19, 1251971) I understand that those who have refused to co operate with Government do so on the broad ground that I and my Government are Satanic!
('22', 514, 3, 20, 1252106) I am glad to think I still have a sense of humour.
('22', 514, 3, 21, 1252157) I have had many epithets applied to myself in my time, but the epithet of “Satanic” has broken entirely new ground Apart, however, from what I conceive to be its peculiar inappropriateness to myself, it surely must appear singularly ill chosen when Indians are at the present moment forming the bulk of the Provincial Governments and a large proportion of the Government of India.
('22', 514, 3, 22, 1252538) I pass on however.
('22', 514, 3, 23, 1252557) The Reforms have been inaugurated and responsibility has been in large measure transferred to Indian hands.
('22', 514, 3, 24, 1252665) How amazing it is then that at such a time those who have for years been asking for greater share in the Government should now, like children, be refusing to play!
('22', 514, 3, 25, 1252829) It reminds me of an American quatrain which I came across in the course of my reading the other day:
('22', 515, 0, 1, 1252930) 516 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('22', 515, 1, 2, 1252972) “Mother, may I go and swim?
('22', 515, 1, 3, 1253000) Yes, my dearest daughter Hang your clothes on a hickory limb, But don’t go near the water.”
('22', 515, 2, 4, 1253092) I cannot help feeling that this quatrain sums up the situation so far as the non co operators are concerned.
('22', 515, 2, 5, 1253201) And now as to our policy with regard to the non co operation movement.
('22', 515, 2, 6, 1253272) The Reforms and the Reformed Councils are the keynote of our policy.
('22', 515, 2, 7, 1253341) Indians now share responsibility with the Government.
('22', 515, 2, 8, 1253395) Therefore I think the Government may well claim from Indians help in combating this agitation.
('22', 515, 2, 9, 1253490) Non co operation is spread by propaganda: it behoves us then, British and Indians, to counter it by propaganda.
('22', 515, 2, 10, 1253602) Non co operation takes hold of grievances where they may exist: it behoves us, so far as in us lies, to remedy these grievances.
('22', 515, 2, 11, 1253731) Non co operation has failed in many of the objects which it set out to attain.
('22', 515, 2, 12, 1253810) An answer in the Imperial Legislature the other day showed how poor the response had been to the demand for the surrender of titles.
('22', 515, 2, 13, 1253943) The existence of the Imperial Legislature and the Provincial Councils shows in this respect too the authors of non co operation have not had their way.
('22', 515, 2, 14, 1254095) I much regret that there are many who have felt themselves obliged to stand out from the Councils.
('22', 515, 2, 15, 1254194) The Councils would have been the better for their help and their views in their deliberations, but the outstanding fact remains that the Councils have been established, are composed of admirable material and are doing their work.
('22', 515, 2, 16, 1254424) Non co operation was attempted in the hijrat movement into Afghanistan.
('22', 515, 2, 17, 1254496) The trail of death and suffering imposed by that exodus upon the unfortunate misguided people who took part in it has, I believe, killed any attempt to revive any such exodus from India.
('22', 515, 2, 18, 1254683) Non co operation succeeded temporarily in inducing emotional boys to leave their schools and colleges—but here again as soon as the emotional ebullition had passed, the students have returned in large numbers to their class rooms.
('22', 515, 2, 19, 1254914) We have then every reason to take heart with regard to the success of the policy which we have adopted.
('22', 515, 2, 20, 1255018) But the non co operators having failed with the classes, especially the educated classes, are now devoting their attention to the masses.
('22', 515, 2, 21, 1255156) Here again, we must endeavour by co ordinated effort to teach the masses aright.
('22', 515, 3, 22, 1255237) There is a Muslim aspect of the present situation.
('22', 515, 3, 23, 1255288) No one could have done more than I to bring Muslim views and sentiments of the community to the Peace Conferences which have been considering the Turkish Peace Terms, and no one—not a Muslim—could have shown more dislike than I to the terms of the Turkish Peace Treaty.
('22', 515, 3, 24, 1255558) I say then that we have every reason to be especially tender and sympathetic to those Mohammedans who have been led into the non co operation movement by their views with regard to the Turkish Peace Treaty.
('22', 515, 3, 25, 1255765) But a moment may come when our policy fails, and when the two alternatives of order on the one hand, or anarchy on the other, alone face us.
('22', 515, 3, 26, 1255906) In such an event there can be only one course for the Government to pursue and that is to uphold the cause of order.
('22', 515, 3, 27, 1256023) We shall then ask all responsible men to range themselves on the side of order, and here I am confident that
('22', 516, 0, 1, 1256132) VOL. 22 : 23 NOVEMBER, 1920 5 APRIL, 1921 517
('22', 516, 1, 2, 1256178) the Reformed Councils will play their part.
('22', 516, 1, 3, 1256222) We, as a Government, will place all the facts before them and all our cards on the table, and I am confident that when we prove to them that the alternative is between order and anarchy, there will be only one response made and that is that “we will support you in any action that you may consider necessary to maintain order in the country.”
('22', 516, 2, 4, 1256565) This is my last visit to Calcutta, and I feel that I cannot leave without paying an acknowledgment to Lord Ronaldshay and his colleagues.
('22', 516, 2, 5, 1256703) I should like to acknowledge the loyal co operation of the Bengal Government with my Government.
('22', 516, 2, 6, 1256800) I should like to recognize the wisdom and sagacity which have marked their administration, and personally thank Lord Ronaldshay for the friendship and support which he has always accorded me.
('22', 516, 2, 7, 1256992) Differences there may have been from time to time, but these differences do not detract from that general policy of loyal co operation which I have always experienced at the hands of Lord Ronaldshay and his colleagues.
('22', 516, 3, 8, 1257211) Speeches by Lord Chelmsford, Vol. II
